Mere unaided natural selection obviously can not be trusted to produce a fine race . ‚Äù Nothing would convince [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria that the preservation of [weakly persons]4368-weakly persons was not injurious to [the community]4369-the community . To this [the Professor]4071-the professor replied , that what is lost by [their]1180-short - sighted people salvation is more than paid back by the better conditions that secured it . [The strong]3695-the strong , [he]4071-the professor said , were strengthened and enabled to retain [their]3695-the strong strength by that which saves the lives of [the weak]4352-the weak . ‚Äú[1178-you] Besides , do [you]1178-you suppose [a race]1179-a race could gain , in the long run , by defiance of its best instincts ? Never ! If the laws of health in body and in mind were at variance , leaving [us]1171-we a hard choice between physical and moral disease , then indeed no despair could be too black . But all experience and all insight testify to the exact opposite . Heavens , how [short - sighted people]1180-short - sighted people are ! It is not the protection of [the weak]4352-the weak , but the evil and stupid deeds that have made [them]1180-short - sighted people so , that [we]1171-we have to thank for the miseries of disease . And for [our]1171-we redemption ‚Äî powers of [the universe]420-the universe ! it is not to the cowardly sacrifice of [the unfortunate]1183-the unfortunate that [we]1171-we must trust , but to a more brotherly spirit of loyalty , a more generous treatment of [all who are defenceless]1184-all who are defenceless , a more faithful holding together among [ourselves]1171-we ‚Äî [weak and strong , favoured and luckless]1185-weak and strong , favoured and luckless . ‚Äù [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria was silent for a moment . Ah ! [you]1200-you may quote [authorities]1201-authorities , wise and good , till [you]1200-you are hoarse ! ‚Äù cried [the Professor]4071-the professor , with a burst of energy ; ‚Äú[1201-authorities] but [they]1201-authorities will not convince [me]0-i that black is white . [I]0-i care not who may uphold the doctrine of vicarious sacrifice ; it is monstrous , it is dastardly , it is damnable ! ‚Äù There are some sentences and some incidents that fix themselves , once for all , in the memory , often without apparent reason , to remain as an influence throughout life . [Her]4377-the silent member of the trio deep regret at [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria 's departure , [her]4377-the silent member of the trio dread of [her]4377-the silent member of the trio own future , [her]4377-the silent member of the trio growing sense of the torment , and horror , and sacrifice that form so large a part of the order of [the world]334-the world , all appeared to be united fantastically in malignant and threatening form , in the final words of [the Professor]4071-the professor : ‚Äú[1201-authorities] It is monstrous , it is dastardly , it is damnable ! ‚Äù The agony of [the whole earth]4382-the whole earth seemed to hang over the sleeper , hovering and black and intolerable , crushing [her]4377-the silent member of the trio with a sense of hopeless pity and fatigue . And on waking , though the absurd masquerading of words and thoughts had ceased , [she]4377-the silent member of the trio was still weighed down with the horror of the dream , which [she]4377-the silent member of the trio knew had a corresponding reality still more awful . And there was no adversary to all this anguish ; [everybody]3781-everybody acquiesced , nay , [everybody]3781-everybody threw on yet another log to [the martyr]4385-the martyr 's pile , and coolly watched the hungry flames at [their]3781-everybody work , for ‚Äú[1201-authorities] Nature , ‚Äù [they]3781-everybody all agreed , demanded sacrifice . No , no ; there was no help anywhere on [earth]787-earth , no help , no help . Nothing fits in with [one]329-one 's eccentric custom ; everything conspires to discourage it . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could give [you]0-i a helping hand , ‚Äù said [the Professor]4071-the professor wistfully ; ‚Äú[0-i] but [one]329-one is so powerless . [Each of [us]1227-our]1226-each of us has to fight the real battle of life alone . [Nobody]3732-nobody can see with [our]1227-our eyes , or feel with [our]1227-our nerves . The crux of the difficulty [each]3686-each bears for [himself]3686-each . But friendship can help [us]1227-our to believe the struggle worth while ; it can sustain [our]1227-our courage and it can offer sympathy in victory,‚Äîbut still more faithfully in defeat . ‚Äù [HADRIA]211-hadria had determined upon making a strong and patient effort to pursue [her]211-hadria work during the winter , while doing [her]211-hadria best , at the same time , to please [[her]211-hadria mother]520-her mother , and to make up to [her]520-her mother , as well as [she]211-hadria could , for [Algitha]81-algitha 's departure . [She]211-hadria would not be dismayed by difficulties : as [the Professor]4071-the professor said , only cowards and [weaklings]4411-weaklings escaped these . [She]211-hadria treated [herself]211-hadria austerely , and found [her]211-hadria power of concentration increasing , and [her]211-hadria hold on [herself]211-hadria greater . But , as usual , [her]211-hadria greatest effort had to be given , not to the work itself , but to win opportunity to pursue it . [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton opposed [[her]97-mrs. fullerton daughter]3909-her daughter 's endeavours as firmly as ever . It was not good for [a girl]3734-a girl to be selfishly pre - occupied . [She]211-hadria ought to think of [others]432-others . If [Hadria]211-hadria yielded the point on any particular occasion , [her]211-hadria mood and [her]211-hadria work were destroyed : if [she]211-hadria resisted , they were equally destroyed , through the nervous disturbance and the intense depression which followed the winning of a liberty too dearly bought . The incessant rising and quelling of [her]211-hadria impulse and [her]211-hadria courage ‚Äî like the ebb and flow of tides ‚Äî represented a vast amount of force not merely wasted , but expended in producing a dangerous wear and tear upon the system . The process told upon [her]211-hadria health , and was the beginning of the weakening and unbalancing of the splendid constitution which [Hadria]211-hadria , in common with [every member of [the family]360-the family]4415-every member of the family , enjoyed as a birthright . The injury was insidious but serious . [Hadria]211-hadria , unable to command any certain part of the day , began to sit up at night . This led to a direct clash of wills . [Mr. Fullerton]89-mr. fullerton said that [the girl]3739-the girl was doing [her]3739-the girl best to ruin [her]211-hadria health for life ; [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton wished to know why [Hadria]211-hadria , who had all the day at [her]211-hadria disposal , could not spend the night rationally . ‚Äú[0-i] But [I]0-i have n't all the day , or any part of it , for certain , ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú[0-i] If [you]0-i grudge the little services [you]0-i do for [me]0-i , pray abandon [them]1230-them , ‚Äù said [the mother]578-the mother , genuinely hurt . [Hadria]211-hadria entered [[her]211-hadria room]4419-her room , one evening , tired out and profoundly depressed . A table , covered with books , stood beside the fire . [She]211-hadria gave the top - heavy pile an impatient thrust and the mass fell , with a great crash , to the floor . A heap of manuscript ‚Äî [her]211-hadria musical achievement for the past year ‚Äî was involved in the fall . [She]211-hadria contemplated the wreck gravely . ‚Äú[0-i] Yes , it is [I]0-i who am weak , not circumstance that is strong . If [I]0-i could keep [my]0-i mind unmoved by the irritations ; if [I]0-i could quarrel with [mother]3851-mother , and displease [father]3862-father , and offend all [the world]334-the world without a qualm , or without losing the delicate balance of thought and mood necessary for composition , then [I]0-i should , to some extent , triumph over [my]0-i circumstances ; [I]0-i should not lose so much time in this wretched unstringing . Only were [I]0-i so immovably constituted , is it probable that [I]0-i should be able to compose at all ? ‚Äù [She]211-hadria drew the score towards [her]211-hadria . ‚Äú[3687-people] [People]3687-people are surprised that [women]606-women have never done anything noteworthy in music . [People]3687-people are so intelligent ! ‚Äù [She]211-hadria turned over the pages critically . If only this instinct were not so overwhelmingly strong ! [Hadria]211-hadria wondered how many [other women , from the beginning of history]4420-other women , from the beginning of history , had cursed the impulse to create ! Fortunately , it was sometimes extinguished altogether , as to - night , for instance , when every impression , every desire was swept clean out of [her]211-hadria , and [her]211-hadria mind presented a creditable blank , such as really ought to satisfy [the most exacting social mentor]4421-the most exacting social mentor . In such a state , [a woman]3753-a woman might be induced to accept anything ! [Hadria]211-hadria brought out two letters from [her]211-hadria pocket ; one from [the Professor]4071-the professor , the other from [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . The latter had been writing frequently of late , pointing out the danger of [Hadria]211-hadria 's exaggerated ideas , and the probability of [their]4424-their ruining [her]211-hadria happiness in life . [Valeria]109-valeria had suffered [herself]109-valeria from ‚Äú[3687-people] ideas , ‚Äù and knew how fatal they were . Life could not be exactly as [one]329-one would have it , and it was absolutely necessary , in order to avoid misery for [oneself]329-one and [others]432-others , to consent to take things more or less as they were ; to make up [one]329-one 's mind to bend a little , rather than have to break , in the end . Things were never quite so shocking as they seemed to [one]329-one 's youthful imagination . [The world]334-the world was made up of compromises . Good was mixed with evil everywhere . The domestic idea , as [Hadria]211-hadria called it , might be , in its present phase , somewhat offensive , but it could be redeemed in its application , in the details and ‚Äú[1237-they] extenuating circumstances . ‚Äù [Valeria]109-valeria could not warn [Hadria]211-hadria too earnestly against falling into the mistake that [Valeria]109-valeria [herself]109-valeria had made . [She]109-valeria had repudiated the notion of anything short of an ideal union ; a perfect comradeship , without the shadow of restraint or bondage in the relationship ; and not having found it , [she]109-valeria had refused the tie altogether . [She]109-valeria could not bring [herself]109-valeria to accept the lesser thing , having conceived the possibility of the greater . [She]109-valeria now saw [her]109-valeria error , and repented it . [She]109-valeria was reaping the penalty in a lonely and unsatisfied life . For a long time [her]109-valeria work had seemed to suffice , but [she]109-valeria felt now that [she]109-valeria had been trusting to a broken reed . [She]109-valeria was terrified at [her]109-valeria solitude . [She]109-valeria could not face the thought of old age , without a single close tie , without a [home]3770-home , without a hold upon [her]109-valeria race . [She]109-valeria ended by entreating [Hadria]211-hadria not to refuse marriage merely because [she]109-valeria could not find [a man]3704-a man to agree with [her]109-valeria in everything , or capable of entering into the spirit of the relationship that perhaps would unite [the men]3678-the men and [women of the future]4433-women of the future . It was a pity that [Hadria]211-hadria had not been born a generation later , but since [she]109-valeria had come into [the world]334-the world at this time of transition , [she]109-valeria must try to avoid the tragedy that threatens [all spirits who are pointing towards the new order]4435-all spirits who are pointing towards the new order , while the old is still working out its unexhausted impetus . This reiterated advice had begun to trouble [Hadria]211-hadria . It did not convince [her]211-hadria , but [Valeria]109-valeria 's words were incessantly repeating themselves in [her]211-hadria mind working as a ferment among [her]211-hadria thoughts . The letters from [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria and [the Professor]4071-the professor were to [her]211-hadria , a source of great pleasure and of great pain . In [her]211-hadria depressed moods , they would often rather increase [her]211-hadria despondency , because [the writers]4437-the writers used to take for granted so many achievements that [she]211-hadria had not been able to accomplish . ‚Äú[1237-they] [They]1237-they think [I]0-i am living and progressing as [they]1237-they are ; [they]1237-they do not know that the riot and stir of intellectual life has ceased . [I]0-i am like a creature struggling in a quicksand . ‚Äù On [the Professor]4071-the professor 's letter , the comments were of a different character . [He]4071-the professor had recommended [her]211-hadria to read certain books , and reminded [her]211-hadria that [no possessor of good books]4439-no possessor of good books could lack the privilege of spiritual sanctuary . ‚Äú[0-i] Ah ! yes , [I]0-i know few pleasures so great as that of finding [one]329-one 's own idea , or hope , or longing , finely expressed , half - born thoughts alive and of stately stature ; and then the exquisite touches of art upon quick nerves , the enlarging of the realms of imagination , knowledge , the heightening of perceptions , intuitions ; finally the blessed power of escaping from [oneself]1239-oneself , with the paradoxical reward of greater self - realization ! But , ah , [Professor]1240-professor , to [me]0-i there is a ‚Äò but ‚Äô even here . [I]0-i am oppressed by a sense of the discrepancy between [the world]334-the world that books disclose to [me]0-i , and [the world that [I]0-i [myself]0-i inhabit]1242-the world that i myself inhabit . In books , the impossibilities are all left out . They give [you]1243-you no sense of the sordid Inevitable that looms so large on [the grey horizon]1244-the grey horizon . Another more personal quarrel that [I]0-i have with books is on account of [their]1245-their attacking all [my]0-i pet prejudices , and sneering at [the type of woman that [I]0-i have the misfortune to belong to]1246-the type of woman that i have the misfortune to belong to . [I]0-i am always exhorted to cure [myself]0-i of being [myself]0-i . Nothing less would suffice . Now this is wounding . All [my]0-i particular feelings , [my]0-i strongest beliefs , are condemned , directly or by inference . [I]0-i could almost believe that there is a literary conspiracy to reform [me]0-i . [The ‚Äú true women ‚Äù[1247-the ‚Äú true women ‚Äù of literature] of literature]1247-the ‚Äú true women ‚Äù of literature infallibly think and feel precisely as [I]0-i do not think and feel , while the sentiments that [I]0-i detest ‚Äî woe is [me]0-i ‚Äî are lauded to the skies . Truly , if [we]1248-we [women]606-women do n't know exactly what [we]1248-we ought to think and feel , it is not for want of telling . Yet [you]1250-you say , [Professor]1240-professor , in this very letter , that the sense of having a peculiar experience is always an illusion , that every feeling of [ours]1248-we has been felt before , if not in [our]1248-we own day , then in the crowded past , with its throngs of forgotten lives and unrecorded experiences . [I]0-i wish to heaven [I]0-i could meet [those who have had exactly mine]1252-those who have had exactly mine ! ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria did not keep up an active correspondence with [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria or with [the Professor]4071-the professor . [She]211-hadria had no idea of adding to the burden of [their]4441-their busy lives , by wails for sympathy . It seemed to [her]211-hadria feeble , and contemptible , to ask to be dragged up by [their]4441-their strength , instead of exerting [her]211-hadria own . If that were insufficient , why then let [her]211-hadria go down , as [thousands]3718-thousands had gone down before [her]211-hadria . As [a miser]4443-a miser telling [his]4443-a miser gold , [she]211-hadria would read and re - read those occasional letters , written amidst the stress of life at high pressure , and bearing evidence of that life of thought and work , in [their]4441-their tense , full - packed phrases . With what a throb of longing and envy [Hadria]211-hadria used to feel the vibration through [her]211-hadria own nerves ! It was only when completely exhausted and harassed that the response was lacking . To - night everything seemed to be obliterated . [Her]211-hadria hope , [her]211-hadria interest were , for the moment , tired out . [[Her]211-hadria friends]4444-her friends would be disappointed in [her]211-hadria , but there was no help for it . [She]211-hadria picked up the score of [her]211-hadria music , and stood , with a handful of the once precious offspring of [her]211-hadria brain held out towards the flames . Then [she]211-hadria drew it back , and half closed [her]211-hadria eyes in self - scrutinizing thought . ‚Äú[1252-those who have had exactly mine] Come now , ‚Äù [she]211-hadria said to [herself]211-hadria , ‚Äú[1253-you] are [you]1253-you sincere in [your]1253-you intention of giving up ? Are [you]1253-you pot doing this in a fit of spite against destiny ? as if destiny cared two straws . Heavens ! what a poor little piece of melodrama . And to think that [you]1253-you should have actually taken [yourself]1253-you in it by it . [One]329-one acts so badly with only [oneself]329-one for [audience]1255-audience . [You]1253-you know perfectly well that [you]1253-you are not going to give in , [you]1253-you are not going to attempt to stifle that which is the centre of [your]1253-you life : [you]1253-you have not courage for such slow suicide . Do n't add insincerity to the other faults that are laid to [your]1253-you account ‚Äî ‚Äù [She]211-hadria mused over the little self - administered lecture . And probing down into [her]211-hadria consciousness , [she]211-hadria realized that [she]211-hadria could not face the thought of surrender . [She]211-hadria meant to fight on . The notion of giving in had been seized instinctively , for a moment of rest . Nothing should really make [her]211-hadria cease the struggle , until the power itself had been destroyed . [She]211-hadria was sure of it , in [her]211-hadria heart , in spite of failures and miserably inadequate expressions of it . Suddenly , as a shaft of light through parting clouds , came bursting forth , radiant , rejoicing , that sense of power , large , resistless , genial as morning sunshine . Yes , yes , let [them]4445-they say what [they]4445-they might , discourage , smile , or frown as [they]4445-they would , the faculty was given to [her]211-hadria , and [she]211-hadria would fight for opportunity to use it while [she]211-hadria had breath . AS if it had all been ingeniously planned , the minutest incidents and conditions of [Hadria]211-hadria 's life conspired towards the event that was to decide its drift for ever . Often , in the dim afternoon , [she]211-hadria would sit by the window and watch the rain sweeping across [the country]401-the country , longing then for [Temperley]118-hubert 's music , which used to make the wild scene so unspeakably beautiful . Now there was no music , no music anywhere , only this fierce and mournful rush of the wind , which seemed as if it were trying to utter some universal grief . At sunset , braving the cold , [she]211-hadria would mount the creaking staircase , pass along [the silent upper corridors]4447-the silent upper corridors , and on through [the empty rooms]4448-the empty rooms to [the garret in [the tower]3991-the tower]4449-the garret in the tower . The solitude was a relief ; the strangeness of the scene appealed to some wild instinct , and to the intense melancholy that lurks in the Celtic nature . Even at night , [she]211-hadria did not shrink from braving the glooms and silences of [the deserted upper floor]4451-the deserted upper floor , nor the solitude of [the garret]293-the garret , which appeared the deeper , from the many memories of happy evenings that it evoked . [She]211-hadria wished [Ernest]86-ernest would come [home]3770-home . It was so long since [she]211-hadria had seen [[her]211-hadria favourite brother]4454-her favourite brother . [She]211-hadria could not bear the thought of [his]86-ernest drifting away from [her]211-hadria . What talks [they]4455-they had had in [this old garret]4456-this old garret ! These nights in [the tower]3991-the tower , among the winds , soothed the trouble of [her]211-hadria spirit as nothing else had power to do . The mystery of life , the thrill of existence , touched [her]211-hadria with a strange joy that ran perilously near to pain . What vast dim possibilities lurked out there , in [the hollows of [the hills]413-the hills]4458-the hollows of the hills ! What inspiration thundered in the voice of the prophet wind ! Once , [she]211-hadria had gone [downstairs]4460-downstairs and out , alone , in a tearing storm , to wander across [the bleak pastures]4461-the bleak pastures , wrapt round by the wind as by a flame ; at one with the desperate elemental thing . [The wanderer]4462-the wanderer felt [herself]211-hadria caught into the heart of [some vast unknown power , of which the wind was but a thrall]4463-some vast unknown power , of which the wind was but a thrall , until [she]211-hadria became , for a moment , consciously part of that which was universal . [Her]211-hadria personality grew dim [she]211-hadria stood , as it seemed , face to face with Nature , divided from the ultimate truth by only a thin veil , to temper the splendour and the terror . Then the tension of personal feeling was loosened . [She]211-hadria saw how entirely vain and futile were the things of life that [we]4464-we grieve and struggle over . It was not a side , an aspect of existence , but the whole of it that seemed to storm round [her]211-hadria , in the darkness . No wonder , when the wind was let loose among [the mountains]4465-the mountains , that [the old Highland people]4466-the old highland people thought that [their]4466-the old highland people dead were about [them]4466-the old highland people . All night long , after [Hadria]211-hadria returned to [[her]211-hadria room]4419-her room in [the keep]294-the keep , the wind kept up its cannonade against the walls , hooting in the chimneys with derisive voices , and flinging itself , in mad revolt , against [the old - established hills]4469-the old - established hills and [the stable earth]4470-the stable earth , which changed its forms only in slow obedience to the persuadings of the elements , in the passing of centuries . It cared nothing for the passion of a single storm . And then came reaction , doubt . After all , humanity was a puny production of the Ages . [Men]3698-men and [women]606-women were like the struggling animalcul√¶ that [[her]211-hadria father]609-her father had so often shewn [the boys]3870-the boys , in a drop of [magnified ditch - water]4475-magnified ditch - water ; yet not quite like those microscopic insects , for the stupendous processes of life had at last created a widening consciousness , a mind which could perceive the bewildering vastness of Nature and its own smallness , which could , in some measure , get outside its own particular ditch , and the strife and struggle of it , groping upwards for larger realities ‚Äî ‚Äú[1253-you] Over [us]1256-us stars and under [us]1256-us graves . ‚Äù To go down next morning to breakfast ; to meet the usual homely events , was bewildering after such a night . Which was dream : this or that ? So solid and convincing seemed , at times , the interests and objects of every day , that [Hadria]211-hadria would veer round to a sudden conviction that these things , or what they symbolized , were indeed the solid facts of human life , and that all other impressions arose from the disorderly working of overcharged brain - cells . It was a little ailment of youth and would pass off . Had it been possible to describe to [[her]211-hadria father]609-her father the impressions made upon [her]211-hadria by [the world]334-the world and Nature , as they had presented themselves to [her]211-hadria imagination from [her]211-hadria childhood , [he]609-her father would have prescribed change of air and gymnastics . Perhaps that was the really rational view of the matter . But what if these hygienic measures cured [her]211-hadria of the haunting consciousness of mystery and vastness ; what if [she]211-hadria became convinced of the essential importance of the Gordon pedigree , or of the amount of social consideration due to [the family who had taken [Clarenoc]7-clarenoc]4478-the family who had taken clarenoc ? Would that alter the bewildring truths of which [she]211-hadria would have ceased to think ? No ; it would only mean that the animalcule had returned to the occupations of [[its]7-clarenoc ditch]4479-its ditch , while [the worlds]4480-the worlds and [the peoples]4481-the peoples went spinning to [their]4481-the peoples destiny . ‚Äú[1253-you] Do the duty that lies nearest [thee]1257-thee , ‚Äù counselled [everybody]3781-everybody : [people of all kinds , books of all kinds]4483-people of all kinds , books of all kinds . ‚Äú[1253-you] Cheap , well - sounding advice , ‚Äù thought [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äú[1253-you] sure of popularity ! Continue to wriggle industriously , O animalcule , in [that particular ditch wherein it has pleased [heaven]4276-heaven to place [thee]1257-thee]1258-that particular ditch wherein it has pleased heaven to place thee ; seek not the flowing stream and [the salt ocean]1260-the salt ocean ; and if , some clear night , a star finds room to mirror itself in [[thy]1257-thee little stagnant world]1261-thy little stagnant world , shining through the fat weeds and slime that almost shut out the heavens , pray be careful not to pay too much heed to [the high - born luminary]1262-the high - born luminary . Look to [your]1257-thee wriggling ; that is [your]1257-thee proper business . [An animalcule that does not wriggle]1263-an animalcule that does not wriggle must be morbid or peculiar . All will tender , in different forms of varying elegance , the safe and simple admonition : ‚Äò Wriggle and be damned to [you]1257-thee ! ‚Äô ‚Äù It was at this somewhat fevered moment , that [Hubert Temperley]118-hubert appeared , once more , upon the scene . [Hadria]211-hadria was with [[her]211-hadria mother]520-her mother , taking tea at [Drumgarren]12-drumgarren , when [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon , catching the sounds of [carriage wheels]4485-carriage wheels , announced that [she]91-mrs. gordon was expecting [Hubert]118-hubert and [[his]118-hubert sister]351-his sister for a visit . In another second , [the travellers]4487-the travellers were in [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room . [Hubert]118-hubert 's self - possession was equal to the occasion . [He]118-hubert introduced [[his]118-hubert sister]351-his sister to [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton and [Hadria]211-hadria . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley was [his]118-hubert junior by a year ; [a slight , neatly - built young woman , with a sort of tact that went on brilliantly up to a certain point , and then suddenly collapsed altogether]4490-a slight , neatly - built young woman , with a sort of tact that went on brilliantly up to a certain point , and then suddenly collapsed altogether . [She]141-miss temperley had [[her]141-miss temperley brother]309-her brother 's self - complacency , and an air of encouragement which [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon seemed to find most gratifying . [She]141-miss temperley dressed perfectly , in quiet Parisian fashion . [Hadria]211-hadria saw that [[her]141-miss temperley brother]309-her brother had taken [her]141-miss temperley into [his]309-her brother confidence , or [she]141-miss temperley concluded so from something in [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley 's manner . [The latter]590-the latter treated [Hadria]211-hadria with a certain familiarity , as if [she]590-the latter had known [her]211-hadria for some time , and [she]590-the latter had a way of seeming to take [her]211-hadria apart , when addressing [her]211-hadria , as if there were a sort of understanding between [them]4494-them . It was here that [her]141-miss temperley instinct failed [her]141-miss temperley ; for [she]141-miss temperley seemed unaware that this assumption of an intimacy that did not exist was liable to be resented , and that it might be unpleasant to be expected to catch special remarks sent over the heads of [the others]303-the others , although ostensibly for the common weal . [Hadria]211-hadria thought that [she]211-hadria had never seen so strange a contrast as [this young woman]4496-this young woman 's behaviour , within and without the circle of [her]141-miss temperley perceptions . It was the more remarkable , since [her]211-hadria mind was bent upon the details and niceties of conduct , and the nuances of existence . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i shall come and see [you]1264-you as soon as [I]0-i can , ‚Äù [she]0-i promised , when [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton rose to leave . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley kept [her]141-miss temperley word . Do think of it . ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria flushed . ‚Äú[0-i] Oh , thank [you]0-i , [I]0-i could not do that ‚Äî [I]0-i ‚Äî ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i understand [you]211-hadria , dear [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äù said [Henriette]142-henriette , drawing [her]142-henriette chair closer to the fire . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria know , [Hubert]118-hubert can never keep anything of great importance from [me]0-i . ‚Äù [She]0-i looked arch . [He]118-hubert very nearly refused it . [He]118-hubert feared that it would be unpleasant for [you]211-hadria . But [I]0-i insisted on [his]118-hubert coming . Why should [he]118-hubert not ? [He]118-hubert would like so much to come here more often , but again [he]118-hubert fears to displease [you]211-hadria . [He]118-hubert is not a [Temperley]141-miss temperley for nothing . [They]1271-they are not of the race of [fools who rush in where angels fear to tread]1272-fools who rush in where angels fear to tread . ‚Äù ‚Äú[1271-they] Are [they]1271-they not ? ‚Äù asked [Hadria]211-hadria absently . ‚Äú[1273-we] [We]1273-we both see [your]211-hadria difficulty , ‚Äù [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley went on . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [Hubert]118-hubert would not so misunderstand [you]211-hadria ‚Äî [the dear fellow]1274-the dear fellow is full of delicacy ‚Äî and [I]0-i should dearly love to hear [him]118-hubert play to [your]211-hadria accompaniment ; [he]118-hubert used to enjoy those practices so much . Would [you]211-hadria think [him]118-hubert intrusive if [he]118-hubert brought [his]118-hubert ' cello some afternoon ? ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria , not without an uneasy qualm , agreed to the suggestion , though by no means cordially . [Accordingly brother]4503-accordingly brother and [sister]1054-sister arrived , one afternoon , for the practice . [Henriette]142-henriette took the leadership , visibly employed tact and judgment , talked a great deal , and was surprisingly delicate , as beseemed a [Temperley]141-miss temperley . [Hadria]211-hadria found the occasion somewhat trying nevertheless , and [Hubert]118-hubert stumbled , at first , in [his]118-hubert playing . In a few minutes , however , [both musicians]4505-both musicians became possessed by the music , and then all went well . [Henriette]142-henriette sat in an easy chair and listened critically . Now and then [she]142-henriette would call out ‚Äú[211-hadria] bravo , ‚Äù or ‚Äú[211-hadria] admirable , ‚Äù and when the performance was over , [she]142-henriette was warm in [her]142-henriette congratulations . [Hadria]211-hadria was flushed with the effort and pleasure of the performance . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [I]0-i never heard [Hubert]118-hubert 's playing to such advantage , ‚Äù said [[his]118-hubert sister]351-his sister . ‚Äú[118-hubert] [I]0-i seem to hear it for the first time . [You]1275-you really ought to practise together often . ‚Äù Another afternoon was appointed ; [Henriette]142-henriette left [Hadria]211-hadria almost no choice . After the next meeting , the constraint had a little worn off , and the temptation to continue the practising was very strong . [Henriette]142-henriette 's presence was reassuring . And then [Hubert]118-hubert seemed so reasonable , and had apparently put the past out of [his]118-hubert mind altogether . After the practice , [brother]4507-brother and [sister]1054-sister would linger a little in [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room , chatting . [Hubert]118-hubert appeared to advantage in [[his]118-hubert sister]351-his sister 's society . [She]142-henriette had a way of striking [his]118-hubert best vein . [Her]142-henriette own talent ran with [his]118-hubert , appealed to it , and created the conditions for its display . [Her]142-henriette presence and inspiration seemed to produce , on [his]118-hubert ability , a sort of cumulative effect . [Henriette]142-henriette set all the familiar machinery in motion ; pressed the right button , and [[her]142-henriette brother]309-her brother became brilliant . A slight touch of diffidence in [his]118-hubert manner softened the effect of [his]118-hubert usual complacency . [Hadria]211-hadria liked [him]118-hubert better than [she]211-hadria had liked [him]118-hubert on [his]118-hubert previous visit . [His]118-hubert innate refinement appealed to [her]211-hadria powerfully . Moreover , [he]118-hubert was cultivated and well - read , and [his]118-hubert society was agreeable . Oh , why did this everlasting , matrimonial idea come in and spoil everything ? Why could not [men]3698-men and [women]606-women have interests in common , without wishing instantly to plunge into a condition of things which hampered and crippled [them]4514-them so miserably ? [Hadria]211-hadria was disposed to under - rate all defects , and to make the most of all virtues in [Hubert]118-hubert , at the present moment . [He]118-hubert had come at just the right time to make a favourable impression upon [her]211-hadria ; for the loneliness of [her]211-hadria life had begun to leave its mark , and to render [her]211-hadria extremely sensitive to influence . [She]211-hadria was [an alien among [the people of [her]211-hadria circle]4516-the people of her circle]4515-an alien among the people of her circle ; and [she]211-hadria felt vaguely guilty in failing to share [their]4516-the people of her circle ideas and ambitions . [Their]4516-the people of her circle glances , [their]4516-the people of her circle silences , conveyed a world of cold surprise and condemnation . [Hubert]118-hubert was tolerance [itself]118-hubert compared with [the majority of [[her]211-hadria associates]4518-her associates]4517-the majority of her associates . [She]211-hadria felt almost as if [he]118-hubert had done [her]211-hadria a personal kindness when [he]118-hubert omitted to look astonished at [her]211-hadria remarks , or to ignore them as ‚Äú[1275-you] awkward . ‚Äù Yet [she]211-hadria felt uneasy about this renewal of the practices , and tried to avoid them as often as possible , though sorely against [her]211-hadria inclination . They were so great a relief and enjoyment . [Her]211-hadria inexperience , and [her]211-hadria carelessness of conventional standards , put [her]211-hadria somewhat off [her]211-hadria guard . [Hubert]118-hubert showed no signs of even remembering the interview of last year , that had been cut short by [[her]211-hadria father]609-her father 's entrance . Why should [she]211-hadria insist on keeping it in mind ? It was foolish . Moreover [she]211-hadria had been expressly given to understand , in a most pointed manner , that [her]211-hadria conduct would not be misinterpreted if [she]211-hadria allowed [him]118-hubert to come occasionally . From several remarks that [Temperley]141-miss temperley made , [she]211-hadria saw that [he]118-hubert too regarded the ordinary domestic existence with distaste . It offended [his]118-hubert fastidiousness . [He]118-hubert was fastidious to [his]118-hubert finger - tips . It amused [Hadria]211-hadria to note the contrast between [him]118-hubert and [Mr. Gordon]93-mr. gordon , who was [a typical father of [a family]4521-a family]4520-a typical father of a family ; limited in [his]93-mr. gordon interests to that circle ; [an amiable ruler of [a tiny , somewhat absurd little world]4523-a tiny , somewhat absurd little world , pompous and important and inconceivably dull]4522-an amiable ruler of a tiny , somewhat absurd little world , pompous and important and inconceivably dull . The bourgeois side of this life was evidently displeasing to [Hubert]118-hubert . Good taste was [his]118-hubert fetish . From [his]118-hubert remarks about [women]606-women , [Hadria]211-hadria was led to observe how subtly critical [he]118-hubert was with regard to feminine qualities , and wondered if [his]118-hubert preference for [herself]118-hubert ought to be regarded as a great compliment . [Henriette]142-henriette congratulated [her]142-henriette on having been admired by [the fastidious Hubert]118-hubert . ‚Äú[1275-you] Let [us]1276-us hope it speaks well for [me]0-i , ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria replied with a cynical smile , ‚Äú[1275-you] but [I]0-i have so often noticed that [men who are very difficult to please]1277-men who are very difficult to please , choose for the domestic hearth [the most dreary and unattractive woman of [their]1277-men who are very difficult to please acquaintance]1278-the most dreary and unattractive woman of their acquaintance ! [I]0-i sometimes doubt if [men]3698-men ever do marry [the women [they]3698-men most admire]1280-the women they most admire . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3698-men] [They]3698-men do , when [they]3698-men can win [them]3698-men , ‚Äù said [Henriette]142-henriette . DURING [Henriette]142-henriette 's visit , one of the meetings of [the Preposterous Society]3682-the preposterous society fell due , and [she]142-henriette expressed a strong wish to be present . [She]142-henriette also craved the privilege of choosing the subject of discussion . Finally , [she]142-henriette received a formal request from [the members]4526-the members to give the lecture [herself]142-henriette . [She]142-henriette was full of enthusiasm about [the Society]359-the society ( such an educating influence ! ) , and prepared [her]142-henriette paper with great care . There had been a tendency among [the circle]4528-the circle , to politely disagree with [Henriette]142-henriette . [Her]142-henriette ideas respecting various burning topics were at variance with the trend of opinion at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee , and [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley was expected to take this opportunity of enlightening [the family]360-the family . [The family]360-the family was equally resolved not to be enlightened . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i have chosen for [my]0-i subject to - night , ‚Äù said [the lecturer]339-the lecturer , ‚Äú[0-i] one that is beginning to occupy public attention very largely : [I]0-i mean the sphere of [woman in society]1281-woman in society . ‚Äù [The audience]323-the audience , among whom [Hubert]118-hubert had been admitted at [[his]118-hubert sister]351-his sister 's earnest request , drew [themselves]323-the audience together , and a little murmur of battle ran along the line . [Henriette]142-henriette 's figure , in [her]142-henriette well - fitting Parisian gown , looked singularly out of place in [the garret]293-the garret , with the crazy old candle - holder beside [her]142-henriette , the yellow flame of the candle flinging fantastic shadows on the vaulted roof , preposterously distorting [her]142-henriette neat form , as if in wicked mockery . The moonlight streamed in , as usual on the nights chosen by [the Society]359-the society for [their]359-the society meetings . [Henriette]142-henriette 's paper was neatly expressed , and its sentiments were admirable . [She]142-henriette maintained a perfect balance between the bigotry of the past and the violence of the present . [Her]142-henriette phrases seemed to rock , like a pair of scales , from excess to excess , on either side . [She]142-henriette came to rest in the exact middle . This led to the Johnsonian structure , or , as [Hadria]211-hadria afterwards said , to the style of a Times leading article : ‚Äú[0-i] While [we]1282-we remember on the one hand , [we]1282-we must not forget on the other ‚Äî ‚Äù At the end of the lecture , [the audience]323-the audience found [themselves]323-the audience invited to sympathize cautiously and circumspectly with the advancement of [women]606-women , but led , at the same time , to conclude that good taste and good feeling forbade [any really nice woman]4538-any really nice woman from moving a little finger to attain , or to help [others]432-others to attain , the smallest fraction more of freedom , or an inch more of spiritual territory , than was now enjoyed by [her]142-henriette sex . When , at some future time , wider privileges should have been conquered by the exertions of [someone else]4540-someone else , then [the really nice woman]4541-the really nice woman could saunter in and enjoy the booty . But till then , let [her]142-henriette leave boisterous agitation to [others]432-others , and endear [herself]142-henriette to all around [her]142-henriette by [her]142-henriette patience and [her]142-henriette loving self - sacrifice . ‚Äú[0-i] That pays better for the present , ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria was heard to mutter to [an adjacent member]4543-an adjacent member . [The lecturer]339-the lecturer , in [her]339-the lecturer concluding remarks , gave a smile of ineffable sweetness , sadly marred , however , by the grotesque effect of the flickering shadows that were cast on [her]339-the lecturer face by the candle . After all , duty not right was the really important matter , and [the lecturer]339-the lecturer thought that it would be better if [one]329-one heard the former word rather oftener in connection with [the woman]4547-the woman 's question , and the latter word rather more seldom . Then , with new sweetness , and in a tone not to be described , [she]339-the lecturer went on to speak of the natural responsibilities and joys of [her]339-the lecturer sex , drawing a moving , if somewhat familiar picture of those avocations , than which [she]339-the lecturer was sure there could be nothing higher or holier . For some not easily explained cause , the construction of this sentence gave it a peculiar unctuous force : ‚Äú[0-i] than which , ‚Äù as [Fred]83-fred afterwards remarked , ‚Äú[0-i] would have bowled over [any but the most hardened sinner]1283-any but the most hardened sinner . ‚Äù For weeks after this memorable lecture , if [any very lofty altitude]4548-any very lofty altitude had to be ascended in conversational excursions , [the aspirant]4549-the aspirant invariably smiled with ineffable tenderness and lightly scaled the height , murmuring ‚Äú[0-i] than which ‚Äù to [a vanquished audience]4550-a vanquished audience . The lecture was followed by a discussion that rather took the stiffness out of [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley 's phrases . [The whole party]1013-the whole party was roused . [Algitha]81-algitha had to whisper a remonstrance to [the boys]3870-the boys , for [their]3870-the boys solemn questions were becoming too preposterous . The lecture was discussed with much warmth . There was a tendency to adopt the form ‚Äú[0-i] than which ‚Äù with some frequency . Bursts of laughter startled a company of rats in the wainscoting , and there was a lively scamper behind the walls . No obvious opposition was offered . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley 's views were examined with gravity , and indeed in a manner almost pompous . But by the end of that trying process , [they]3870-the boys had a sadly bedraggled and plucked appearance , much to [[their]3870-the boys parent]4553-their parent 's bewilderment . [She]81-algitha endeavoured to explain further , and was met by guilelessly intelligent questions , which had the effect of depriving the luckless objects of [their]3870-the boys solitary remaining feather . [The members of the society]358-the members of the society continued to pine for information , and [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley endeavoured to provide it , till late into the night . The discussion finally drifted on to dangerous ground . [Algitha]81-algitha declared that [she]81-algitha considered that [no man]4555-no man had any just right to ask [a woman]3753-a woman to pledge [herself]3753-a woman to love [him]4555-no man and live with [him]4555-no man for the rest of [her]3753-a woman life . How could [she]81-algitha ? [Hubert]118-hubert suggested that [the woman]4547-the woman made the same claim on [the man]3754-the man . ‚Äú[0-i] Which is equally absurd , ‚Äù said [Algitha]81-algitha . ‚Äú[0-i] Just as if [any two people]1284-any two people , when [they]1284-any two people are beginning to form [their]1284-any two people characters , could possibly be sure of [their]1284-any two people sentiments for the rest of [their]1284-any two people days . [They]1284-any two people have no business to marry at such an age . [They]1284-any two people are bound to alter . ‚Äù ‚Äú[1284-any two people] But [they]1284-any two people must regard it as [their]1284-any two people duty not to alter with regard to [one another]3945-one another , ‚Äù said [Henriette]142-henriette . ‚Äú[1284-any two people] Quite so ; just as [they]1284-any two people ought to regard it as [their]1284-any two people duty among other things , not to grow old , ‚Äù suggested [Fred]83-fred . ‚Äú[1284-any two people] Then , [Algitha]81-algitha , do [you]81-algitha mean that [they]1284-any two people may fall in love elsewhere ? ‚Äù [Ernest]86-ernest inquired . ‚Äú[81-algitha] [They]1284-any two people very likely will do so , if [they]1284-any two people make such an absurd start , ‚Äù [Algitha]81-algitha declared . ‚Äú[81-algitha] And if [they]1284-any two people do ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[81-algitha] Then , if the sentiment stands test and trial , and proves genuine , and not a silly freak , the fact ought to be frankly faced . [Husband]1286-husband and [wife]1287-wife have no business to go on keeping up a bond that has become false and irksome . ‚Äù [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley broke into protest . ‚Äú[81-algitha] But surely [you]81-algitha do n't mean to defend such faithlessness . ‚Äù [Algitha]81-algitha would not admit that it was faithlessness . [She]81-algitha said it was mere honesty . [She]81-algitha could see nothing inherently wrong in falling in love genuinely after [one]329-one arrived at years of discretion . [She]81-algitha thought it inherently idiotic , and worse , to make a choice that ought to be for life , at years of indiscretion . Still , [people]3687-people were idiotic , and that must be considered , as well as all the other facts , such as the difficulty of really knowing [each other]4561-each other before marriage , owing to social arrangements , and also owing to the training , which made [men]3698-men and [women]606-women always pose so ridiculously towards [one another]3945-one another , pretending to be something that [they]3945-one another were not . ‚Äú[81-algitha] Well done , [Algitha]81-algitha , ‚Äù cried [Ernest]86-ernest , laughing ; ‚Äú[81-algitha] [I]0-i like to hear [you]81-algitha speak out . Now tell [me]0-i frankly : supposing [you]81-algitha married quite young , before [you]81-algitha had had much experience ; supposing [you]81-algitha afterwards found that [you]81-algitha and [[your]81-algitha husband]1288-your husband had both been deceiving [yourselves]81-algitha and [each other]4561-each other , unconsciously perhaps ; and suppose , when more fully awakened and developed , [you]81-algitha met [another fellow]1290-another fellow and fell in love with [him]1290-another fellow genuinely , what would [you]81-algitha do ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[1291-she] Oh , [she]1291-she would just mention it to [[her]1291-she husband]553-her husband casually , ‚Äù [Fred]83-fred interposed with a chuckle , ‚Äú[1291-she] and disappear . ‚Äù ‚Äú[1291-she] [I]0-i should certainly not go through terrific emotions and self - accusations , and think the end of [the world]334-the world had come , ‚Äù said [Algitha]81-algitha serenely . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i should calmly face the situation . ‚Äù ‚Äú[1291-she] Calmly ! [She]1291-she by supposition being madly in love ! ‚Äù ejaculated [Fred]83-fred , with a chuckle . ‚Äú[1291-she] Calmly , ‚Äù repeated [Algitha]81-algitha . ‚Äú[1291-she] And [I]0-i should consider carefully what would be best for [all concerned]1294-all concerned . [She]142-henriette talked without interruption , [[her]142-henriette companion]3995-her companion listening , agreeing occasionally with [[her]142-henriette adversary]4576-her adversary , in a disconcerting manner ; then falling into silence . ‚Äú[0-i] It seems to [me]0-i that [you]0-i are making a very terrible mistake in [your]0-i life , [Hadria]211-hadria . [You]0-i may not admire [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon 's existence ; for [my]0-i part [I]0-i think [she]91-mrs. gordon leads a very good , useful life , but there is no reason why all married lives should be like [hers]91-mrs. gordon . ‚Äù ‚Äú[91-mrs. gordon] Why are [they]1306-they , then ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i do n't see that [they]1306-they are . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] It is the prevailing type . What [an oblique , shorn - looking object one]1307-an oblique , shorn - looking object one would be after a few years ! ‚Äù [Henriette]142-henriette grew eloquent . [Hadria]211-hadria covered [her]211-hadria face with [her]211-hadria hands . ‚Äú[0-i] [You]0-i who uphold all these social arrangements , how do [you]0-i feel when [you]0-i find [yourself]0-i obliged to urge [me]0-i to marry , not for the sake of the positive joys of domestic existence , but for the merely negative advantage of avoiding a hapless and forlorn state ? [You]0-i propose it as a pis - aller . Does that argue that all is sound in the state of [Denmark]20-denmark ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] If [you]0-i had not this unreasonable objection to what is really [a woman]3753-a woman 's natural destiny , the difficulty would not exist . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] Have [women]606-women no pride ? ‚Äù [Henriette]142-henriette did not answer . ‚Äú[0-i] Have [they]606-women no sense of dignity ? If [one]329-one marries ( accepting things on the usual basis , of course ) [one]329-one gives to [another person]1312-another person rights and powers over [one]329-one 's life that are practically boundless . To retain [one]329-one 's self - direction in case of dispute would be possible only on pain of social ruin . [I]0-i have little enough freedom now , heaven knows ; but if [I]0-i married , why [my]0-i very thoughts would become the property of [another]1315-another . Thought , emotion , love itself , must pass under the yoke ! There would be no nook or corner entirely and indisputably [my]0-i own . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i should not regard that as a hardship , ‚Äù said [Henriette]142-henriette , ‚Äú[0-i] if [I]0-i loved [[my]0-i husband]1295-my husband . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i should consider it not only a hardship , but beyond endurance . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] But , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear , [you]3722-my dear are impracticable . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] That is what [I]0-i think domestic life is ! ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria 's quiet tone was suddenly changed to one of scorn . ‚Äú[3722-my dear] [You]3722-my dear talk of love ; what has love worthy of the name to do with this preposterous interference with the freedom of [another person]1312-another person ? If that is what love means ‚Äî the craving to possess and restrain and demand and hamper and absorb , and generally make mince - meat of [the beloved object]1319-the beloved object , then preserve [me]0-i from the master - passion . ‚Äù [Henriette]142-henriette was baffled . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know how to make [you]3722-my dear see this in a truer light , ‚Äù [she]0-i said . ‚Äú[3722-my dear] There is something to [my]0-i mind so beautiful in the close union of [two human beings]1320-two human beings , who pledge [themselves]1320-two human beings to love and honour [one another]3945-one another , to face life hand in hand , to share every thought , every hope , to renounce each [his]1295-my husband own wishes for the sake of the other . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] That sounds very elevating ; in practice it breeds [Mr.]1322-mr. and [Mrs. Gordon]91-mrs. gordon . ‚Äù ‚Äú[91-mrs. gordon] Do [you]3722-my dear mean to tell [me]0-i [you]3722-my dear will never marry on this account ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] [I]0-i would never marry [anyone who would exact the usual submissions and renunciations , or even desire them]1323-anyone who would exact the usual submissions and renunciations , or even desire them , which [I]0-i suppose amounts almost to saying that [I]0-i shall never marry at all . What [man]332-man would endure [a wife who demanded to retain [her]1325-a wife who demanded to retain her absolute freedom , as in the case of a close friendship absolute freedom , as in the case of a close friendship]1325-a wife who demanded to retain her absolute freedom , as in the case of a close friendship ? [The man]3754-the man is not born ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] [You]3722-my dear seem to forget , [dear [Hadria]211-hadria]1327-dear hadria , in objecting to place [yourself]3722-my dear under the yoke , as [you]3722-my dear call it , that [[your]3722-my dear husband]1288-your husband would also be obliged to resign part of [his]1288-your husband independence to [you]3722-my dear . The prospect of loss of liberty in marriage often prevents [a man]3704-a man from marrying ( [‚Äú Wise man]4579-‚Äú wise man ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] ejaculated [Hadria]211-hadria ) , so [you]3722-my dear see the disadvantage is not all on one side , if so [you]3722-my dear choose to consider it . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] Good heavens ! do [you]3722-my dear think that the opportunity to interfere with [another person]1312-another person would console [me]0-i for being interfered with [myself]0-i ? [I]0-i do n't want [my]0-i share of the constraining power . [I]0-i would as soon accept the lash of [a slave - driver]1331-a slave - driver . This moral lash is almost more odious than the other , for its thongs are made of the affections and the domestic ‚Äò virtues , ‚Äô than which there can be nothing sneakier or more detestable ! ‚Äù [Henriette]142-henriette heaved a discouraged sigh . ‚Äú[3722-my dear] [You]3722-my dear are wrong , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äù [she]0-i said emphatically ; ‚Äú[3722-my dear] [you]3722-my dear are wrong , wrong , wrong . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] How ? why ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] One ca n't have everything in this life . [Henriette]142-henriette gave it up . [THE family]360-the family had reassembled for the New Year 's festivities . The change in [Algitha]81-algitha since [her]211-hadria departure from [home]3770-home was striking . [She]211-hadria was gentler , more affectionate to [[her]211-hadria parents]3931-her parents , than of yore . The tendency to grow hard and fretful had entirely disappeared . The sense of self was obviously lessened with the need for self - defence . [Hadria]211-hadria discovered that an attachment was springing up between [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister and [Wilfred Burton]107-wilfred burton , about whom [she]211-hadria wrote so frequently , and that this development of [her]211-hadria emotional nature , united with [her]211-hadria work , had given a glowing centre to [her]211-hadria life which showed itself in a thousand little changes of manner and thought . [Hadria]211-hadria told [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister that [she]0-i felt [herself]0-i unreal and fanciful in [her]0-i presence . ‚Äú[4254-my mother] [I]0-i go twirling things round and round in [my]0-i head till [I]0-i grow dizzy . [We]1349-we want [workers]1350-workers by [the thousand]1351-the thousand . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley had been asked to stay at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee for the New Year . [Algitha]81-algitha conceived for [her]141-miss temperley a sentiment almost vindictive . [Hadria]211-hadria and [the boys]3870-the boys enjoyed nothing better than to watch [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley giving forth [her]141-miss temperley opinions , while [Algitha]81-algitha 's figure gradually stiffened and [her]81-algitha neck drew out , as [Fred]83-fred said , in truly telescopic fashion , like that of [Alice in Wonderland]145-alice in wonderland . [The boys]3870-the boys constructed a figure of cushions , stuffed into one of [Algitha]81-algitha 's old gowns , the neck being a padded broom - handle , made to work up and down at pleasure ; and with this counterfeit presentment of [[their]3870-the boys sister]542-their sister , [they]3870-the boys used to act the scene amidst shouts of applause , [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley entering , on one occasion , when the improvised cocoa - nut head had reached its culminating point of high disdain , somewhere about the level of the curtain - poles . [Some mad spirit]4621-some mad spirit seemed to possess [her]211-hadria . It would appear almost as if [she]211-hadria had passed into a different phase of character . [She]211-hadria lost caution and care and the sense of external events . When the dance was ended , [Hubert]148-hubert led [her]211-hadria from [the hall]4592-the hall . [He]148-hubert was puzzled , but more hopeful than usual . [Hadria]211-hadria might almost have accepted [him]148-hubert in sheer absence of mind . [He]148-hubert put the thought in different terms . [He]148-hubert began to speak more boldly . [He]148-hubert gave [his]148-hubert view of life and happiness , [his]148-hubert philosophy and religion . [Hadria]211-hadria lazily agreed . [She]211-hadria lay under a singular spell . The bizarre old music smote still upon the ear . [She]211-hadria felt as if [she]211-hadria were in the thrall of some dream whose events followed one another , as the scenes of a moving panorama unfold themselves before [the spectators]3788-the spectators . [Temperley]141-miss temperley began to plead [his]148-hubert cause . [Hadria]211-hadria , with a startled look in [her]211-hadria eyes , tried to check [him]148-hubert . But [her]211-hadria will refused to issue a vigorous command . The sense of the importance of personal events had entirely disappeared . What did it all matter ? ‚Äú[0-i] Over [us]1385-us stars and under [us]1385-us graves . ‚Äù [The graves]4627-the graves would put it all right some day . As for attempting to direct [one]329-one 's fate , and struggle out of [the highways of [the world]334-the world]4629-the highways of the world ‚Äî midsummer madness ! It was not only [the Mrs. Gordons]92-the gordons , but the [Valeria Du Prel]109-valeria who told [one]329-one so . [Everybody]151-everybody said ( but in discreeter terms ) , ‚Äú[0-i] Disguise from [yourself]1386-you the solitude by setting up little screens of affections , and little pompous affairs about which [you]1386-you must go busily , and with all the solemnity that [you]1386-you can muster . ‚Äù [The savage]4632-the savage builds [[his]4632-the savage mud hut]4633-his mud hut to shelter [him]4632-the savage from the wind and the rain and the terror of the beyond . Outside is [the wilderness ready to engulf [him]4632-the savage]4634-the wilderness ready to engulf him . Rather than be left alone at the mercy of elemental things , with [no little hut]4635-no little hut , warm and dark and stuffy , to shelter [one]329-one , [a woman]3753-a woman will sacrifice everything ‚Äî liberty , ambition , health , power , [her]3753-a woman very dignity . There was a letter in [Hadria]211-hadria 's pocket at this moment , eloquently protesting in favour of [the mud hut]4638-the mud hut . [Hadria]211-hadria must have been appearing to listen favourably to [Temperley]141-miss temperley 's pleading , for [he]4632-the savage said eagerly , ‚Äú[0-i] Then [I]0-i have not spoken this time quite in vain . [I]0-i mean [we]1387-we make too much fuss about these trifles ; do n't [you]0-i think so ? ‚Äù [She]211-hadria spoke dreamily . [I]0-i can not help being intensely personal at this moment . [I]0-i ca n't help grasping at the hope of happiness . [Hadria]211-hadria , it lies in [your]211-hadria hand . Wo n't [you]211-hadria be generous ? ‚Äù [She]211-hadria gave a distressed gesture , and seemed to make some vain effort , as when [the victim of a nightmare]4639-the victim of a nightmare struggles to overcome the paralysis that holds [him]4639-the victim of a nightmare . ‚Äú[211-hadria] Then [I]0-i may hope a little , [Hadria]211-hadria ‚Äî [I]0-i must hope . ‚Äù Still the trance seemed to hold [her]211-hadria enthralled . The music was diabolically merry . [She]211-hadria could fancy evil spirits tripping to it in swarms around [her]211-hadria . [They]4640-they seemed to point at [her]211-hadria , and wave [their]4640-they arms around [her]211-hadria , and from [them]4640-they came an influence , magnetic in its quality , that forbade [her]211-hadria to resist . All had been pre - arranged . Nothing could avert it . [She]211-hadria seemed to be waiting rather than acting . Against [her]211-hadria inner judgment , [she]211-hadria had allowed those accursed practices to go on . Against [her]211-hadria instinct , [she]211-hadria had permitted [Henriette]142-henriette to become intimate at [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee ; indeed it would have been hard to avoid it , for [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley was not easy to discourage . Why had [she]211-hadria assured [Hadria]211-hadria so pointedly that [Hubert]148-hubert would not misinterpret [her]211-hadria consent to renew the practices ? Was it not a sort of treachery ? Had not [Henriette]142-henriette , with [her]142-henriette larger knowledge of [the world]334-the world , been perfectly well aware that whatever might be said , the renewal of the meetings would be regarded as encouragement ? Did [she]142-henriette not know that [Hadria]211-hadria [herself]211-hadria would feel implicated by the concession ? [Temperley]141-miss temperley 's long silence had been misleading . The danger had crept up insidiously . And had [she]211-hadria not been treacherous to [herself]211-hadria ? [She]211-hadria had longed for companionship , for music , for something to break the strain of [her]211-hadria wild , lonely life . Knowing , or rather half - divining the risk , [she]211-hadria had allowed [herself]211-hadria to accept the chance of relief when it came . Lack of experience had played a large part in the making of to - night 's dilemma . [Hadria]211-hadria 's own strange mood was another ally to [[her]211-hadria lover]4642-her lover , and for that , [old Mrs. McPherson]149-mrs. mcpherson and [her]149-mrs. mcpherson reels were chiefly responsible . Of such flimsy trifles is the human fate often woven . ‚Äú[0-i] Tell [me]0-i , did [you]0-i ask [[your]0-i sister]1388-your sister to ‚Äî ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] No , no , ‚Äù [Hubert]148-hubert interposed . ‚Äú[0-i] [[My]0-i sister]4161-my sister knows of [my]0-i hopes , and is anxious that [I]0-i should succeed . ‚Äù ‚Äú[4161-my sister] [I]0-i thought that [she]4161-my sister was helping [you]0-i . ‚Äù ‚Äú[4161-my sister] [She]4161-my sister would take any legitimate means to help [me]0-i , ‚Äù said [Hubert]148-hubert . ‚Äú[4161-my sister] [You]0-i can not resent that . The strength of [Temperley]141-miss temperley 's emotion had stirred [her]211-hadria . The magic of personal influence had begun to tell upon [her]211-hadria . It was so hard not to believe when [some one]3818-some one insisted with such certainty , with such obvious sincerity , that everything would be right . [He]4647-him seemed so confident that [she]211-hadria could make [him]4647-him happy , strange as it appeared . Perhaps after all ‚Äî ? And what a release from the present difficulties . But could one trust ? A confused mass of feeling struggled together . A temptation to give the answer that would cause pleasure was very strong , and beneath all lurked a trembling hope that perhaps this was the way of escape . In apparent contradiction to this , or to any other hope , lay a sense of fatality , a sad indifference , interrupted at moments by flashes of very desperate caring , when suddenly the love of life , the desire for happiness and experience , for the exercise of [her]211-hadria power , for its use in the service of [[her]211-hadria generation]4649-her generation , became intense , and then faded away again , as obstacles presented [their]4650-their formidable array before the mind . Why [she]154-mrs. temperley went to [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard could not be imagined : [one]329-one would think [she]154-mrs. temperley had [a family]4521-a family buried [there]571-there , [she]154-mrs. temperley who was , ‚Äú[1414-a stranger to the place] as one might say , [a stranger to [the place]981-the place]1414-a stranger to the place , ‚Äù and could not be supposed to have any interest in the graves , which held for [her]154-mrs. temperley nor [kith]4747-kith nor kin ! [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , however , appeared to be able to dispense with this element of attraction in [the ‚Äú[1414-a stranger to the place] grassy barrows]4748-the ‚Äú grassy barrows . ‚Äù [She]154-mrs. temperley and a company of [youthful Cochin - China fowls]4749-youthful cochin - china fowls remained for hours among [them]4749-youthful cochin - china fowls , on this cheerful morning , and [no observer]4750-no observer could have determined whether it was the graves or the fowls that riveted [her]154-mrs. temperley attention . [She]154-mrs. temperley had perched [herself]154-mrs. temperley on the stile that led from [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard to [the fields]4328-the fields : [a slender figure in serviceable russet and irresponsible - looking hat , autumn - tinted too]4753-a slender figure in serviceable russet and irresponsible - looking hat , autumn - tinted too , in sympathy with the splendid season . In [her]154-mrs. temperley ungloved left hand , which was at once sensitive and firm , [she]154-mrs. temperley carried a book , keeping a forefinger between the pages to mark a passage . [Her]154-mrs. temperley face bore signs of suffering , and at this moment , a look of baffled and restless longing , as if life had been for [her]154-mrs. temperley a festival whose sounds came from a hopeless distance . Yet there was something in the expression of the mouth , that suggested a consistent standing aloof from [herself]154-mrs. temperley and [her]154-mrs. temperley desires . The lines of the face could never have been drawn by mere diffusive , emotional habits . Thought had left as many traces as feeling in the firm drawing . The quality of the face was of that indefinable kind that gives to all characteristic things their peculiar power over the imagination . The more powerful the quality , the less can it be rendered into terms . It is the one marvellous , remaining , musical fact not to [he]4754-he defined that makes [the Parthenon]4755-the parthenon , or some other masterpiece of art , translate [us]4756-us to a new plane of existence , and inspire , for the time being , [the pessimist with hope]4757-the pessimist with hope and [the sceptic with religion]4758-the sceptic with religion . [The Cochin - Chinas]160-the cochin - chinas pecked about with [a contented mien among the long grass]4759-a contented mien among the long grass , finding odds and ends of nourishment , and here and there eking out [their]4760-their livelihood with a dart at a passing fly . [Their]4760-their long , comic , tufted legs , which seemed to form a sort of monumental pedestal whereon the bird itself was elevated , stalked and scratched about with an air of industrious serenity . There were few mornings in the year which left unstirred the grass which grew long over [the graves]4627-the graves , but this was one of the few . Each blade stood up still and straight , bearing its string of dewdrops . There were one or two village sounds that came subdued through the sunshine . The winds that usually haunted [the high spot]4762-the high spot had fallen asleep , or were lying somewhere in ambush among [the woodlands beyond]4763-the woodlands beyond . The look of strain had faded from the face of [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , leaving only an expression of sadness . The removal of all necessity for concealing thought allowed [her]154-mrs. temperley story to write itself on [her]154-mrs. temperley face . [The speculative]4764-the speculative would have felt some curiosity as to the cause of a sadness in one seemingly so well treated by destiny . Neither poverty nor the cares of great wealth could have weighed upon [her]154-mrs. temperley spirit ; [she]154-mrs. temperley had beauty , and a quality more attractive than beauty , which must have placed many things at [her]154-mrs. temperley command ; [she]154-mrs. temperley had evident talent ‚Äî [her]154-mrs. temperley very attitude proclaimed it ‚Äî and the power over Fortune that talent ought to give . Possibly , [the observer]4765-the observer might reflect , the gift was of that kind which lays [the possessor]4766-the possessor peculiarly open to [her]154-mrs. temperley outrageous slings and arrows . Had [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley shown any morbid signs of self - indulgent emotionalism the problem would have been simple enough but this was not the case . The solitude was presently broken by the approach of [an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel . [He]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel remarked upon the fineness of the day , and took up [his]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel position at a short distance from [the stile]4768-the stile , where the turf had been cleared away in a long - shaped patch . Here , with great deliberation [he]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel began [his]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel task . The sound of [his]4767-an old man laden with pickaxe and shovel steady strokes fell on the stillness . Presently , the clock from [the grey tower]4769-the grey tower gave forth [its]4770-its announcement ‚Äî eleven . One by one , the slow hammer sent the waves of air rolling away , almost visibly , through the sunshine , their sound alternating with the thud of the pickaxe , so as to produce an effect of intentional rhythm . [One]329-one might have fancied that clock and pickaxe iterated in turn , ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] Time , Death ! Time , Death ! Time , Death ! ‚Äù till the clock had come to the end of its tale , and then the pickaxe went on alone in the stillness‚Äî‚ÄúDeath[1417-lord] ! Death ! Death ! Death ! ‚Äù A smile , not easy to be accounted for , flitted across the face of [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . [The library at [the Red House]4718-the red house]4801-the library at the red house was [the only room that had been radically altered since the days of [the former tenants , whose taste had leant towards the florid rather than the classic]4804-the former tenants , whose taste had leant towards the florid rather than the classic]4803-the only room that had been radically altered since the days of the former tenants , whose taste had leant towards the florid rather than the classic . [The library]4805-the library alone had been subjected to peine forte et dure . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley said that [it]4805-the library had been purified by suffering . [Hubert]118-hubert was among [the many who shrink and harden into mental furrows]4845-the many who shrink and harden into mental furrows as time passes . What [he]118-hubert had thought at twenty , at thirty - five had acquired sanctity and certainty , from having been the opinion of [Hubert Temperley]118-hubert for all those favoured years . [He]118-hubert had no suspicion that the views which [he]118-hubert cherished in so dainty and scholarly a fashion were simply an edition de luxe of the views of [everybody else]4846-everybody else . [He]118-hubert smiled at the views of [everybody else]4846-everybody else : [his]118-hubert own were put forth as something choice and superior . [He]118-hubert had the happy knack of being bourgeois with the air of [an artist]4849-an artist . For some occult reason , the imagination of all was at work especially and exclusively on the figure of [that polished gentleman in war - paint and feathers]4862-that polished gentleman in war - paint and feathers , sporting round the cauldron that contained the boiled earthly remains of [[his]118-hubert relations]4863-his relations . [Mr. Fleming]159-joseph fleming betrayed the common thought by remarking that it would be very becoming to [him]159-joseph fleming . ‚Äú[0-i] Ah ! [I]0-i wish [we]1583-we were [all savages in feathers and war - paint]1587-all savages in feathers and war - paint , dancing on the edge of [some wild forest]1588-some wild forest , with nothing but [the sea]1589-the sea and the sky for limits ! ‚Äù [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria surprised [[her]109-valeria audience]320-her audience by this earnest aspiration . ‚Äú[1590-you] Do [you]1590-you feel inclined to revert ? ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria enquired . ‚Äú[1590-you] Because if so , [I]0-i shall be glad to join [you]1590-you . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i think there is a slight touch of the savage about [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , ‚Äù observed [Fleming]159-joseph fleming pensively . ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] [I]0-i mean , do n't [you]1590-you know ‚Äî of course‚Äî. ‚Äù ‚Äú[1590-you] [You]1590-you are quite right ! ‚Äù cried [Valeria]109-valeria . ‚Äú[1590-you] [I]0-i have often noticed a sort of wildness that crops up now and then through a very smooth surface . [Hadria]211-hadria may sigh for [the woodlands]1591-the woodlands , yet ‚Äî ! ‚Äù THE first break in the unity of [the Fullerton family]4073-the fullerton family had occurred on the occasion of [Hadria]211-hadria 's marriage . The short period that elapsed between that memorable New - Year's - Eve and the wedding had been a painful experience for [Dunaghee]1-dunaghee . [Hadria]211-hadria 's conduct had shaken [[her]211-hadria brothers]4866-her brothers ' faith in [her]211-hadria and in [all womankind]4867-all womankind . [Ernest]86-ernest especially had suffered disillusion . [He]86-ernest had supposed [her]211-hadria above the ordinary , pettier weaknesses of [humanity]4357-humanity . [[Other fellows]4869-other fellows ' sisters]4870-other fellows ' sisters had seemed to [him]86-ernest miserable travesties of [their]4870-other fellows ' sisters sex compared with [her]211-hadria . ( There was one exception only , to this rule . ) But now , what was [he]86-ernest to think ? [She]211-hadria had shattered [his]86-ernest faith . If [she]211-hadria had n't been ‚Äú[1592-herself] so cocksure of [herself]1592-herself , ‚Äù [he]86-ernest would n't have minded so much ; but after all [she]211-hadria had professed , to go and marry , and marry [a starched specimen like that]4871-a starched specimen like that ! [Fred]83-fred was equally emphatic . For a long time [he]86-ernest had regarded it all as a joke . [He]86-ernest shook [his]86-ernest head knowingly , and said that sort of thing would n't go down . When [he]86-ernest was at length convinced , [he]86-ernest danced with rage . [He]86-ernest became cynical . [He]86-ernest had no patience with [girls]3769-girls . [They]3769-girls talked for talking 's sake . It meant nothing . [Algitha]81-algitha understood , better than [[her]81-algitha brothers]4866-her brothers could understand , how [Hadria]211-hadria 's emotional nature had been caught in some strange mood , how the eloquent assurances of [[her]211-hadria lover]4642-her lover might have half convinced [her]211-hadria . [Algitha]81-algitha 's own experience of proposals set [her]81-algitha on the track of the mystery . ‚Äú[1592-herself] It is most misleading , ‚Äù [she]81-algitha pointed out , to [[her]81-algitha scoffing brothers]4875-her scoffing brothers . ‚Äú[329-one] [One]329-one would suppose that marrying was the simplest thing in [the world]334-the world ‚Äî nothing perilous , nothing to object to about it . [A man]3704-a man proposes to [you]1596-you as if [he]3704-a man were asking [you]1596-you for the sixth waltz , only [his]3704-a man manner is perfervid . And [my]0-i belief is that half [the girls who accept]1597-the girls who accept do n't realize that [they]1597-the girls who accept are agreeing to anything much more serious . ‚Äù ‚Äú[1598-the more fools] [The more fools]1598-the more fools [they]1597-the girls who accept ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[3704-a man] True ; but it really is most bewildering . Claims , obligations , all the ugly sides of the affair are hidden away ; [the man]3754-the man is at [his]3754-the man best , full of refinement and courtesy and unselfishness . And if [he]3754-the man persuades [the girl]3739-the girl that [he]3754-the man really does care for [her]3739-the girl , how can [she]3739-the girl suppose that [she]3739-the girl can not trust [her]3739-the girl future to [him]3754-the man ‚Äî if [he]3754-the man loves [her]3739-the girl ? And yet [she]3739-the girl ca n't ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[3739-the girl] How can [a man]3704-a man suppose that [one girl]1602-one girl is going to be different from [every other girl]1603-every other girl ? ‚Äù asked [Fred]83-fred . ‚Äú[3754-the man] Different , [you]1604-you mean , from what [he]3754-the man supposes [every other girl]1603-every other girl to be , ‚Äù [Algitha]81-algitha corrected . ‚Äú[3754-the man] It 's [his]3754-the man own look - out if [he]3754-the man 's such [a fool]1606-a fool . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i believe [Hadria]211-hadria married because [she]211-hadria was sick of being [the family consolation]3836-the family consolation , ‚Äù said [Ernest]86-ernest . ‚Äú[211-hadria] Well , of course , the hope of escape was very tempting . [[You]1608-you boys]3840-you boys do n't know what [she]211-hadria went through . [We]3840-you boys all regret [her]211-hadria marriage to [Hubert Temperley]118-hubert ‚Äî though between [ourselves]3840-you boys , not more than [he]118-hubert regrets it , if [I]0-i am not much mistaken ‚Äî but it is very certain that [she]211-hadria could not have gone on living at [home]3770-home much longer , as things were . ‚Äù [Fred]83-fred said that [she]211-hadria ought to have broken out after [Algitha]81-algitha 's fashion , if it was so bad as all that . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i think [mother]3851-mother would have died if [she]211-hadria had , ‚Äù said [the sister]4876-the sister . ‚Äú[0-i] [Hadria]211-hadria was awkwardly placed , ‚Äù [Fred]83-fred admitted . ‚Äú[211-hadria] Do [you]1612-you remember that evening in [the garret]293-the garret when [we]3840-you boys all told [her]211-hadria what [we]3840-you boys thought ? ‚Äù asked [Ernest]86-ernest .
