[She]142-henriette is as knowing ‚Äî ‚Äù ‚Äú[142-henriette] [I]0-i wish [we]3840-you boys had strangled [her]142-henriette . ‚Äù ‚Äú[142-henriette] [I]0-i shall never forget , ‚Äù [Algitha]81-algitha went on , ‚Äú[142-henriette] that night when [Hadria]211-hadria was taken with a fit of terror ‚Äî it was nothing less ‚Äî and wrote to break off the engagement , and [that woman]1618-that woman undertook to deliver the letter and lost it , on purpose [I]0-i am always convinced , and then the favourable moment was over . ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] What made [her]211-hadria so anxious for the marriage beats [me]0-i , ‚Äù cried [Ernest]86-ernest . ‚Äú[211-hadria] It was not a particularly good match from a mercenary point of view . ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] [She]211-hadria thought [us]3840-you boys [an interesting family to marry into]1619-an interesting family to marry into , ‚Äù suggested [Fred]83-fred , ‚Äú[211-hadria] which is undeniable . ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] Then [she]211-hadria must be greatly disappointed at seeing so little of [us]3840-you boys ! ‚Äù cried [Ernest]86-ernest . In the early days , [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley had stayed frequently at [the Red House]4718-the red house , and [Hadria]211-hadria had been cut off from [[her]211-hadria own family]4879-her own family , who detested [Henriette]142-henriette . For a year or more , there had been a fair promise of a successful adjustment of the two incongruous natures in the new conditions . [They]3840-you boys both tried to keep off dangerous ground and to avoid collisions of will . [They]3840-you boys made the most of [their]3840-you boys one common interest , although even here [they]3840-you boys soon found [themselves]3840-you boys out of sympathy . [Hubert]118-hubert 's instincts were scholastic and lawful , [Hadria]211-hadria was disposed to daring [innovation]171-innovation . [Her]211-hadria bizarre compositions shocked [him]118-hubert painfully . [The two]4880-the two jarred on one another , in great things and in small . The halcyon period was short - lived . The dream , such as it was , came to an end . [Hubert]118-hubert turned to [[his]118-hubert sister]351-his sister , in [his]118-hubert bewilderment and disappointment . [They]3840-you boys had both counted so securely on the effect of experience and the pressure of events to teach [Hadria]211-hadria the desirable lesson , and [they]3840-you boys were dismayed to find that , unlike [other women]4882-other women , [she]211-hadria had failed to learn it . [Henriette]142-henriette was in despair . It was [she]142-henriette who had brought about the ill - starred union . How could [she]142-henriette ever forgive [herself]142-henriette ? How repair the error [she]142-henriette had made ? Only by devoting [herself]142-henriette to [[her]142-henriette brother]309-her brother , and trying patiently to bring [[his]309-her brother wife]573-his wife to a wiser frame of mind . A considerable time had elapsed , during which [Hadria]211-hadria saw [[her]211-hadria brothers]4866-her brothers and [sister]1054-sister only at long intervals . [Ernest]86-ernest had become estranged from [her]211-hadria , to [her]211-hadria great grief . [He]86-ernest was as courteous and tender in [his]86-ernest manner to [her]211-hadria as of yore , but there was a change , not to be mistaken . [She]211-hadria had lost [the brother of [her]211-hadria girlhood]4887-the brother of her girlhood for ever . While it bitterly grieved , it did not surprise [her]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria acknowledged in dismay the inconsistency of [her]211-hadria conduct . [She]211-hadria must have been mad ! The universal similarity in the behaviour of [girls]3769-girls , [herself]211-hadria included , alarmed [her]211-hadria . Was there some external will that drove [them]3769-girls all , in hordes , to [their]3769-girls fate ? Were all the intricacies of event and circumstance , of [their]3769-girls very emotion , merely the workings of that ruthless cosmic will by which [the individual]4889-the individual was hypnotised and ruled ? As usual at critical moments , [Hadria]211-hadria had been solitary in [her]211-hadria encounter with the elements of [Fate]102-fate . There were conflicts that even [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister knew nothing about , the bewilderments and temptations of a nature hampered in its action by its own voluminous qualities and its caprice . [[Her]211-hadria brothers]4866-her brothers supposed that in a short time [Hadria]211-hadria would be ‚Äú[211-hadria] wearing bonnets and a card - case , and going the rounds with an elegant expression like the rest of [them]1620-them . ‚Äù How different were the little local facts of life ‚Äî the little chopped - up life that accumulates in odds and ends from moment to moment ‚Äî from the sun - and - smoke vision of early irresponsible days ! [Mrs. Fullerton]97-mrs. fullerton was pleased with the marriage , not merely because [[Hubert]118-hubert 's father]4892-hubert 's father , [Judge Temperley]131-temperley , could secure for [[his]4892-hubert 's father son]4893-his son a prosperous career , but because [she]97-mrs. fullerton was so thankful to see [a strange , unaccountable girl like [Hadria]211-hadria]4894-a strange , unaccountable girl like hadria settling quietly down , with [a couple of [children]626-children]4895-a couple of children to keep [her]211-hadria out of mischief . That was what it had come to ! Perhaps [they]4866-her brothers calculated a little too surely . Possibly [even two children]4897-even two children might not keep [her]211-hadria entirely out of mischief . Out of what impulse of malice had [Fate]102-fate pitched upon [the most essentially mutinous and erratic of the whole brood]4898-the most essentially mutinous and erratic of the whole brood , for the sedatest r√¥le ? But perhaps [Fate]102-fate , too , had calculated unscientifically . Mischief was always possible , if [one]329-one gave [one]329-one 's mind to it . Or was [she]211-hadria growing too old to have the spirit for thorough - going devilry ? [Youth]172-youth seemed rather an affair of mental outlook than of years . [She]211-hadria felt twenty years older since [her]211-hadria marriage . [She]211-hadria wondered why it was that marriage did not make [all women wicked,‚Äîopenly and actively so]4901-all women wicked,‚Äîopenly and actively so . If ever there was an arrangement by which every evil instinct and every spark of [the devil]1352-the devil was likely to be aroused and infuriated , surely the customs and traditions that clustered round [this estate]4903-this estate constituted that dangerous combination ! Hardship , difficulty , tragedy could be faced , but not the humiliating , the degrading , the contemptible . [Hadria]211-hadria had [her]211-hadria own particular ideas as to what ought to be set down under these headings . [Most women]4904-most women , [she]211-hadria found , ranked certain elements very differently , with lavish use of halos and gilding in [their]4904-most women honour , feeling perhaps , [she]211-hadria hinted , the dire need of such external decoration . Good heavens ! Did [no other woman]4905-no other woman realize the insult of it all ? [Hadria]211-hadria knew [so few women]4906-so few women intimately ; none intimately enough to be convinced that no such revolt lay smouldering beneath [their]4906-so few women smiles . [She]211-hadria had a lonely assurance that [she]211-hadria had never met [the sister - soul]4907-the sister - soul ( for such there must be by the score , as silent as [she]211-hadria ) , who shared [her]211-hadria rage and [her]211-hadria detestations . [Valeria]109-valeria , with all [her]109-valeria native pride , regarded these as proof of a big flaw in an otherwise sound nature . Yet how deep , how passionately strong , these feelings were , how gigantic the flaw ! What possessed [people]3687-people that [they]3687-people did not see what was so brutally clear ? As [young girls]863-young girls led forth unconscious into the battle , with a bandage over [their]863-young girls eyes , and cotton - wool in [their]863-young girls ears ‚Äî yes , then it was inevitable that [the !]4910-the ! should see and hear nothing . Had [they]863-young girls been newly imported from [the moon]4911-the moon [they]863-young girls could scarcely have less acquaintance with terrestrial conditions ; but afterwards , when ruthlessly , with the grinning assistance of [the onlookers]461-the onlookers , the facts of the social scheme were cynically revealed , and [the r√¥le]4913-the r√¥le imperiously allotted ‚Äî with much admonition and moving appeals to conscience and religion , and all [the other aides - de - camp at command]4914-the other aides - de - camp at command ‚Äî after all that , how in the name of [heaven]4276-heaven could [they]863-young girls continue to ‚Äú[211-hadria] babble of [green fields]1621-green fields ‚Äù ? Was it conceivable that among [the thousands of women to whom year after year the facts were disclosed , not one understood and not one]4916-the thousands of women to whom year after year the facts were disclosed , not one understood and not one ‚Äî hated ? A flame sprang up in [Hadria]211-hadria 's eyes . There must be [other women]4882-other women somewhere at this very moment , whose whole being was burning up with this bitter , this sickening and futile hatred ! But how few , how few ! How vast was [the meek majority]4918-the meek majority , fattening on indignity , proud of [their]4918-the meek majority humiliation ! Yet how wise [they]4918-the meek majority were after all . It hurt so to hate ‚Äî to hate like this . Submission was an affair of temperament , a gift of birth . Nature endowed with a serviceable meekness those whom [she]211-hadria designed for insult . Yet it might not be meekness so much as mere brutal necessity that held [them]863-young girls all in thrall ‚Äî the inexorable logic of conditions . [Fate]102-fate knew better than to assail [the victim]870-the victim point blank , and so put [her]870-the victim on [her]870-the victim guard . No ; [she]211-hadria lured [her]870-the victim on gently , cunningly , closing behind [her]870-the victim , one by one , the doors of escape , persuading [her]870-the victim , forcing [her]870-the victim to fasten on [her]870-the victim own tethers , appealing to a thousand qualities , good and bad ; now to a moment 's weakness or pity , now to [her]870-the victim eternal fear of grieving [others]432-others ( that was a well - worked vein ! ) , now to [her]870-the victim instinct of self - sacrifice , now to grim necessity itself , profiting too by the increasing discouragements , the vain efforts , the physical pain and horrible weariness , the crowding of little difficulties , harassments , the troubles of [others]432-others ‚Äî ah ! how infinite were these ! so that there was no interval for breathing , and scarcely time or space to cope with the legions of the moment ; the horizon was black with [their]4918-the meek majority advancing hosts ! And this assuredly was no unique experience . [Hadria]211-hadria remembered how [she]211-hadria had once said that if the worst came to the worst , it would be easy to run away . To [her]211-hadria inexperience desperate remedies had seemed so simple , so feasible ‚Äî the factors of life so few and unentwined . [She]211-hadria had not understood how prolific are [our]4922-us deeds , how an act brings with it a large and unexpected progeny , which surround [us]4922-us with new influences and force upon [us]4922-us unforeseen conditions . Yet frequent had been the impulse to adopt that girlish solution of the difficulty . [She]211-hadria had no picturesque grievances of the kind that would excite sympathy . On the contrary , popular feeling would set dead against [her]211-hadria ; [she]211-hadria would be acting on an idea that [nobody]3732-nobody shared , not even [[her]211-hadria most intimate friend]4924-her most intimate friend . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria had arrived at the conclusion that [she]109-valeria did not understand [Hadria]211-hadria . [She]109-valeria had attributed many of [her]211-hadria peculiarities to [her]211-hadria unique education and [her]211-hadria inexperience . [Hadria]211-hadria had indeed changed greatly since [her]211-hadria marriage , but not in the manner that might have been expected . On the contrary , a closer intimacy with popular social ideals had fired [her]211-hadria with a more angry spirit of rebellion . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria had met examples of every kind of eccentricity , but [she]109-valeria had never before come upon so marked an instance of this particular type . [Hadria]211-hadria 's attitude towards life had suggested to [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria the idea of [[her]109-valeria heroine]4005-her heroine , [Caterina]173-caterina . [She]211-hadria remonstrated with [Hadria]211-hadria , assuring [her]211-hadria that no insult towards [women]606-women was intended in the general scheme of society , and that it was a mistake to regard it in so resentful a spirit . ‚Äú[211-hadria] But that is just the most insulting thing about it , ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria exclaimed . ‚Äú[211-hadria] Insult is so much a matter of course that [people]3687-people are surprised if one takes umbrage at it . Read this passage from [Aristotle]174-aristotle that [I]0-i came upon the other day . [He]174-aristotle is perfectly calm and amiable , entirely unconscious of offence , when [he]174-aristotle says that ‚Äò [a wife]1373-a wife ought to shew [herself]1373-a wife even more obedient to the rein than if [she]1373-a wife entered [the house]296-the house as [a purchased slave]1625-a purchased slave . For [she]1373-a wife has been bought at a high price , for the sake of sharing life and bearing [children]626-children , than which no higher or holier tie can possibly exist . ‚Äô ( [Henriette]142-henriette to the very life ! ) ‚Äù [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria laughed , and re - read the passage from the Politics , in some surprise . ‚Äú[1627-you] Do [you]1627-you suppose insult is deliberately intended in that graceful sentiment ? ‚Äù asked [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú[1627-you] Obviously not . If [any woman of that time]1628-any woman of that time had blazed up in anger at the well - meant speech , [she]1628-any woman of that time would have astonished and grieved [[her]1628-any woman of that time contemporaries]1629-her contemporaries . [Aristotle]174-aristotle doubtless professed a high respect for women who followed [his]174-aristotle precepts ‚Äî as [men]3698-men do now when [we]1631-our are obedient . ‚Äù ‚Äú[174-aristotle] Of course , [our]1631-our society in this particular has not wandered far from the Greek idea , ‚Äù [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria observed pensively . [Hadria]211-hadria pronounced the paradox , ‚Äú[174-aristotle] The sharpness of the insult lies in its not being intended . ‚Äù [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria could not prevail upon [her]211-hadria to modify the assertion . [Hadria]211-hadria pointed out that [the Greeks]175-the greeks also meant no offence in regarding [[their]175-the greeks respectable women]4927-their respectable women as [simple reproductive agents of inferior human quality]4928-simple reproductive agents of inferior human quality . ‚Äú[174-aristotle] And though [our]1631-our [well - brought - up girls]1632-well - brought - up girls shrink from the frank speech , [they]1632-well - brought - up girls do not appear to shrink from the ideas of [the old Greeks]1633-the old greeks . [They]1632-well - brought - up girls do n't mind playing the part of cows so long as [one]329-one does n't mention it . ‚Äù About eighteen months ago , [the village]1124-the village had been full of talk and excitement in consequence of the birth of [an heir to [the house of [Engleton]27-engleton]4931-the house of engleton]4930-an heir to the house of engleton , [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton 's mission in life being frankly regarded as unfulfilled during the previous three or four years , when [she]176-lady engleton had disappointed the hopes of [the family]360-the family . [Hadria]211-hadria listened scornfully . In [her]211-hadria eyes , the crowning indignity of the whole affair was [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton 's own smiling acceptance of the position , and [her]176-lady engleton complacent eagerness to produce [the tardy inheritor of the property]4933-the tardy inheritor of the property and honours . This expression of sentiment had , by some means , reached [the Vicarage]4698-the vicarage and created much consternation . [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker asserted that it was right and Christian of [the lady]3679-the lady to desire that which gave [every one]913-every one so much pleasure . ‚Äú[329-one] A climax of feminine abjectness ! ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria had exclaimed in [Henriette]142-henriette 's presence . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley , after endeavouring to goad [[her]141-miss temperley sister - in - law]4937-her sister - in - law into the expression of jubilant congratulations , was met by the passionate declaration that [she]141-miss temperley felt more disposed to weep than to rejoice , and more disposed to curse than to weep . Obviously , [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley had reason to be uneasy about [her]141-miss temperley part in bringing about [[her]141-miss temperley brother]309-her brother 's marriage . These sudden overflows of exasperated feeling had become less frequent as time went on , but [the neighbours]1469-the neighbours looked askance at [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . Though a powder - magazine may not always blow up , one passes it with a grave consciousness of vast stores of inflammable material lying somewhere within , and who knows what spark might set the thing spouting to the skies ? When [the occasional visitors]4940-the occasional visitors had left , life in [the village]1124-the village settled down to its normal level , or more accurately , to [its]1124-the village normal flatness as regarded general contours , and its petty inequalities in respect to local detail . It reminded [Hadria]211-hadria of the landscape which stretched in quiet long lines to the low horizon , while close at hand , [the ground]4942-the ground fussed and fretted itself into minor ups and downs of no character , but with all the trouble of [a mountain district in [its]1124-the village complexities of slope and hollow]4943-a mountain district in its complexities of slope and hollow . [Hadria]211-hadria suffered from a gnawing home - sickness ; a longing for the rougher , bleaker scenery of [the North]28-the north . The tired spirit translated [the homely English country]4944-the homely english country , so deeply reposeful in [its]4944-the homely english country spirit , into an image of dull unrest . If only those broken , stupid lines could have been smoothed out into the grandeur of [a plain]4945-a plain , [Hadria]211-hadria thought that it would have comforted [her]211-hadria , as if a song had moved across it with the long - stretching winds . As it was , to look from [her]211-hadria window only meant to find repeated the trivialities of life , more picturesque indeed , but still trivialities . It was the estimable and domestic qualities of Nature that presented themselves : Nature in [her]211-hadria most maternal and uninspired mood ‚Äî Mother earth submissive to the dictatorship of [man]332-man , permitting [herself]211-hadria to be torn , and wounded , and furrowed , and harrowed at [his]332-man pleasure , yielding [her]211-hadria substance and [her]211-hadria life to sustain the produce of [his]332-man choosing , [her]211-hadria body and [her]211-hadria soul abandoned supine to [his]332-man caprice . The sight had an exasperating effect upon [Hadria]211-hadria . Its symbolism haunted [her]211-hadria . The calm , sweet English landscape affected [her]211-hadria at times with a sort of disgust . It was , perhaps , the same in kind as the far stronger sensation of disgust that [she]211-hadria felt when [she]211-hadria first saw [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton with [[her]176-lady engleton new - born child]4947-her new - born child , full of pride and exultation . It was as much as [she]211-hadria could do to shake hands with [the happy mother]4948-the happy mother . When [Valeria]109-valeria expressed dismay at so strange a feeling [Hadria]211-hadria had refused to be treated as [a solitary sinner]4949-a solitary sinner . There were [plenty of fellow - culprits]4950-plenty of fellow - culprits , [she]109-valeria said , only [they]4950-plenty of fellow - culprits did not dare to speak out . [Valeria]109-valeria would not hear of it . [Marion Jordan]177-marion jordan ! the gentlest , timidest , most typical of [young English girls]4954-young english girls ! The sunlight fell through the leaves on the singing tea - kettle and the cups and saucers , and made bright patches on the figures and the faces assembled round the tea - table . [Hubert Temperley]118-hubert had again brought [[his]118-hubert friend]4122-his friend [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming , in the forlorn hope , [he]118-hubert said , of being able to give [him]159-joseph fleming something to eat and drink . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had called by chance this afternoon , and [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker , [[the vicar]4965-the vicar 's wife]4966-the vicar 's wife , with two of [[her]162-mrs. walker countless daughters]4967-her countless daughters , had come by invitation . [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker was [a middle - aged , careworn , rather prim - looking woman]4968-a middle - aged , careworn , rather prim - looking woman . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton was handsome . Bright auburn hair waved back in picturesque fashion from a piquant face , and constituted more than half [her]176-lady engleton claim to beauty . The brown eyes were bright and vivacious . The mouth was seldom quite shut . It scarcely seemed worth while , [the loquacious lady]4969-the loquacious lady had confessed . [She]176-lady engleton showed a delicate taste in dress . Shades of brown and russet made a fine harmony with [her]176-lady engleton auburn hair , and the ivory white and fresh red of [her]176-lady engleton skin . [She]176-lady engleton and [Temperley]154-mrs. temperley always enjoyed a sprightly interchange of epigrams . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had the qualities that [Hubert]118-hubert had admired in [Hadria]211-hadria before [their]4970-their marriage , and [she]176-lady engleton was entirely free from the other characteristics that had exasperated [him]118-hubert so desperately since that hideous mistake that [he]118-hubert had made . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had originality and brilliancy , but [she]176-lady engleton knew how to combine these qualities with perfect obedience to the necessary conventions of life . [She]176-lady engleton had the sparkle of champagne , without the troublesome tendency of that delicate beverage to break bounds , and brim over in iridescent , swelling , joyous foam , the discreet edges of such goblets as custom might decree for the sunny vintage . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton sparkled , glowed , nipped even at times , was of excellent dry quality , but [she]176-lady engleton never frothed over . [She]176-lady engleton always knew where to stop ; [she]176-lady engleton had the genius of moderation . [She]176-lady engleton stood to [Hadria]211-hadria as a correct rendering of a cherished idea stands to a faulty one . [She]176-lady engleton made [Hubert]118-hubert acutely feel [his]118-hubert misfortune , and shewed [him]118-hubert [his]118-hubert lost hope , [his]118-hubert shattered ideal . ‚Äú[0-i] Is the picture finished ? ‚Äù [he]118-hubert enquired , as [he]118-hubert handed [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton [her]176-lady engleton tea . ‚Äú[0-i] What , the view from [[your]1645-you field]1646-your field ? [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton gave a little scream . ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , come to the rescue . [[Your]154-mrs. temperley brother]1710-your brother is calling [us]1711-us names . [He]1710-your brother says [we]1711-us grovel consistently and always . ‚Äù [Ernest]86-ernest laughed , and protested . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton pretended to be mortally offended . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley was sorry [she]154-mrs. temperley could give no redress . [She]154-mrs. temperley had suffered from [Ernest]86-ernest 's painful frankness from [her]154-mrs. temperley youth upwards . The conversation grew discursive . Throughout history , [she]142-henriette reflected , [children]626-children had been the unfailing means of bringing [women]606-women into line with tradition . Who could stand against [them]626-children ? [They]626-children had been able to force the most rebellious to [their]626-children knees . An appeal to the maternal instinct had quenched the hardiest spirit of revolt . No wonder the instinct had been so trumpeted and exalted ! [Women]606-women might harbour dreams and plan insurrections ; but [[their]606-women children]654-their children ‚Äî [little ambassadors of the established and expected]1750-little ambassadors of the established and expected ‚Äî were argument enough to convince [the most hardened sceptics]1751-the most hardened sceptics . It was a terrible cultus , a savage idol that had devoured [them]1786-they both , as cruel and insatiable as [the brazen god of old]1788-the brazen god of old , with [his]1788-the brazen god of old internal fires , which [the faithful fed devoutly]1789-the faithful fed devoutly , with [shrinking girls]1790-shrinking girls and [screaming children]1791-screaming children . ‚Äú [I]109-valeria still fail to understand why [you]211-hadria adopt [this child]5063-this child , ‚Äù[109-valeria] said [Valeria]109-valeria . ‚Äú [[My]109-valeria Caterina]5087-my caterina would never have done it . ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú [The little creature]5088-the little creature interests [me]211-hadria , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú It is a tiny field for the exercise of the creative forces . [Every one]913-every one has some form of active amusement . Some like golf , others flirtation . [I]211-hadria prefer this sort of diversion . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú But [you]211-hadria have [[your]211-hadria own children]5090-your own children to interest [you]211-hadria , surely far more than this one . ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria 's face grew set and defiant . ‚Äú [They]5090-your own children represent to [me]211-hadria the insult of society ‚Äî [my]211-hadria own private and particular insult , the tribute exacted of [my]211-hadria womanhood . It is through [them]5090-your own children that [I]211-hadria am to be subdued and humbled . Just once in a way , however , the thing does not quite ‚Äò come off . ‚Äô ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú What has set [you]211-hadria on edge so , [I]109-valeria wonder . ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú [People]3687-people , traditions , unimpeachable sentiments . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú [Yours]211-hadria are not unimpeachable at any rate ! ‚Äù[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria cried laughing . ‚Äú [Caterina]173-caterina is [an angel]5092-an angel compared with [you]211-hadria , and yet [[my]109-valeria publisher]5093-my publisher has [his]5093-my publisher doubts about [her]173-caterina . ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú [Caterina]173-caterina would do as [I]211-hadria do , [I]211-hadria know , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú [Those who are looked at askance by]5094-those who are looked at askance by [the world]334-the world appeal to [my]211-hadria instincts . [I]211-hadria shall be able to teach [this child]5063-this child , perhaps , to strike a blow at the system which sent [[her]5063-this child mother]520-her mother to [a dishonoured grave]5098-a dishonoured grave , while it leaves [the man]3754-the man for whose sake [she]5063-this child risked all this , in peace and the odour of sanctity . ‚Äù[211-hadria] Time seemed to be marked , in [the sleepy village]1792-the sleepy village , by [the baby]1487-the baby 's growth . [Valeria]109-valeria , who thought [she]109-valeria was fond of [babies]1794-babies , used to accompany [Hadria]211-hadria on [her]109-valeria visits to [the cottage]1763-the cottage , but [she]109-valeria treated [the infant]1796-the infant so much as if it had been a guinea - pig or a rabbit that [the nurse]1797-the nurse was indignant . The weeks passed in rapid monotony , filled with detail and leaving no mark behind [them]1798-them , no sign of movement or progress . The cares of [the house]296-the house , [the children]667-the children , left only limited time for walking , reading , correspondence , and such music as could be wrung out of a crowded day . An effort on [Hadria]211-hadria 's part , to make serious use of [her]211-hadria musical talent had been frustrated . But a pathetic , unquenchable hope always survived that presently , when this or that corner had been turned , this or that difficulty overcome , conditions would be conquered and opportunity arrive . Not yet had [she]211-hadria resigned [her]211-hadria belief that the most harassing and wearying and unceasing business that [a human being]668-a human being can undertake , is compatible with the stupendous labour and the unbounded claims of [an artist]4849-an artist 's career . The details of practical life and petty duties sprouted up at every step . If [they]1798-them were put aside , even for a moment , the wheels of daily existence became clogged and then all opportunity was over . [Hope]187-hope had begun to alternate with a fear lest that evasive corner should never be turned , that little crop of interruptions never cease to turn up . And yet it was so foolish . Each obstacle in itself was paltry . It was [their]667-the children number that overcame [one]329-one , as the tiny arrows of [the Lilliputs]188-the lilliputs overcame [Gulliver]189-gulliver . [One of [[Hadria]211-hadria 's best friends in [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene]1805-hadria 's best friends in craddock dene]1804-one of hadria 's best friends in craddock dene was [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming , who had become very intimate at [the Red House]4718-the red house during the last year or two . [Hadria]211-hadria used to tire of the necessity to be apparently rational ( such was [her]211-hadria own version ) , and found it a relief to talk nonsense , just as [she]211-hadria pleased , to [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming , who never objected or took offence , if [he]159-joseph fleming occasionally looked surprised . [Other men]1807-other men might have thought [she]211-hadria was laughing at [them]667-the children , but [Joseph]159-joseph fleming made no such mistake when [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley broke out , as [she]154-mrs. temperley did now and then , in fantastic fashion . [She]154-mrs. temperley was standing , one morning , on [the little bridge over [the stream]1809-the stream that ran at a distance of a few hundred yards from [the Red House]4718-the red house]1808-the little bridge over the stream that ran at a distance of a few hundred yards from the red house . [The two boys]1811-the two boys were bespattering [themselves]1811-the two boys in [the meadow below]1812-the meadow below , by [the water]1813-the water 's verge . [He]159-joseph fleming addressed [himself]159-joseph fleming to [her]154-mrs. temperley maternal feelings by remarking what handsome and clever boys [they]1811-the two boys were . ‚Äú Handsome and clever ? ‚Äù[154-mrs. temperley] [she]154-mrs. temperley repeated . ‚Äú Is that all [you]159-joseph fleming can say , [Mr. Fleming]159-joseph fleming ? ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú [A mother]4953-a mother has to find in [[her]4953-a mother children]576-her children all that [she]4953-a mother can hope to find in life , and [she]4953-a mother naturally desires to make the most of [them]576-her children , do n't [you]159-joseph fleming see ? ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] ‚Äú Ah ! yes , quite so , ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] said [Joseph]159-joseph fleming dubiously . ‚Äú [Nobody]3732-nobody , [I]159-joseph fleming suppose , likes to be commonplace all round ; [one]329-one must have some poetry somewhere ‚Äî so [most women]4904-most women idealize [[their]4904-most women children]654-their children , and if [other people]3849-other people wo n't help [them]654-their children in the effort , do n't [you]159-joseph fleming see ? it is most discouraging . ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] ‚Äú Are [you]159-joseph fleming chaffing , or what ? ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] [Joseph]159-joseph fleming enquired . ‚Äú No , indeed ; [I]159-joseph fleming am perilously serious . ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] ‚Äú [I]159-joseph fleming can well understand how [a mother]4953-a mother must get absorbed in [[her]4953-a mother children]576-her children , ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] said [Joseph]159-joseph fleming . ‚Äú [I]159-joseph fleming suppose it 's a sort of natural provision . ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] ‚Äú Think of [Mrs. Allan]190-mrs. allan with [her]190-mrs. allan outrageous eight ‚Äî all making mud - pies ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria ; ‚Äú a magnificent ‚Äò natural provision ! ‚Äô A small income , [a small house]5110-a small house , with those pervasive eight . [He]159-joseph fleming had decided that [she]154-mrs. temperley was a little eccentric , and that explained everything ; just as [he]159-joseph fleming explained instances of extraordinary reasoning power in a dog by calling it ‚Äú instinct . ‚Äù[159-joseph fleming] Whatever [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley might do was slightly eccentric , and had [she]154-mrs. temperley suddenly taken it into [her]154-mrs. temperley head to dance a fandango on [the public road]1817-the public road , it would have merely put a little extra strain on that word . [Not the most respected of [the ladies who turned up [their]1822-the ladies who turned up their disapproving noses disapproving noses]1822-the ladies who turned up their disapproving noses]1821-not the most respected of the ladies who turned up their disapproving noses , was more dull or more depressing than [Hadria]211-hadria could be , on occasion , as [she]211-hadria had [herself]211-hadria pointed out ; and would not this soften stony hearts ? When [she]211-hadria discovered that [[her]211-hadria kindly neighbour]1823-her kindly neighbour had been fighting [her]211-hadria battles for [her]211-hadria , [she]211-hadria was touched ; but [she]211-hadria asked [him]1823-her kindly neighbour not to expend [his]1823-her kindly neighbour strength on [her]211-hadria behalf . [Hadria]211-hadria thus found [herself]211-hadria in an awkwardly uncertain position ; either [she]211-hadria was looked at askance , as eccentric , or [she]211-hadria found [herself]211-hadria called upon to make good expectations of saintliness , such as never were on [land]1828-land or [sea]1829-sea . [Saintly]192-saintly ? [Hadria]211-hadria shook [her]211-hadria head . [She]211-hadria could imagine [no one]383-no one further from such a condition than [she]211-hadria was at present , and [she]211-hadria felt it in [her]211-hadria , to swing down and down to the very opposite pole from [that serene altitude]1831-that serene altitude . [She]211-hadria admitted that , from a utilitarian point of view , [she]211-hadria was making a vast mistake . As things were , [Mrs. Walker]162-mrs. walker and [Mrs. Allan]190-mrs. allan , laboriously spinning [[their]1832-their ponderous families]1833-their ponderous families on [their]1832-their own axes , in a reverent spirit , had chosen the better part . But [Hadria]211-hadria did not care . [She]211-hadria would not settle down to make the best of things , as even [Algitha]81-algitha now recommended , ‚Äú since there [she]211-hadria was , and there was no helping it . ‚Äù[81-algitha] ‚Äú [I]211-hadria will never make the best of things , ‚Äù[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria said . ‚Äú [I]211-hadria know nothing that gives such opportunities to [the Devil]1352-the devil . ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria had characteristically left the paradox unjustified . ‚Äú What do [you]211-hadria mean ? ‚Äù[81-algitha] asked [Algitha]81-algitha . ‚Äú Surely [the enemy of good]5116-the enemy of good has most hold over the discontented spirit . ‚Äù[81-algitha] [Hadria]211-hadria likened the contented to [stagnant pools]1834-stagnant pools , wherein corruptions grow apace . ‚Äú It is only [the discontented ocean that remains , for all its storms]5117-the discontented ocean that remains , for all its storms , fresh and sane to the end . ‚Äù[211-hadria] But though [she]211-hadria said this , for opposition 's sake perhaps , [she]211-hadria had [her]211-hadria doubts about [her]211-hadria own theory . Better a cheerful sin or two than allow that to take hold ! ‚Äú But then there is this sickly feminine conscience to deal with ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria exclaimed . ‚Äú It clings to the worst of [us]5118-us still , and prevents the wholesome big catastrophes that might bring salvation . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ANOTHER year had blundered itself away , leaving little trace behind it , in [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris resented it as a sign of indifference . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was like [the Chinese wives , who complain bitterly of [a husband]512-a husband 's neglect when [he]512-a husband omits to beat [them]1875-the chinese wives , who complain bitterly of a husband 's neglect when he omits to beat them]1875-the chinese wives , who complain bitterly of a husband 's neglect when he omits to beat them . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris taunted [the Professor]4071-the professor for failing to assert [his]4071-the professor ‚Äú rights . ‚Äù[1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris] ‚Äú Morally , [I]4071-the professor have no rights , except such as [you]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris choose to give [me]4071-the professor of [your]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris own free will , ‚Äù[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor replied . ‚Äú [I]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris am not [[your]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris gaoler]5127-your gaoler . ‚Äù[1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris] ‚Äú And even that did not penetrate to [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris better nature till it was too late , ‚Äù[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria continued . ‚Äú But after the mischief was done , that phrase seems to have stung [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris to torment . [Her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris training had blinded [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris , as [one]329-one is blinded in coming out of darkness into a bright light . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris was used to narrower hearts and smaller brains . [Her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris last letter ‚Äî a terrible record of the miseries of remorse ‚Äî [shews]5129-shews that [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris recognized at last what sort of [a man [he]4071-the professor was whose heart [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris had broken]5130-a man he was whose heart she had broken . [She]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris could not face the horrors of self - accusation ; [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris preferred to kill [herself]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris . ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú What a shocking story ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú And all the more so because [the Professor]4071-the professor clings to [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris memory so faithfully . [He]4071-the professor blames [himself]4071-the professor for everything . [He]4071-the professor ought , [he]4071-the professor says , to have realized better the influence of [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris training ; [he]4071-the professor ought to have made [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris understand that [he]4071-the professor could not assert what [she]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris called [his]4071-the professor ‚Äò rights ‚Äô without insulting [her]1858-the professor 's wife , whom madame bertaux had happened to meet in paris and [himself]4071-the professor . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú Whenever [one]329-one hears anything new about [the Professor]4071-the professor , it is always something that makes [one]329-one admire and love [him]1878-him more than ever ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria . [Her]211-hadria first meeting with [him]1878-him was in [the old [Yew Avenue]36-yew avenue in [the Priory garden]1677-the priory garden]1879-the old yew avenue in the priory garden . [He]1878-him was on [his]1878-him way to call at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [She]211-hadria stood on a patch of grass by a rustic seat commanding the vista of yews , and above [them]1882-them , a wilderness of lilacs and laburnums , in full flower . [It]1883-it looked to [her]211-hadria like [a pathway that led to [some exquisite fairy palace of]1885-some exquisite fairy palace of [one]329-one 's childhood]1884-a pathway that led to some exquisite fairy palace of one 's childhood . Almost with the first word that [the Professor]4071-the professor uttered , [Hadria]211-hadria felt a sense of relief and hope . The very air seemed to grow lighter , the scent of the swaying flowers sweeter . [She]211-hadria always afterwards associated this moment of meeting with the image of that avenue of mourning yews , crowned with the sunlit magnificence of an upper world of blossom . What had [she]211-hadria been thinking of to run so close to despair during these years ? A word , a smile , and the dead weight swerved , swung into balance , and life lifted up its head once more . [She]211-hadria remembered now , not [her]211-hadria limitations , but the good things of [her]211-hadria lot ; the cruelties that Fate had spared [her]211-hadria , the miseries that [the ruthless goddess]1888-the ruthless goddess had apportioned to [others]432-others . But [the Professor]4071-the professor 's presence did not banish , but rather emphasized , the craving to take part in the enriching of that general life which was so poor and sad . [He]4071-the professor strengthened [her]211-hadria disposition to revolt against the further impoverishment of it , through the starving of [her]211-hadria own nature . [He]4071-the professor would not blame [her]211-hadria simply on account of difference from [others]432-others . [She]211-hadria felt sure of that . [He]4071-the professor would not be shocked if [she]211-hadria had not answered to the stimulus of surroundings as faithfully as [most women]4904-most women seemed to answer to [them]4904-most women . [Circumstance]106-circumstance had done its usual utmost to excite [her]211-hadria instinct to beat down the claims of [[her]211-hadria other self]1893-her other self , but for once , circumstance had failed . It was a solitary failure among a creditable multitude of victories . But if instinct had not responded to the imperious summons , [the other self]1894-the other self had been suffering the terrors of a siege , and [the garrison]1895-the garrison had grown starved and weakly . What would be the end of it ? And [the little cynical imp that peeped among [her]211-hadria thoughts]1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts , as [a monkey among forest boughs]1897-a monkey among forest boughs , gibbered [his]1896-the little cynical imp that peeped among her thoughts customary ‚Äú What matters it ? [He]4071-the professor would not be hard upon [any human being]1899-any human being . [He]4071-the professor knew that existence was not such an easy affair to manage . [She]211-hadria wished that [she]211-hadria could tell [him]4071-the professor everything in [her]211-hadria life ‚Äî its struggle , its desperate longing and ambition , its hatred , its love : only [he]4071-the professor would understand all the contradictions and all the pain . [She]211-hadria would not mind [his]4071-the professor blame , because [he]4071-the professor would understand , and the blame would be just . [They]1900-they walked together down [the avenue]945-the avenue towards [the beautiful old Tudor house]1902-the beautiful old tudor house , which stood on the further side of [a broad lawn]1903-a broad lawn . [The Professor]4071-the professor looked worn and thin . [He]4071-the professor owned to being very tired of the hurry and struggle of [town]4255-town . [He]4071-the professor was sick of the conflict of jealousies and ambitions . It seemed so little worth while , this din of voices that would so soon be silenced . ‚Äú [I]211-hadria starve for the sight of a true and simple face , for the grasp of a brotherly hand . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú [You]4071-the professor ? ‚Äù[211-hadria] exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú There are so few , so very few , where the throng is thick and the battle fierce . It saddens [me]211-hadria to see [good fellows]5136-good fellows trampling [one another]3945-one another down , growing hard and ungenerous . [One]329-one grows very sick and sorry at times amidst the cruelty and the baseness that threaten to destroy [one]329-one 's courage and [one]329-one 's hope . [I]211-hadria know that human nature has in it a germ of nobility that will save it , in the long run , but meanwhile things seem sadly out of joint . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú Is that the order of the universe ? ‚Äù[211-hadria] asked [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú No , [I]4071-the professor think it is rather the disorder of [man]332-man 's nature , ‚Äù[4071-the professor] [he]4071-the professor replied . [He]3704-a man lived before [his]3704-a man time . [[His]3704-a man wife]573-his wife had taunted [him]3704-a man because [he]3704-a man would not treat [her]573-his wife as [his]3704-a man legal property , or rule [her]573-his wife through the claims and opportunities that popular sentiment assigned to [him]3704-a man . Then , not only imagination , but [cold reason]196-cold reason [herself]211-hadria grew eloquent with promises . ‚Äú It was in [there]571-there , in [the old drawing - room]4723-the old drawing - room , where [we]5163-we had sat together evening after evening , that [they]5164-they found [her]211-hadria dead , [the very type of all that is brilliant and exquisite and living]5165-the very type of all that is brilliant and exquisite and living . To [me]211-hadria [she]211-hadria was everything . All [my]211-hadria personal happiness was centred in [her]211-hadria . [I]211-hadria cared for nothing so long as [she]211-hadria was in the same world as [myself]211-hadria , and [I]211-hadria might love [her]211-hadria . [I]211-hadria had troubled [myself]211-hadria but little about the question of the survival of the personality after death ; [I]211-hadria had been pre - occupied with life . Now [I]211-hadria realized out of what human longings and what human desperation [our]5163-we religions are built . For one gleam of hope that [we]5163-we should meet again ‚Äî what would [I]211-hadria not have given ? But it never came . The trend of [my]211-hadria thought made all such hopes impossible . [I]211-hadria have grown charier of the word ‚Äò impossible ‚Äô now . [We]5163-we know so infinitesimally little . [I]211-hadria had to learn to live on comfortless . All that was strongly personal in [me]211-hadria died . All care about [myself]211-hadria went out suddenly , as in other cases [I]211-hadria think it goes out slowly , beaten down by the continued buffetings of life . [I]211-hadria gave [myself]211-hadria to [my]211-hadria work , and then a curious decentralizing process took place . [I]211-hadria ceased to be the point round which [the world]334-the world revolved , in [my]211-hadria own consciousness . [I]211-hadria mean that this was a continuous , not an occasional state of consciousness . After that came an unexpected peace . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú [You]1920-you have travelled a long and hard road to find it ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú Not a unique fate , ‚Äù[1920-you] [he]1920-you said with a smile . ‚Äú It must be a terrible process that quite kills the personal in one , it is so strong . [[Her]573-his wife father]609-her father and [grandfather]1925-grandfather had both been [men of violent and tyrannical temper]1926-men of violent and tyrannical temper , and tradition gave the same character to [[their]1926-men of violent and tyrannical temper forefathers]1927-their forefathers . [[Eleanor]197-helen 's mother]1928-eleanor 's mother was [one of [the meek and saintly women who almost invariably fall to the lot of [overbearing men]1931-overbearing men]1930-the meek and saintly women who almost invariably fall to the lot of overbearing men]1929-one of the meek and saintly women who almost invariably fall to the lot of overbearing men . [The Erinnys]198-the erinnys were still unsatisfied . [[My]211-hadria poor wife]5170-my poor wife became the victim of [their]198-the erinnys fury . And every new light that science throws upon human life shews that this must be so . [The old Greeks]1633-the old greeks saw that unconscious evil - doing is punished as well as that which is conscious . [These poor unselfish women]5172-these poor unselfish women , piling up [their]5172-these poor unselfish women own supposed merit , at the expense of the character of [[their]5172-these poor unselfish women tyrants]5173-their tyrants , laid up a store of misery for [[their]5172-these poor unselfish women descendant]5174-their descendant , [[my]211-hadria unhappy wife]5175-my unhappy wife . Imagine the sort of training and tradition that [she]5175-my unhappy wife had to contend with ; [[her]5175-my unhappy wife mother]520-her mother ignorant and supine , [[her]5175-my unhappy wife father]609-her father violent , bigoted , almost brutal . [Eleanor]197-helen 's nature was obscured and distorted by it . Having inherited the finer and stronger qualities of [[her]5175-my unhappy wife father]609-her father 's race , with much of its violence , [she]5175-my unhappy wife was going through a struggle at the time of [our]5179-our marriage : training , native vigour and [nobility]5180-nobility all embroiled in a desperate civil war . It was too much . There is no doubt as to the ultimate issue , but the struggle killed [her]5175-my unhappy wife . It is a common story : a character militant which meets destruction in the struggle for life . The past evil pursues and throttles the present good . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú This takes away the last consolation from [women who have been forced to submit to evil conditions]5181-women who have been forced to submit to evil conditions , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú It is the truth , ‚Äù[4071-the professor] said [the Professor]4071-the professor . ‚Äú [The Erinnys]198-the erinnys are [no mere fancy of the Greek mind]5182-no mere fancy of the greek mind . It takes more energy to get the dinner delayed for a quarter of an hour in [most well - regulated houses]5190-most well - regulated houses , or some slight change in routine , than to alter a frontier , or pass an Act of Parliament . ‚Äù[109-valeria] [Hadria]211-hadria laughed . ‚Äú Until [you]109-valeria discovered this by personal inconvenience , [you]109-valeria always scolded [me]211-hadria for [my]211-hadria disposition to jeer at the domestic scheme . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú It is a little geometrical , ‚Äù[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria admitted . ‚Äú Geometrical ! [The eye]5192-the eye sees to the end of every path , and knows that it leads to nothing . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú Ah ! dear [Hadria]211-hadria , but [all the pathways of [the world]334-the world]5193-all the pathways of the world have that very same goal . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú At least some of them have the good taste to wind a little , and thus disguise the fact . And think of the wild flowers [one]5195-one may gather by the wayside in [some forest track]5196-some forest track , or among [the mountain passes]5197-the mountain passes ; but in these prim alleys what natural thing can one know ? [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton 's artistic instinct seemed to occupy itself less with the interpretation of Nature than with the appreciation of the handiwork of [man]332-man . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald shared [her]176-lady engleton indifference for the poetic expression , but not for the reality expressed . ‚Äú [I]176-lady engleton quarrel with [you]181-professor theobald about art , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú Art is art , and nature is nature , both charming in [their]5274-their way , though [I]176-lady engleton prefer art . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] ‚Äú [Our]5275-our old quarrel ! ‚Äù[4071-the professor] said [the Professor]4071-the professor . ‚Äú Because a wild glade is beautiful in its quality of wild glade , [you]5276-you ca n't see the beauty in a trim bit of garden , with its delightful suggestion of human thought and care . ‚Äù[4071-the professor] ‚Äú [I]181-professor theobald object to stiffness , ‚Äù[181-professor theobald] said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . [His]181-professor theobald proposals to improve [the stately old gardens at [the Priory]1664-the priory]1967-the stately old gardens at the priory by adding what [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton called ‚Äú fatuous wriggles to all the walks , for mere wrigglings ' sake , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] had led to hot discussions on the principles of art and the relation of symmetry to the sensibilities of [mankind]1102-mankind . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton thought [the Professor]4071-the professor crude in taste , and shallow in knowledge , on this point . ‚Äú And yet [you]5276-you appreciate so keenly [my]176-lady engleton old enamels , and [your]5276-you eye seeks out , in a minute , a picturesque roof or gable . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] ‚Äú Perhaps [Theobald]181-professor theobald leans to the picturesque and does not care for the classic , ‚Äù[1971-his colleague] suggested [[his]4071-the professor colleague]1971-his colleague ; ‚Äú a fundamental distinction in mental bias . ‚Äù[1971-his colleague] ‚Äú Then why does [he]181-professor theobald enjoy so much of the Renaissance work on caskets and goblets ? [He]181-professor theobald was raving about them last night in the choicest English . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton crossed over to speak to [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald approached [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley and [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming . [Hadria]211-hadria knew by some instinct that [the Professor]4071-the professor had been waiting for an opportunity to speak to [her]211-hadria . As [he]4071-the professor drew near , a feeling of intense enmity arose within [her]211-hadria , which reached its highest pitch when [he]4071-the professor addressed [her]211-hadria in a fine , low - toned voice of peculiarly fascinating quality . Every instinct rose up as if in warning . [He]4071-the professor sat down beside [her]211-hadria , and began to talk about [the Priory]1664-the priory and [its]1664-the priory history . [His]4071-the professor ability was obvious , even in [his]4071-the professor choice of words and [his]4071-the professor selection of incidents . [He]4071-the professor had the power of making dry arch√¶ological facts almost dramatic . [His]4071-the professor speech differed from that of [most men]1974-most men , in the indefinable manner wherein excellence differs from mediocrity . Yet [Hadria]211-hadria was glad to notice some equally indefinable lack , corresponding perhaps to the gap in [his]4071-the professor consciousness that [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had come upon in [their]1975-their discussions on the general principles of art . What was it ? A certain stilted , unreal quality ? Scarcely . Words refused to fit themselves to the evasive form . Something that suggested the term ‚Äú second class , ‚Äù[1976-a master of the ambiguous] though whether it were the manner or the substance that was responsible for the impression , was difficult to say . Sometimes [his]4071-the professor words allowed two possible interpretations to be put upon a sentence . [He]4071-the professor was [a master of the ambiguous]1976-a master of the ambiguous . Obviously it was not lack of skill that produced the double - faced phrases . [He]4071-the professor did not leave [[his]4071-the professor listeners]1015-his listeners long in doubt as to [his]4071-the professor personal history . [He]4071-the professor enjoyed talking about [himself]4071-the professor . [He]4071-the professor was [a Professor of arch√¶ology]1978-a professor of arch√¶ology , and had written various learned books on the subject . But [his]4071-the professor studies had by no means been confined to the one theme . History had also interested [him]4071-the professor profoundly . [He]4071-the professor had published a work on [the old houses of [England]14-england]1979-the old houses of england . [The Priory]1664-the priory figured among [them]1979-the old houses of england . It was not difficult to discover from the conversation of [this singular man]1981-this singular man , whose subtle and secretive instincts were contradicted , at times , by a strange inconsequent frankness , that [his]4071-the professor genuine feeling for the picturesque was accompanied by an equally strong predilection for the appurtenances of wealth and splendour ; [his]4071-the professor love of great names and [estates]1982-estates being almost of the calibre of [the housemaid]1983-the housemaid 's passion for lofty personages in [her]1983-the housemaid penny periodical . [He]4071-the professor seemed to be [a man of keen and cunning ability]1984-a man of keen and cunning ability , who studied and played upon the passions and weaknesses of [[his]4071-the professor fellows]951-his fellows , possibly for [their]951-his fellows good , but always as [a magician]518-a magician might deal with the beings subject to [his]4071-the professor power . By what strange lapse did [he]4071-the professor thus na√Øvely lay [himself]4071-the professor open to [their]951-his fellows smiles ? [Hadria]211-hadria was amused at [his]4071-the professor occasional impulse of egotistic frankness ( or what appeared to be such ) , when [he]4071-the professor would solemnly analyse [his]4071-the professor own character , admitting [his]4071-the professor instinct to deceive with an engaging and scholarly candour . [His]4071-the professor penetrating eyes kept a watch upon [[his]4071-the professor audience]1987-his audience . [His]4071-the professor very simplicity seemed to be guarded by [his]4071-the professor keenness . [Hadria]211-hadria chafed under [his]4071-the professor persistent effort to attract and interest [her]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria gave a little inward shiver on finding that there was a vague , unaccountable , and unpleasant fascination in the personality of [the man]3754-the man . It was not charm , it was nothing that inspired admiration ; it rather inspired curiosity and stirred the spirit of research , a spirit which evidently animated [himself]4071-the professor . [She]211-hadria felt that , in order to investigate the workings of [her]211-hadria mind and [her]211-hadria heart , [the Professor]4071-the professor would have coolly pursued the most ruthless psychical experiments , no matter at what cost of anguish to [herself]211-hadria . In the interests of science and humanity , [the learned Professor]1990-the learned professor would certainly not hesitate to make [one wretched individual]1991-one wretched individual agonize . [His]4071-the professor appeal to the intellect was stimulatingly strong ; it was like a stinging wind , that made one walk at a reckless pace , and brought the blood tingling through every vein . That intellectual force could alone explain the fact of [his]4071-the professor being counted by [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue as [a friend]727-a friend . Even then it was a puzzling friendship . Could it be that to [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , [he]116-professor fortescue shewed only [his]116-professor fortescue best side ? [His]116-professor fortescue manner was more respectful towards [[his]116-professor fortescue colleague]1971-his colleague than towards [other men]1807-other men , but even with [him]116-professor fortescue [he]116-professor fortescue was irreverent in [his]116-professor fortescue heart , as towards [mankind]1102-mankind in general . To [Hadria]211-hadria [he]116-professor fortescue spoke of [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue with enthusiasm ‚Äî praising [his]116-professor fortescue great power , [his]116-professor fortescue generosity , [his]116-professor fortescue genial qualities , and [his]116-professor fortescue uprightness ; then [he]116-professor fortescue laughed at [him]116-professor fortescue as [a modern Don Quixote]1996-a modern don quixote , and sneered at [his]116-professor fortescue efforts to save animal suffering when [he]116-professor fortescue might have made a name that would never be forgotten , if [he]116-professor fortescue pursued a more fruitful branch of research . [Hadria]211-hadria remarked that [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald 's last sentence had added the crowning dignity to [his]116-professor fortescue eulogium . [He]116-professor fortescue glanced at [her]211-hadria , as if taking [her]211-hadria measure . ‚Äú [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , ‚Äù[116-professor fortescue] [he]116-professor fortescue called out , ‚Äú [I]116-professor fortescue envy [you]116-professor fortescue [[your]116-professor fortescue champion]5277-your champion . Every abuse may find shelter behind it . The slave trade , for instance ; have [we]5282-our not white slavery in [our]5282-our midst ? How inconsistent to trouble about [negroes]5283-negroes till [[our]5282-our own people]5284-our own people are truly free ! Wife - beating ? [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue stared in surprise . ‚Äú But do [you]116-professor fortescue really mean to tell [me]116-professor fortescue that [you]116-professor fortescue think it logical to excuse one abuse by pointing to another ? ‚Äù[116-professor fortescue] ‚Äú [I]181-professor theobald think that while there are [ill - used women]5296-ill - used women and [children]626-children , it is certainly inconsistent to consider animals , ‚Äù[181-professor theobald] said [Theobald]181-professor theobald . ‚Äú It does not occur to [you]116-professor fortescue that the spirit in [man that permits abuse of power over animals]5298-man that permits abuse of power over animals is precisely the same devil - inspired spirit that expresses itself in cruelty towards [children]626-children . [We]2007-they may perhaps have [you]2004-him for [a neighbour]2008-a neighbour after all . ‚Äù [HADRIA]211-hadria tried to avoid [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , but [he]181-professor theobald was not easily avoided . [She]211-hadria frequently met [him]181-professor theobald in [[her]211-hadria walks]5306-her walks . The return of spring had tempted [her]211-hadria to resume [her]211-hadria old habit of rising with the sun . But [she]211-hadria found , what [she]211-hadria had feared , that [her]211-hadria strength had departed , and [she]211-hadria as fatigued instead of invigorated , as of yore . [She]211-hadria did not regard this loss in a resigned spirit . Resignation was certainly not [her]211-hadria strong point . [[The vicar]4965-the vicar 's wife]4966-the vicar 's wife and [[the doctor]1471-the doctor 's wife]5310-the doctor 's wife and [the rest of [the neighbours]1469-the neighbours]5311-the rest of the neighbours compared [their]5311-the rest of the neighbours woes and weariness over five o'clock tea , and these appeared so many and so severe that [Hadria]211-hadria felt half ashamed to count [hers]211-hadria at all . Yet why lower the altars of [the sane goddess]5313-the sane goddess because [her]5313-the sane goddess shrine was deserted ? Health was health , though [all the women of [England]14-england]5314-all the women of england were [confirmed invalids]5315-confirmed invalids . And with nothing less ought [reasonable creatures]5316-reasonable creatures to be satisfied . As for taking enfeeblement as a natural dispensation , [she]211-hadria would as soon regard delirium tremens in that light . [She]211-hadria chafed fiercely against the loss of that blessed sense of well - being and overflowing health , that [she]211-hadria used to have , in the old days . [She]211-hadria resented the nerve - weariness , the fatigue that [she]211-hadria was now more conscious of than ever , with the coming of the spring . The impulse of creative energy broke forth in [her]211-hadria . The pearly mornings and the birds ' songs stirred every instinct of expression . The outburst did not receive its usual check . The influences of disenchantment were counteracted by [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's presence . [His]116-professor fortescue sympathy was marvellous in its penetration , brimming the cold hollows of [her]211-hadria spirit , as [a flooded river]5317-a flooded river fills the tiniest chinks and corners about [its]5317-a flooded river arid banks . [He]116-professor fortescue called forth all [her]211-hadria natural buoyancy and [her]211-hadria exulting sense of life , which was precisely the element which charged [her]211-hadria sadness with such a fierce electric quality , when [she]211-hadria became possessed by it , as a cloud by storm . [Valeria]109-valeria too was roused by the season . ‚Äú[2008-a neighbour] What a parable it all is , as old as [the earth]2009-the earth , and as fresh , each new year , as if [a messenger - angel]2010-a messenger - angel had come straight from [heaven]4276-heaven , in [[his]2010-a messenger - angel home - spun of young green]2012-his home - spun of young green , to tell [us]2013-they that all is well . ‚Äù If [Hadria]211-hadria met [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald in [her]211-hadria rambles , [she]211-hadria always cut short [her]211-hadria intended walk . [She]211-hadria and [Valeria]109-valeria with [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue wandered together , far and wide . [They]2013-they watched the daily budding greenery , the gleams of daffodils among [their]2013-they sword - blades of leaves , the pushing of sheaths and heads through the teeming soil , the bursts of sunshine and the absurd childish little gushes of rain , skimming [the green country]5318-the green country like a frown . ‚Äú[2010-a messenger - angel] Truly a time for joy and idleness . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2010-a messenger - angel] If only , ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria , when [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald thus grew enthusiastic on the subject , ‚Äú[2010-a messenger - angel] if only [[my]0-i cook]2014-my cook had not given a month 's notice . ‚Äù [She]211-hadria would not second [his]181-professor theobald mood , be it what it might . Each day , as [they]2013-they passed along [the lanes]5319-the lanes , the pale green had spread , like fire , on the hedges , caught the chestnuts , with their fat buds shining in the sun , which already was releasing the close - packed leaflets . [Hadria]211-hadria ( apparently out of sheer devilry , said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald ) kept up a running commentary on the season , and on [her]211-hadria hapless position , bound to be off on the chase for [a cook]5320-a cook at this moment of festival . Nor was this all . Crockery , pots and pans , clothes for [the children]667-the children , clothes for [herself]211-hadria , were urgently needed , and [no experienced person]5322-no experienced person , [she]211-hadria declared , could afford to regard the matter as simple because it was trivial . ‚Äú[2014-my cook] One of the ghastliest mistakes in this trivial and laborious world . ‚Äù [Valeria]109-valeria thought that [cooks]5323-cooks had simply to be advertised for , and [they]5323-cooks came . ‚Äú[2014-my cook] What na√Øvet√© ! ‚Äù exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú[197-helen] [Helen]197-helen was persuaded to cross [the seas]2015-the seas from [[her]197-helen Spartan home]2016-her spartan home to set [Troy]37-troy ablaze , and tarnish [her]197-helen fair fame , but it would take [twenty sons of [Priam]202-priam]2017-twenty sons of priam to induce [a damsel]2018-a damsel to come over [dry land]2019-dry land to [Craddock Dene]164-craddock dene , to cook [our]2020-our dinners and retain [her]2018-a damsel character . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2021-you] [You]2021-you would almost imply that [women]606-women do n't so very much care about [[their]606-women characters]2023-their characters , ‚Äù said [Valeria]109-valeria . ‚Äú[606-women] Oh , [they]606-women do ! but sometimes the dulness that [an intelligent society]2024-an intelligent society has ordained as the classic accompaniment to social smiles , gets the better of [a select few]2025-a select few ‚Äî [Helen]197-helen par exemple . ‚Äù It frequently happened that [Hadria]211-hadria and [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria came across [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton and [[her]176-lady engleton guests]5324-her guests , in [the Priory garden]1677-the priory garden . From being accidental , the meetings had become intentional . ‚Äú[197-helen] [I]0-i like to fancy [we]2020-our are [fugitives]2026-fugitives ‚Äî like [Boccaccio]203-boccaccio 's merry company ‚Äî from the plague of [our]2020-our daily prose , to this garden of sweet poetry ! ‚Äù cried [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . [They]2020-our all kindled at the idea . [Valeria]109-valeria made some fanciful laws that [she]109-valeria said were to govern [the little realm]5326-the little realm . [Everyone]3726-everyone might express [himself]3726-everyone freely , and all that [he]3726-everyone said would be held as sacred , as if it were in confidence . To speak ill or slightingly of [anyone]806-anyone , was forbidden . All local and practical topics were to be dropped , as soon as [the moss - grown griffins who guarded [the Garden of Forgetfulness]5330-the garden of forgetfulness]5329-the moss - grown griffins who guarded the garden of forgetfulness were passed . [Hadria]211-hadria was incorrigibly flippant about the banishment of important local subjects . [She]211-hadria said that the kitchen - boiler was out of order , and yet [she]211-hadria had to take part in these highly - cultivated conversations and smile , as [she]211-hadria complained , with that kitchen - boiler gnawing at [her]211-hadria vitals . [She]211-hadria claimed to be set on a level with [the Spartan boy]5331-the spartan boy , if not above [him]5331-the spartan boy . [Valeria]109-valeria might scoff , as those proverbially did who never felt a wound . [Hadria]211-hadria found a certain lack of tender feeling among [the happy few who had no such tragic burdens to sustain]5332-the happy few who had no such tragic burdens to sustain . Not only were [these prosaic subjects banished from within the cincture of the gentle griffins]5333-these prosaic subjects banished from within the cincture of the gentle griffins , but also the suspicions , spites , petty jealousies , vulgar curiosities , and all the indefinable little darts and daggers that fly in the social air , destroying human sympathy and good - will . Each mind could expand freely , no longer on the defensive against the rain of small stabs . There grew up a delicate , and chivalrous code among [the little group who met within [the griffins]5335-the griffins ' territory]5334-the little group who met within the griffins ' territory . ‚Äú[203-boccaccio] It is not for [us]2027-we to say that , individually , [we]2027-we transcend the average of [educated mortals]2028-educated mortals , ‚Äù said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , ‚Äú[203-boccaccio] but [I]0-i do assert that collectively [we]2027-we soar high above that depressing standard . ‚Äù [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue observed that whatever might be said about [[their]2027-we own little band]5336-their own little band , it was a strange fact that [bodies of]5337-bodies of [human beings]4313-human beings were able to produce , by union , a condition far above or far below the average of [their]2027-we separate values . ‚Äú[0-i] There is something chemical and explosive in human relationships , ‚Äù [he]116-professor fortescue said . These meetings stood out as a unique experience in the memory of [all who took part in them]5339-all who took part in them . [Chance]204-chance had brought [them]2027-we to pass , and [they]2027-we refused to answer to the call of [a less learned magician]5340-a less learned magician . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton and [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley alternately sent tea and fruit to [the terrace]1680-the terrace , on the days of meeting , and there [the little company]5342-the little company would spend the afternoon serenely , surrounded by the beauties of [the garden]3867-the garden with [its]3867-the garden enticing avenues , [its]3867-the garden chaunting birds , its flushes of bloom , and its rich delicious scents . ‚Äú[0-i] Why do [we]2027-we , in the nineteenth century , starve [ourselves]2027-we of these delicate joys ? ‚Äù cried [Valeria]109-valeria . ‚Äú[2027-we] Why do [we]2027-we so seldom leave [our]2027-we stupid pre - occupations and open [our]2027-we souls to the sun , to the spring , to the gentle invitations of [gardens]2029-gardens , to the charm of conversation ? [We]2027-we seem to know nothing of the serenities , the urbanities of life . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2027-we] [We]2027-we live too fast ; [we]2027-we are too much troubled about outward things ‚Äî [cooks]5323-cooks and [dressmakers]4812-dressmakers , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley , ‚Äù said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] [Poor cooks]2032-poor cooks and [dressmakers]4812-dressmakers ! ‚Äù murmured [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] where are [their]2032-poor cooks serenities and urbanities ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i would not deprive [any person]2034-any person of the good things of life , ‚Äù cried [Valeria]109-valeria ; ‚Äú[0-i] but at present , it is only [a few who can appreciate and contribute to the delicate essence]2035-a few who can appreciate and contribute to the delicate essence that [I]0-i speak of . [I]0-i do n't think [one]329-one could expect it of [[one]329-one 's cook]2038-one 's cook , after all . ‚Äù ‚Äú[329-one] [One]329-one is mad to expect anything of [those who have had no chance]2040-those who have had no chance , ‚Äù said [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . ‚Äú[329-one] That nevertheless [we]2041-us consistently do,‚Äîor what amounts to the same thing : [we]2041-us plume [ourselves]2041-us on what chance has enabled [us]2041-us to be and to achieve , as if between [us]2041-us and [the less fortunate]2042-the less fortunate there were some great difference of calibre and merit . Nine times in ten , there is nothing between [us]2041-us but luck . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] Oh , dear , [you]0-i are democratic , [Professor]181-professor theobald ! ‚Äù cried [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú[0-i] No ; [I]0-i am merely trying to be just . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] To be just [you]0-i must apply [your]0-i theory to [men]3698-men and [women]606-women , as well as to class and class , ‚Äù [Valeria]109-valeria suggested . ‚Äú[0-i] [Mon Dieu]205-mon dieu ! but so [I]0-i do ; so [I]0-i always have done , as soon as [I]0-i was intellectually short - coated . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] And would [you]0-i excuse all [our]2041-us weaknesses on that ground ? ‚Äù asked [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , with a somewhat ingratiating upward gaze of [her]176-lady engleton blue eyes . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i would account for [them]2045-them as [I]0-i would account for the weaknesses of [my]0-i own sex . As for excusing , the question of moral responsibility is too involved to be decided off - hand . ‚Äù The atmosphere of [Griffin - land]38-griffin - land , as [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald called it , while becoming to [his]181-professor theobald character , made [him]181-professor theobald a little recklessly frank at times . [He]181-professor theobald admitted that throughout [his]181-professor theobald varied experience of life , [he]181-professor theobald had found flattery the most powerful weapon in a skilled hand , and that [he]181-professor theobald had never known it fail . [He]181-professor theobald related instances of the signal success which had followed its application with the trowel . [He]181-professor theobald reminded [[his]181-professor theobald listeners]1015-his listeners of [Lord Beaconsfield]206-lord beaconsfield 's famous saying , and chuckled over [the unfortunate woman]5345-the unfortunate woman , ‚Äú[0-i] plain as a pike - staff , ‚Äù who had become [his]181-professor theobald benefactress , in consequence of a discreet allusion to the ‚Äú[0-i] power of beauty ‚Äù and a well - placed sigh . ‚Äú[4547-the woman] [The woman]4547-the woman must have been [a fool]1606-a fool ! ‚Äù said [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming . ‚Äú[4547-the woman] By no means ; [she]4547-the woman was of brilliant intellect . But praises of that were tame to [her]4547-the woman ; [she]4547-the woman knew [her]4547-the woman force , and was perhaps tired of the solitude it induced . ‚Äù [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald laughed mightily at [his]181-professor theobald own sarcasm . ‚Äú[4547-the woman] But when the whisper of ‚Äò beauty ‚Äô came stealing to [her]4547-the woman ear ( which was by no means like a shell ) it was surpassing sweet to [her]4547-the woman .
