What is [your]0-i verdict , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley ? ‚Äù [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley supposed that [clever women]5346-clever women had something of human nature in [them]5346-clever women , and valued overmuch what [they]5346-clever women did not possess . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had perhaps looked for an answer that would have betrayed more of [the speaker]306-the speaker 's secret feelings . ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] It is the fashion , [I]0-i know , ‚Äù [he]181-professor theobald said , ‚Äú[0-i] to regard [woman]3844-woman as an enigma . Now , without professing any unusual acuteness , [I]0-i believe that this is a mistake . [Woman]207-woman is [an enigma]2050-an enigma certainly , because [she]207-woman is human , but that ends it . [Her]207-woman conditions have tended to cultivate in [her]207-woman the power of dissimulation , and the histrionic quality , just as [the peaceful ilex]2051-the peaceful ilex learns to put forth thorns if [you]2052-you expose it to the attacks of devouring cattle . It is this instinct to develop thorns in self - defence , and yet to live a little behind the prickly outposts , that leads to [our]2053-our notion of mystery in [woman]3844-woman 's nature . Let [a man]3704-a man 's subsistence and career be subject to the same powers and chances as the success of [a woman]3753-a woman 's life now hangs on , and see whether [he]3704-a man too does not become [a histrionic enigma]2057-a histrionic enigma . ‚Äù [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue observed that [the clergy]5348-the clergy , at times , developed qualities called feminine , because in some respects [their]5348-the clergy conditions resembled those of [women]606-women . [Theobald]181-professor theobald assented enthusiastically to this view . [He]181-professor theobald had [himself]181-professor theobald entered [the church]1115-the church as [a young fellow]5351-a young fellow ( let not [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley look so inconsiderately astonished ) , and had left it on account of being unable to conscientiously subscribe to its tenets . ‚Äú[0-i] But not before [I]0-i had acquired some severe training in that sort of strategy which is incumbent upon [women]606-women , in the conduct of [their]606-women lives . Whatever [I]0-i might privately think or feel , [[my]0-i office]2059-my office required that [I]0-i should only express that which would be more or less grateful to [[my]0-i hearers]2060-my hearers . ( Is not this [the woman]4547-the woman 's case , in almost every position in life ? ) Even orthodoxy must trip it on tiptoe ; there was always some prejudice , some susceptibility to consider . What was frankness in others was imprudence in [me]0-i ; [other men]1807-other men 's minds might roam at large ; [mine]0-i was tethered , if not in its secret movements , at least in its utterance ; and it is a curious and somewhat sinister law of Nature , that perpetual denial of utterance ends by killing the power or the feeling so held in durance . ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria coloured . ‚Äú[0-i] That experience and its effect upon [my]0-i own nature , which has lasted to this day , ‚Äù added [Theobald]181-professor theobald , ‚Äú[0-i] served to increase [my]0-i interest in the fascinating study of character in its relation to environment . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] Ah ! ‚Äù exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äú[0-i] then [you]0-i do n't believe in the independent power of the human will ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] Certainly not . To talk of character overcoming circumstance is to talk of an effect without a cause . Yet this phrase is a mere commonplace in [our]2063-our speech . [A man]3704-a man no more overcomes [his]3704-a man circumstance than oxygen overcomes nitrogen when it combines with it to form the air [we]2063-our breathe . If the nitrogen is present , the combination takes place ; but if there is no nitrogen to be had , all the oxygen in [the world]334-the world will not produce [our]2063-our blessed atmosphere ! ‚Äù [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming caused a sort of anti - climax by mentioning simply that [he]159-joseph fleming did n't know that any nitrogen was required in the atmosphere . [One]329-one always heard about the oxygen . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald remarked , with a chuckle , that this was one of the uses of polite conversation ; [one]329-one picked up information by the way - side . [HADRIA]211-hadria thought that [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had not spoken at random , when [he]181-professor theobald said that the sweetest tribute [a woman]3753-a woman can receive is that paid to [her]3753-a woman personal charm . [Both Professors]5381-both professors looked at [her]211-hadria , each with an expression of enquiry . It was difficult to understand from exactly what sources of experience or intuition the singular remark could have sprung . The conversation took a slight swerve . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald contended that all [our]2083-our fond distinctions of vice and virtue , right and wrong , were mere praise and blame of conditions and events . ‚Äú[2081-you] [We]2083-our like to fancy the qualities of character inherent , while really they are laid on by slow degrees , like paint , and [we]2083-our name [our]2083-our acquaintance by the colour of [his]2084-his last coat . ‚Äù This view offended [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . ‚Äù cried [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . ‚Äú[0-i] Then [you]0-i insist on varnish , [I]0-i on paint . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] There is a difference . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] And it affects [your]2087-you respective views throughout , ‚Äù added [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , ‚Äú[0-i] for if the paint theory be correct , then it is true that to know [[one]329-one 's fellows]2089-one 's fellows is impossible , [you]2087-you can only know the upper coat ; whereas if the truth lies in varnish , the substance of the nature is revealed to [you]2087-you frankly , if [you]2087-you have eyes to trace the delicacies of the markings , which tell the secrets of sap and fibre , of impetus and check : all the inner marvels of life and growth that go forward in that most botanic thing , the human soul . ‚Äù ‚Äú[116-professor fortescue] [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue is eloquent , but [he]116-professor fortescue makes [one]329-one feel distressingly vegetable , ‚Äù said [Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . ‚Äú[116-professor fortescue] Oh ! Why should [they]2101-them hurry away ? ‚Äú[2100-its] The time when [we]2101-them could lay claim to have ‚Äò hurried ‚Äô has long since passed , [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , ‚Äù said [Hubert]118-hubert , ‚Äú[176-lady engleton] [we]2101-them can only plead forgiveness by blaming [you]176-lady engleton for making [us]2101-them too happy . ‚Äù [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald went to the window . ‚Äú[176-lady engleton] What splendid moonlight ! During this period of the Renaissance , as [Hadria]211-hadria afterwards called the short - lived epoch , [little Martha]129-martha was visited frequently . [[Her]129-martha protectress]5424-her protectress had expected to have to do battle with hereditary weakness on account of [[her]129-martha mother]520-her mother 's sufferings , but [the child]4983-the child [shewed]5427-shewed no signs of this . [Hadria]211-hadria had begun to feel a more personal interest in [her]211-hadria charge . [She]211-hadria had taken it under [her]211-hadria care of [her]211-hadria own choice , without the pressure of any social law or sentiment , and in these circumstances of freedom , its helplessness appealed to [her]211-hadria protective instincts . [Little Martha]129-martha shrank away a little from the bearded face , and [her]129-martha lower lip worked threateningly , but the perilous moment was staved over by means of [the Professor]4071-the professor 's watch , hastily claimed by [Hannah]212-hannah , who dispensed with ceremony in the emergency . [The child]4983-the child was in high delight at the loquacious new toy ‚Äî so superior to foolish fluffy rabbits that could not tick to save [their]2161-the young m√©nage skins . [Martha]129-martha had no notion of relinquishing [her]129-martha hold , so [they]5445-they need not tug in that feeble way ; if [they]5445-they pulled too hard , [she]129-martha would yell ! [She]129-martha evidently meant business , said [[her]129-martha captive]5446-her captive . [She]129-martha proceeded to stuff the watch into [her]129-martha mouth as far as it would go . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton seemed to have expected dissent . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i think , ‚Äù [she]0-i said , ‚Äú[0-i] that [we]2248-our are getting too squeamish nowadays as to speech . [Women]606-women are so frightened to call a spade a spade . ‚Äù ‚Äú[606-women] It is the spade that is ugly , not the name . ‚Äù ‚Äú[606-women] But , [[my]0-i dear]3722-my dear ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] Oh , it is not a question of squeamishness , it is the insult of the thing . [She]176-lady engleton liked to listen to [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley when [she]176-lady engleton was thoroughly roused . ‚Äú[3722-my dear] It is the hideous mixture of the delicately civilised with the brutally savage that makes [one sick]2253-one sick . A frankly barbarous ceremony , where there was no pretence of refinement and propriety and so forth , would be infinitely less revolting . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3722-my dear] Which [your]3722-my dear language is plain , ‚Äù observed [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , much amused . ‚Äú[3722-my dear] [I]0-i hope so . Did n't [you]3722-my dear see how it all hurt [that poor girl]2254-that poor girl ? One of [her]2254-that poor girl training too ‚Äî suspended in mid air ‚Äî not an earthward glance . [You]3722-my dear know [Mrs. Jordan]179-mrs. jordan 's views on the education of [girls]3769-girls . [Poor girls]2256-poor girls . [They]2256-poor girls are morally skinned , in such a way as to make contact with Fact a veritable torture , and then suddenly [they]2256-poor girls are sent forth defenceless into Life to be literally curry - combed . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2256-poor girls] [They]2256-poor girls adjust [themselves]2256-poor girls , ‚Äù said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú[2256-poor girls] Adjust [themselves]2256-poor girls ! ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria vindictively flicked off the head of a dandelion with [her]211-hadria parasol . ‚Äú[2256-poor girls] [They]2256-poor girls awake to find [they]2256-poor girls have been living in [a Fool 's Paradise]2257-a fool 's paradise ‚Äî [a little upholstered corner with stained glass windows and rose - coloured light]2258-a little upholstered corner with stained glass windows and rose - coloured light . [They]2256-poor girls find that suddenly [they]2256-poor girls are expected to place in the centre of [their]2256-poor girls life everything that up to that moment [they]2256-poor girls have scarcely been allowed even to know about ; [they]2256-poor girls find that [they]2256-poor girls must obediently veer round , with the amiable adaptability of a well - oiled weather - cock . Every instinct , every prejudice must be thrown over . All the effects of [their]2256-poor girls training must be instantly overcome . And all this with perfect subjection and cheerfulness , on pain of moral avalanches and deluges , and heaven knows what convulsions of conventional nature ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[2256-poor girls] There certainly is some curious incongruity in [our]2259-our training , ‚Äù [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton admitted . ‚Äú[2256-poor girls] Incongruity ! Think what it means for [a girl]3734-a girl to have been taught to connect the idea of something low and evil with that which nevertheless is to lie at the foundation of all [her]3734-a girl after life . That is what it amounts to , and [people]3687-people complain that [women]606-women are not logical . ‚Äù [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton laughed . ‚Äú[3687-people] Fortunately things work better in practice than might be expected , judging them in the abstract . How [bashful Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald seems suddenly to have become ! Why does n't [he]181-professor theobald join [us]2259-our , [I]0-i wonder ? However , so much the better ; [I]0-i do like to hear [you]2263-you talk heresy . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2263-you] [I]0-i do more than talk it , [I]0-i mean it , ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i fail utterly to get at the popular point of view . ‚Äù But [you]2263-you misrepresent it ‚Äî there are modifying facts in the case . ‚Äù[0-i] ‚Äú [I]176-lady engleton do n't see [them]5528-them . [Girls]3769-girls are told : ‚Äò So and so is not a nice thing for [you]2263-you to talk about . Wait , however , until the proper signal is given , and then woe betide [you]2263-you if [you]2263-you do n't cheerfully accept it as [your]2263-you bounden duty . ‚Äô If that does not enjoin abject slavishness and deliberate immorality of the most cold - blooded kind , [I]176-lady engleton simply do n't know what does . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton seemed to ponder somewhat seriously , as [she]176-lady engleton stood looking down at the grave beside [her]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú How [we]5530-we ever came to have tied [ourselves]5530-we into such an extraordinary mental knot is what bewilders [me]176-lady engleton , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [Hadria]211-hadria continued , ‚Äú and still more , why it is that [we]5530-we all , by common consent , go on acting and talking as if the tangled skein ran smooth and straight through one 's fingers . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú Chiefly , perhaps , because [women]606-women wo n't speak out , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] suggested [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú [They]2265-they have been so drilled , ‚Äù[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äú so gagged , so deafened , by ‚Äò the shrieks of near relations . ‚Äô ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton was asking for an explanation , when the wedding - bells began to clang out from [the belfry]2264-the belfry , merry and roughly rejoicing . ‚Äú Tom - boy bells , ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria called [them]2265-they . ( How [that man]5238-that man does dawdle ! ) ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria shrugged [her]211-hadria shoulders . ‚Äú It seems to [me]211-hadria so ; for now suppose , on the other hand , that [this same Marion]5558-this same marion , on any day subsequent to this , should go to [that same mother]5559-that same mother , and announce an exactly opposite feeling ‚Äî a profound objection to the maternal function ‚Äî how would [she]219-marion be received ? It really shows a touching confidence in the swift adaptability of [the woman]4547-the woman 's sentimental organization ! ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton gave an uneasy laugh , and seemed lost in uncomfortable thought . [She]176-lady engleton enjoyed playing with unorthodox speculations , but [she]176-lady engleton objected to have [her]176-lady engleton customary feelings interfered with , by a reasoning which [she]176-lady engleton did not see [her]176-lady engleton way to reduce to a condition of uncertainty . [She]176-lady engleton liked to leave a question delicately balanced , enjoying all the fun of ‚Äú advanced ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] thought without endangering [her]176-lady engleton favourite sentiments . Like [many women of talent]2284-many women of talent , [she]176-lady engleton was intensely maternal , in the instinctive sense ; and for that reason had a vague desire to insist on [all other women]2285-all other women being equally so ; but the notion of the instinct becoming importunate in [a girl]3734-a girl revolted [her]176-lady engleton ; a state of mind that struggled to justify itself without conscious entrenchment behind mere tradition . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton sincerely tried to shake off prejudice . ‚Äú [You]5564-you are in a mixed condition of feeling , [I]211-hadria see , ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria said . ‚Äú [I]211-hadria am not surprised . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton appeared to be again plunged in thought . ‚Äú The maternal instinct ‚Äî yes ; it seems to be round that unacknowledged centre that the whole storm is raging . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] ‚Äú A desperate question that [Society]43-society shrinks from in terror : whether [women]606-women shall be expected to conduct [themselves]606-women as if the instinct had been weighed out accurately , like weekly stores , and given to [all alike]5572-all alike , or whether choice and individual feeling is to be held lawful in this matter ‚Äî there is the red - hot heart of the battle . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] ‚Äú Remember [men of science]5573-men of science are against freedom in this respect . [Women]606-women are driving [[their]606-women masters]5576-their masters to plain speaking ‚Äî the ornaments are being dragged down . And what do [we]5573-men of science find ? [She]211-hadria wishes things , in [this department]5577-this department , left as they are . [I]176-lady engleton daresay . [One]329-one can guard against that , after a fashion , by never making a stretch after truth . And the reward comes , of its kind . [This poor woman]5605-this poor woman , a short while ago , was dying of grief and shame and agony , and [the village]1124-the village was stirred with excitement , as if the solar system had come to grief . It all seemed so stupendous and important , yet now ‚Äî look at that tall grass waving in the wind ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] [PROFESSOR THEOBALD]181-professor theobald had been engaged , for the last ten minutes , in instructing [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming and a few stragglers , among whom was [Dodge]155-dodge , in the characteristics of ancient architecture . [He]181-professor theobald was pointing out the fine Norman window of [the south transept]2293-the south transept , [Joseph]159-joseph fleming nodding wearily , [Dodge]155-dodge leaning judicially on [his]181-professor theobald broom and listening with attention . [Joseph]159-joseph fleming , as [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton remarked , was evidently bearing [the Normans]221-the normans a bitter grudge for making interesting arches . [The Professor]181-professor theobald seemed to have no notion of tempering the wind of [his]181-professor theobald instruction to [the shorn lambs of [[his]181-professor theobald audience]1987-his audience]2294-the shorn lambs of his audience . ‚Äú [I]176-lady engleton ca n't understand why [he]159-joseph fleming does not join [us]5607-us , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú It must be nearly luncheon time . However , it does n't much matter , as [everyone]3726-everyone seems to be up here . [I]176-lady engleton wonder , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [she]176-lady engleton went on after a pause , ‚Äú what [the bride]5491-the bride would think if [she]5491-the bride had heard [our]5607-us conversation this morning ! ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] ‚Äú Probably [she]5491-the bride would recognize many a half - thought of [her]5491-the bride own , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton shook [her]176-lady engleton head . ‚Äú [They]5610-they alarm [me]176-lady engleton , all these ideas . For [myself]176-lady engleton , [I]176-lady engleton feel bound to accept the decision of [wise and good men , who have studied social questions deeply]5611-wise and good men , who have studied social questions deeply . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] Personal feeling had finally overcome [her]176-lady engleton desire to fight off the influence of tradition . ‚Äú [I]176-lady engleton do not feel competent to judge in a matter so complex , and must be content to abide by the opinions of [those who have knowledge and experience]5612-those who have knowledge and experience . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton thus retreated hastily behind cover . That was a strategic movement always available in difficulties , and it left [[one]329-one 's companion]2297-one 's companion in speculation alone in the open , arrogantly sustaining an eagle - gaze in the sun 's face . The advantages of feminine humility were obvious . [One]329-one could come out for a skirmish and then run for shelter , in awkward moments . [No woman]5158-no woman ought to venture out on [the bare plain]2300-the bare plain without a provision of the kind . [Hadria]211-hadria had a curious sensation of being so exposed , when [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton retreated behind [her]211-hadria ‚Äú good and [wise men]5613-wise men , ‚Äù[211-hadria] and [she]211-hadria had the usual feminine sense of discomfort in the feeling of presumption that it produced . Heredity asserted itself , as it will do , in the midst of the fray , just when [its victim]2301-its victim seems to have shaken [himself]2301-its victim free from the mysterious obsession . But [Hadria]211-hadria did not visibly flinch . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton received the impression that [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley was too sure of [her]154-mrs. temperley own judgment to defer even to the wisest . [She]176-lady engleton experienced a pleasant little glow of humility , wrapping [herself]176-lady engleton in it , as in a protecting garment , and unconsciously comparing [her]176-lady engleton more moderate and modest attitude favourably with [[her]176-lady engleton companion]3995-her companion 's self - confidence . Just at that moment , [Hadria]211-hadria 's self - confidence was gasping for breath . But [her]176-lady engleton sense of the comic in [[her]176-lady engleton companion]3995-her companion 's tactics survived , and set [her]176-lady engleton off in an apparently inconsequent laugh , which goaded [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton into retreating further , to an encampment of pure orthodoxy . ‚Äú [I]176-lady engleton fear there is an element of the morbid , in all this fretful revolt against the old - established destiny of [our]5614-our sex , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [she]176-lady engleton said . And anything is better than this meek endurance , this persistent heaping of penalties on [the scapegoat]2349-the scapegoat . ‚Äù No good ever came of mere revenge , however , ‚Äù[181-professor theobald] said [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . ‚Äú Sometimes that is the only form of remonstrance that is listened to , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú When [people]3687-people have the law in [their]3687-people own hands and [Society]43-society at [their]3687-people back , [they]3687-people can afford to be deaf to mere verbal protest . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú As for [the child]4983-the child , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , ‚Äú [she]4983-the child will be in no little danger of a fate like [[her]4983-the child mother]520-her mother 's . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] [Hadria]211-hadria 's face darkened . ‚Äú At least then , [she]4983-the child shall have some free and happy hours first ; at least [she]4983-the child shall not be driven to it by the misery of moral starvation , starvation of the affections . [She]4983-the child shall be protected from [the solemn fools ‚Äî with sawdust for brains and a mechanical squeaker for heart]5672-the solemn fools ‚Äî with sawdust for brains and a mechanical squeaker for heart ‚Äî who , on principle , cut off from [[her]4983-the child mother]520-her mother all joy and all savour in life , and then punished [her]4983-the child for falling a victim to the starved emotional condition to which [they]5672-the solemn fools ‚Äî with sawdust for brains and a mechanical squeaker for heart had reduced [her]4983-the child . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú The matter seems complex , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , ‚Äú and [I]176-lady engleton do n't see how revenge comes in . ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] ‚Äú It is a passion that has never been eradicated . THE sound of music stole over [the gardens of [the Priory]1664-the priory]2350-the gardens of the priory , at sunset . It was the close of one of the most exquisite days of Spring . A calm had settled over [the country]401-the country with the passing away of [the sun - god]2353-the sun - god . [His]2353-the sun - god attendant winds and voices had been sacrificed on [his]2353-the sun - god funeral pyre . [Two figures]2354-two figures sat on [the terrace]1680-the terrace by the open window of [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room , listening to the utterance , in music , of a tumultuous , insurgent spirit . In [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , the musical passion was deeply rooted , as it is in most profoundly sympathetic and tender natures . [Algitha]81-algitha anxiously watched the effect of [[her]81-algitha sister]313-her sister 's playing on [[her]81-algitha companion]3995-her companion . The wild power of [the composer]2359-the composer was not merely obvious , it was overwhelming . It was like ‚Äú a sudden storm among mountains , ‚Äù[2359-the composer] ‚Äú the wind - swept heavens at midnight , ‚Äù[2359-the composer] ‚Äú [the lonely sea]5677-the lonely sea ‚Äù[2359-the composer] : [he]2359-the composer struggled for the exactly - fitting simile . There was none , because of its many - sidedness . Loneliness remained as an ever - abiding quality . There were moon - glimpses and sun - bursts over the scenery of the music ; there was sweetness , and a vernal touch that thrilled [the listeners]2360-the listeners as with the breath of flowers and the fragrance of earth after rain , but always , behind all fancy and grace and tenderness , and even passion , lurked that spectral loneliness . [The performer]2361-the performer would cease for some minutes , and presently begin again in a new mood . The music was always characteristic , often wild and strange , yet essentially sane . ‚Äú There is a strong Celtic element in it , ‚Äù[4071-the professor] said [the Professor]4071-the professor . ‚Äú This is a very wonderful gift . [I]4071-the professor suppose [one]329-one never does really know [[one]329-one 's fellows]2089-one 's fellows : [her]329-one music to - night reveals to [me]4071-the professor new sides of [Hadria]211-hadria 's character . ‚Äù[4071-the professor] ‚Äú [I]81-algitha confess [they]5681-they alarm [me]81-algitha , ‚Äù[81-algitha] said [Algitha]81-algitha . ‚Äú Truly , this is not the sort of power that can be safely shut up and stifled . It is the sort of power for which everything ought to be set aside . [The gardens]2375-the gardens were steeped in profound peace . [One]329-one could hear no sound for miles round . [The broad country]2377-the broad country made [itself]2377-the broad country closely felt by [its]2377-the broad country stirring silence . [The stretches of fields beyond [fields]2379-fields]2378-the stretches of fields beyond fields , the woodlands in their tender green , the long , long sweep of [the quiet land]2380-the quiet land , formed a benign circle round [the garden]3867-the garden , and led the sense of peace out and out to [the horizon]2382-the horizon , where the liquid light of the sky touched [the hills]413-the hills . The face of [the Professor]116-professor fortescue had a transparent look and a singular beauty of expression , such as is seen on the faces of the dead , or on the faces of [those who are carried beyond themselves by some generous enthusiasm]2384-those who are carried beyond themselves by some generous enthusiasm . [They]2385-they watched , in silence , the changes creeping over the heavens , the subtle transmutations of tint ; [the fairylands of cloud]2386-the fairylands of cloud , growing like dreams , and melting in golden annihilation ; the more delicate and exquisite , the sooner the end . The first pale hints of splendour had spread , till [the whole West]2387-the whole west was throbbing with the radiance . But it was short - lived . The soul of the light , with its vital vibrating quality , seemed to die , and then slowly the glow faded , till every sparkle was gone , and the amphitheatre of the sky lay cold , and dusk , and empty . It was not till the last gleam had melted away that a word was spoken . ‚Äú It is like a prophecy , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú To - morrow the dawn , remember . ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria 's thoughts ran on in the silence . What remains of [me]4071-the professor has been dragged ashore as from a wreck , amidst a rush of wind and wave . But just now , thanks greatly to [your]211-hadria sympathy and [Algitha]81-algitha 's , [I]4071-the professor seem restored to [myself]4071-the professor . [I]4071-the professor can never describe the rapture of that sensation to one who has never felt [himself]5751-oneself sinking down and down into darkness , to a dim hell , where the doom is a slow decay instead of the fiery pains of burning . ‚Äù[4071-the professor] ‚Äú This is all wrong , wrong ! ‚Äù[4071-the professor] cried [the Professor]4071-the professor anxiously . ‚Äú Ah ! but [I]4071-the professor feel now , such certainty , such courage . It seems as if [Fate]102-fate were giving [me]4071-the professor one more chance . [I]4071-the professor have often run very close to making a definite decision ‚Äî to dare everything rather than await [this fool]5752-this fool 's disaster . But then comes that everlasting feminine humility , sneaking up with its simper : ‚Äò Is not this presumptuous , selfish , mistaken , wrong ? What business have [you]211-hadria , one out of so many , to break roughly through the delicate web that has been spun for [your]211-hadria kindly detention ? ‚Äô Of course [my]4071-the professor retort is : ‚Äò What business have [they]5753-they to spin the web ? ‚Äô But [one]329-one can never get up a real sense of injured innocence . It is always [the spiders who seem injured and innocent]5755-the spiders who seem injured and innocent . However , this time [I]4071-the professor am going to try , though the heavens fall ! ‚Äù[4071-the professor] A figure appeared , in the dusk , at the further end of [the avenue]945-the avenue . It proved to be [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria , who had come to find [Hadria]211-hadria . [Henriette]142-henriette had arrived unexpectedly by [the late afternoon train]2419-the late afternoon train , and [Valeria]109-valeria had volunteered to announce [her]142-henriette arrival to [[her]142-henriette sister - in - law]4937-her sister - in - law . ‚Äú Ah ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] exclaimed [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äú heaven helps [him]5756-him who helps [himself]5756-him ! This will fit in neatly with [my]211-hadria plans . ‚Äù[211-hadria] [VALERIA DU PREL]109-valeria , finding that [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley proposed a visit of some length , returned to [town]4255-town by [the early morning train]2422-the early morning train . ‚Äú [Valeria]109-valeria , do [you]109-valeria know anyone in [Paris]35-paris to whom [you]109-valeria could give [me]211-hadria a letter of introduction ? ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria asked , at the last moment , when there was just time to write the letter , and no more . ‚Äú Are [you]109-valeria going to [Paris]35-paris ? ‚Äù[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria asked , startled . ‚Äú Please write the letter and [I]109-valeria will tell [you]109-valeria some day what [I]109-valeria want it for . ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú Nothing very mad , [I]109-valeria hope ? ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú No , only a little ‚Äî judiciously mad . ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú Well , there is [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux , in [the Avenue Kleber]5757-the avenue kleber , but [her]195-madame bertaux [you]109-valeria know already . [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria looked rather anxiously at [Hadria]211-hadria and [[her]211-hadria sister - in - law]4937-her sister - in - law , as [they]2426-they stood on the steps to bid [her]211-hadria good - bye . [The two figures]450-the two figures turned and entered [the house]296-the house together , as [the pony - cart]4124-the pony - cart passed through the gate . [Hadria]211-hadria always gave [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley much opportunity for the employment of tact , finding this tact more elucidating than otherwise to the designs that it was intended to conceal ; it affected them in the manner of a magnifying - glass . About a couple of years ago , the death of [[her]211-hadria mother]520-her mother had thrown [Henriette]142-henriette on [her]211-hadria own resources , and set free a large amount of energy that craved a legitimate outlet . [The family with whom [she]211-hadria was now living in [London]8-london , not being related to [her]211-hadria]2431-the family with whom she was now living in london , not being related to her , offered but limited opportunities . [Henriette]142-henriette 's eye was fixed , with increasing fondness , upon [the Red House]4718-the red house . There lay the callow brood marked out by Nature and [man]332-man , for [her]211-hadria ministrations . With infinite adroitness , [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley questioned [[her]141-miss temperley sister - in - law]4937-her sister - in - law , by inference and suggestion , about the affairs of [the household]2435-the household . [Hadria]211-hadria evaded the attempt , but rejoiced , for reasons of [her]211-hadria own , that it was made . [She]211-hadria began to find the occupation diverting , and characteristically did not hesitate to allow [[her]211-hadria critic]2436-her critic to form most alarming conclusions as to the state of matters at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [She]211-hadria was pensive , and mild , and a little surprised when [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley , with a suppressed gasp , urged that the question was deeply serious . It amused [Hadria]211-hadria to reproduce , for [Henriette]142-henriette 's benefit , the theories regarding the treatment and training of [children]626-children that [she]211-hadria had found current among [the mothers of [the district]714-the district]2439-the mothers of the district . [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux happened to call during the afternoon , and [that outspoken lady]2441-that outspoken lady scoffed openly at these theories , declaring that [women]606-women made idiots of [themselves]606-women on behalf of [[their]606-women children]654-their children , whom [they]606-women preposterously ill - used with unflagging devotion . ‚Äú The moral training of [young minds]5767-young minds is such a problem , ‚Äù[142-henriette] said [Henriette]142-henriette , after [the visitor]4013-the visitor had left , ‚Äú it must cause [you]211-hadria many an anxious thought . ‚Äù[142-henriette] [Hadria]211-hadria arranged [herself]211-hadria comfortably among cushions , and let every muscle relax . ‚Äú [The boys]3870-the boys are so young yet , ‚Äù[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria said drowsily . ‚Äú [I]211-hadria have no doubt that will all come , later on . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú But , [[my]142-henriette dear]3722-my dear [Hadria]211-hadria , unless [they]3870-the boys are trained now ‚Äî ‚Äù[142-henriette] ‚Äú Oh , there is plenty of time ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú Do [you]211-hadria mean to say ‚Äî ? ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú Only what [other people]3849-other people say . [One]329-one ca n't expect accomplished morality from [poor little dots of five and six]5777-poor little dots of five and six . The charm of infancy would be gone . ‚Äù[142-henriette] [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley explained , remonstrated . [Hadria]211-hadria was limp , docile , unemphatic . Perhaps [Henriette]142-henriette was right , [she]142-henriette did n't know . A sense of honour ? ( [Hadria]211-hadria suppressed a smile . ) Could [one]329-one , after all , expect of six what [one]329-one did not always get at six and twenty ? Morals altogether seemed a good deal to ask of [irresponsible youth]2447-irresponsible youth . [Henriette]142-henriette could not overrate the importance of early familiarity with the difference between right and wrong . Certainly it was important , but [Hadria]211-hadria shrank from an extreme view . [One]329-one must not rush into it without careful thought . ‚Äú But meanwhile [the children]667-the children are growing up ! ‚Äù[142-henriette] cried [Henriette]142-henriette , in despair . [Hadria]211-hadria had not found that [experienced mothers]2449-experienced mothers laid much stress on that fact . Besides , there was considerable difficulty in the matter . [Henriette]142-henriette did not see it . The difference between right and wrong could easily be taught to [a child]754-a child . Perhaps so , but it seemed to be thought expedient to defer the lesson till the distant future ; at least , if [one]329-one might judge from the literature especially designed for growing minds , wherein clever villainy was exalted , and deeds of ferocious cruelty and revenge occurred as a daily commonplace among [heroes]2452-heroes . The same policy was indicated by the practice of allowing [children]626-children to become familiar with the sight of slaughter , and of violence of every kind towards animals , from earliest infancy . [Hadria]211-hadria concluded from all this , that it was thought wise to postpone the moral training of [the young]2454-the young till a more convenient season . [Henriette]142-henriette looked at [[her]142-henriette sister - in - law]4937-her sister - in - law , with a sad and baffled mien . [She]211-hadria had taken hints , [she]211-hadria said , from [mothers of [large families]2461-large families]2460-mothers of large families . [Henriette]142-henriette laid stress upon fresh air , even in [the house]296-the house . [Hadria]211-hadria believed in fresh air ; but was it not going a little far to have it in [the house]296-the house ? [Henriette]142-henriette shook [her]142-henriette head . Fresh air was always necessary . In moderation , perhaps , [Hadria]211-hadria admitted . But the utmost care was called for , to avoid taking cold . [She]211-hadria laid great stress upon that . [Children]626-children were naturally so susceptible . In [all the nurseries that [she]211-hadria had visited]2465-all the nurseries that she had visited , where every possible precaution was taken against draughts , [the children]667-the children were incessantly taking cold . ‚Äú Perhaps the precautions made [them]667-the children delicate , ‚Äù[142-henriette] [Henriette]142-henriette suggested . But this paradox [Hadria]211-hadria could not entertain . ‚Äú Take care of the colds , and the fresh air will take care of itself , ‚Äù[211-hadria] was [her]211-hadria general maxim . ‚Äú But , [[my]211-hadria dear]3722-my dear [Hadria]211-hadria , do [you]211-hadria mean to tell [me]211-hadria that [the people about here]914-the people about here are so benighted as really not to understand the importance to the system of a constant supply of pure air ? ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria puckered up [her]211-hadria brow , as if in thought . ‚Äú Well , ‚Äù[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria said , ‚Äú [several mothers]5784-several mothers have mentioned it , but [they]5784-several mothers take more interest in fluid magnesia and tonics . ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Henriette]142-henriette looked dispirited . ( [Hadria]211-hadria bent low over [her]211-hadria embroidery . ) The night ? ‚Äú Oh ! then [one]329-one must , of course , expect to be a little stuffy . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú But , ‚Äù[141-miss temperley] cried [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley , almost hopeless , ‚Äú impure air breathed , night after night , is an incessant drain on the strength , even if each time it only does a little harm . ‚Äù[141-miss temperley] [Hadria]211-hadria smiled over [her]211-hadria silken arabesques . ‚Äú Oh , [nobody]3732-nobody ever objects to things that only do a little harm . ‚Äù[211-hadria] There was a moment of silence . [You]142-henriette have no scope for it at present . ‚Äù[142-henriette] [Henriette]142-henriette was bewildered , horrified , yet secretly thrilled with joy on [her]142-henriette own account . [Her]211-hadria manner was restless . A day or two of rain had prevented the usual walks . When it cleared up again , the season had taken a stride . Still more glorious was the array of tree and flower , and their indescribable freshness suggested the idea that [they]2483-they were bathed in the mysterious elixir of life , and that if one touched [them]2483-they , eternal youth would be the reward . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald said suddenly , that [Hadria]211-hadria looked as if [she]211-hadria were turning over some project very anxiously in [her]211-hadria mind ‚Äî a project on which much depended . ‚Äú[0-i] [You]181-professor theobald are very penetrating , ‚Äù [she]0-i replied , after a moment 's hesitation , ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] that is exactly what [I]0-i am doing . When [I]0-i was [a girl]3734-a girl , [[my]0-i brothers]857-my brothers and [sisters]378-sisters and [I]0-i used to discuss the question of the sovereignty of the will . [I]0-i want to try that theory and see what comes of it . ‚Äù ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] [You]181-professor theobald alarm [me]0-i , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley . ‚Äù ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] Yes , [people]3687-people always do seem to get alarmed when one attempts to put [their]3687-people favourite theories in practice . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3687-people] But really ‚Äî for [a woman]3753-a woman ‚Äî ‚Äù ‚Äú[3753-a woman] The sovereignty of the will is a dangerous doctrine ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[3753-a woman] Well , as things are ; [a young woman]926-a young woman , [a beautiful woman]2494-a beautiful woman . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2494-a beautiful woman] [You]181-professor theobald recall an interesting memory , ‚Äù [she]154-mrs. temperley said . ‚Äú[2494-a beautiful woman] Ah , that is unkind . ‚Äù [Her]154-mrs. temperley smile checked [him]181-professor theobald . ‚Äú[2494-a beautiful woman] When [you]181-professor theobald fall into a mocking humour , [you]181-professor theobald are quite impracticable . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i merely smiled , ‚Äù [she]154-mrs. temperley said , ‚Äú[0-i] sweetly , as [I]0-i thought . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] It is really cruel ; [I]0-i have not had a word with [you]181-professor theobald for days , and [the universe]420-the universe has become [a wilderness]2496-a wilderness . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [A pleasant wilderness]2497-a pleasant wilderness , ‚Äù [she]154-mrs. temperley observed , looking round . ‚Äú[0-i] Nature is a delightful background , but a poor subject . ‚Äù ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] Do [you]181-professor theobald think so ? [I]0-i often fancy [one]329-one 's general outlook would be nicer , if one had an indistinct human background and a clear foreground of unspoiled Nature . But that may be a jaundiced view . ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria went off to meet [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton , who was coming down [the avenue]945-the avenue with [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald instinctively began to follow and then stopped , reddening , as [he]181-professor theobald met the glance of [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley . [He]181-professor theobald flung [himself]181-professor theobald into conversation with [her]141-miss temperley , and became especially animated when [he]181-professor theobald was passing [Hadria]211-hadria , who did not appear to notice [him]181-professor theobald . As [both Professors]5381-both professors were to leave [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene at the end of the week , this was the last meeting in [the Priory gardens]5796-the priory gardens . [Miss Temperley]141-miss temperley found [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald entertaining , but at times a little incoherent . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] Why , there is [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria ! ‚Äù exclaimed [Henriette]142-henriette . ‚Äú[109-valeria] What [an erratic person]2499-an erratic person [she]109-valeria is . [She]109-valeria went to [London]8-london the day before yesterday , and now [she]109-valeria turns up suddenly without a word of warning . ‚Äù This confirmed [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald 's suspicions that something serious was going on at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [Valeria]109-valeria explained [her]109-valeria return to [Hadria]211-hadria , by saying that [she]109-valeria had felt so nervous about what [the latter]590-the latter might be going to attempt , that [she]109-valeria had come back to see if [she]109-valeria could be of help , or able to ward off any rash adventure . There was a pleasant open space among [the shrubberies]5799-the shrubberies , where several seats had been placed to command a dainty view of [the garden]3867-the garden and lawns , with [the house]296-the house in the distance , and here [the party]428-the party gradually converged , in desultory fashion , coming up and strolling off again , as the fancy inspired [them]428-the party . Cigars were lighted , and a sense of sociability and enjoyment suffused itself , like a perfume , among [the group]941-the group . [She]176-lady engleton did so want to continue the hot discussion [they]2500-they were having at [the Red House]4718-the red house that afternoon , when [Mr. Temperley]118-hubert would be so horridly logical . The conversation became general . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald fell out of it . [He]181-professor theobald was furtively watching [Hadria]211-hadria , whose eyes were strangely bright . [She]211-hadria was sitting on the arm of a seat , listening to the talk , with a little smile on [her]211-hadria lips . [Her]211-hadria hand clasped the back of the seat rigidly , as if [she]211-hadria were holding something down . The qualities and defects of [the female character]5806-the female character were frankly canvassed , each view being held with fervour , but expressed with urbanity . [Women]606-women were always so and so ; [women]606-women were absolutely never so and so : [women]606-women felt , without exception , thus and thus ; on the contrary , [they]606-women were entirely devoid of such sentiments . A large experience and wide observation always supported each opinion , and [eminent authorities]5810-eminent authorities swarmed to the standard . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i do think that [women]606-women want breadth of view , ‚Äù said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú[606-women] [They]606-women sometimes want accuracy of statement , ‚Äù observed [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , with a possible second meaning in [his]181-professor theobald words . ‚Äú[606-women] It seems to [me]0-i [they]606-women lack concentration . Do n't [we]2576-we all know how terrifying a thing speech is , and thought ? [a chartered libertine]2582-a chartered libertine . ‚Äù ‚Äú[2582-a chartered libertine] Why , [you]211-hadria are saying almost exactly what [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald said the other day , and [we]2576-we were so shocked . ‚Äù ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] And yet [my]0-i meaning has scarcely any relation to [his]181-professor theobald , ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria hastened to say . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] [He]181-professor theobald meant to drag down all belief in goodness by reminding [us]2576-we of dark moments and hours ; by placarding the whole soul with the name of some shadow that moves across it , [I]0-i sometimes think from [another world]2583-another world , some deep under - world that yawns beneath [us]2576-we and sends up blackness and fumes and strange cries . ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria 's eyes had wandered far away . ‚Äú[0-i] Are [you]211-hadria never tormented by an idea , an impression that [you]211-hadria know does not belong to [you]211-hadria ? THE speed was glorious . Back flashed [field]5829-field and hill and copse , and the dear ‚Äú[0-i] companionable hedgeways . ‚Äù Back flew iterative telegraph posts with Herculean swing , into the Past , looped together in rhythmic movement , marking the pulses of old Time . On , with rack and roar , into the mysterious Future . [One]329-one could sit at the window and watch the machinery of Time 's foundry at work ; the hammers of [his]329-one forge beating , beating , the wild sparks flying , the din and chaos whirling round one 's bewildered brain;‚ÄîPast becoming Present , Present melting into Future , before [one]329-one 's eyes . Was this the response of [the genius of the ring]5838-the genius of the ring , the magic ring that [we]5839-we call will ? And would [the complaisant genius]5840-the complaisant genius always appear and obey [one]329-one 's behests , in this strange fashion ? Thoughts ran on rhythmically , in the steady , flashing movement through verdant [England]14-england . The Real ! that was the truly exquisite , the truly great , the true realm of the imagination ! What imagination was ever born to conceive or compass it ? A rattle under [a bridge]5842-a bridge , a roar through [a tunnel]5843-a tunnel , and on again , through [Kentish orchards]5844-kentish orchards . A time of blossoming . Disjointed , delicious impressions followed one another in swift succession , often superficially incoherent , but threaded deep , in the stirred consciousness , on a silver cord:‚Äîthe unity of the creation was as obvious as its multiplicity . Images of the Past joined hands with visions of [the Future]48-the future . In [these sweet green meadows]5845-these sweet green meadows , [men]3698-men had toiled , as thralls , but a few lifetimes ago , and [they]3698-men had gathered together , as [Englishmen]5847-englishmen do , first to protest and reasonably demand , and then to buy [their]3698-men freedom with [their]3698-men lives . [The little girl]5857-the little girl stared more fixedly than ever . A smile and the offer of a flower made [her]5857-the little girl look down , for a minute , but the gaze was resumed . Wherefore ? Was the inward tumult too evident in the face ? Well , no matter . [The world]334-the world was beautiful and wide ! [They]5900-they had put scars on [her]211-hadria soul , as deep and ghastly as ever red - hot irons had marked on tortured flesh . Perhaps it was because of this rabid agony undergone , that now [she]211-hadria seemed to have scarcely any clinging to [her]211-hadria home,‚Äîfor the present at any rate . And [she]211-hadria knew that [she]211-hadria left only sorrow for conventional disasters behind [her]211-hadria . The joy of freedom and its intoxication drowned every other feeling . It was sheer relief to be away , to stretch [oneself]5901-oneself in mental liberty and leisure , to look round at earth and sky and [the hurrying crowds]5902-the hurrying crowds , in quiet enjoyment ; to possess [one]329-one 's days , [one]329-one 's existence for the first time , in all these long years ! It was as the home - coming of [a dispossessed heir]5905-a dispossessed heir . This freedom did not strike [her]211-hadria as strange , but as obvious , as familiar . It was the first condition of a life that was worth living . And yet never before had [she]211-hadria known it . [Ernest]86-ernest and [Fred]83-fred and even [Austin]84-austin had enjoyed it from boyhood , and in far greater completeness than [she]211-hadria could ever hope to possess it , even now . Yet even this limited , this comparative freedom , which [a man]3704-a man could afford to smile at , was intoxicating . Heavens ! under what a leaden cloud of little obligations and restraints , and loneliness and pain , [she]211-hadria had been living ! And for what purpose ? To make obeisance to [a phantom public]5907-a phantom public , not because [she]211-hadria cared one iota for the phantom or its opinions , but because [husband]1286-husband and [parents]620-parents and [relations]5910-relations were terrified at the prospect of a few critical and disapproving remarks , that [they]5907-a phantom public would not even hear ! How mad it all was ! [Hadria]211-hadria greeted [it]5993-it with a feeling of gratitude . [The great Boulevard]58-the great boulevard was ablaze and swarming with life . [The caf√©s]5994-the caf√©s were full ; the gilt and mirrors and the crowds of consommateurs within , all visible as [one]329-one passed along [the street]5996-the street , while , under the awning outside , [crowds]5997-crowds were sitting smoking , drinking , reading the papers . [The cabman]6000-the cabman directed [[his]6000-the cabman vehicle]6001-his vehicle down [the Rue Royale]6002-the rue royale , passing [the stately Madeleine]6003-the stately madeleine , with [its]6003-the stately madeleine guardian sycamores , and out into [the windy spaciousness of [the Place de la Concorde]6005-the place de la concorde]6004-the windy spaciousness of the place de la concorde . The festooned lights of [the Champs Elys√©es]6007-the champs elys√©es swung themselves up , in narrowing line , till [they]5997-crowds reached the pompous arch at the summit , and among the rich trees of [those Elysian fields]6008-those elysian fields gleamed the festive lamps of caf√©s chantants . ‚Äú[2607-a remembrancer] Si Madame desire encore quelque chose ? ‚Äù [The neat maid , in picturesque white cap and apron]6009-the neat maid , in picturesque white cap and apron , stood with [her]6009-the neat maid , in picturesque white cap and apron hand on the door of [the little bedroom]6010-the little bedroom , on [one of the highest storeys of [the pension]6012-the pension]6011-one of the highest storeys of the pension . Half of one of the long windows had been set open , and the sounds of the rolling of vehicles over [the smooth asphalte]6013-the smooth asphalte , mingled with those of voices , were coming up , straight and importunate , into [the dainty bedroom]6014-the dainty bedroom . The very sounds seemed nearer and clearer in [this keen - edged land]6015-this keen - edged land . The bed stood in one corner , canopied with white and blue ; a thick carpet gave a sense of luxury and deadened the tramp of footsteps ; a marble mantel - piece was surmounted by a mirror , and supported a handsome bronze clock and two bronze ornaments . The furniture was of solid mahogany . A nameless French odour pervaded the atmosphere , delicate , subtle , but unmistakeable . And out of the open window , one could see a series of other lighted windows , all of exactly the same tall graceful design , opening in the middle by the same device and the same metal handle that had to be turned in order to open or close the window . Within , [the rooms]6016-the rooms obviously modelled [themselves]6016-the rooms on the one unvarying ideal . [A few figures]6017-a few figures could be seen coming and going , busy at work or play . Above the steep roofs , a blue - black sky was alive with brilliant stars . ‚Äú[2607-a remembrancer] Merci ; ‚Äù [Madame]195-madame bertaux required nothing more . JUST at first , it was a sheer impossibility to do anything but bask and bathe in the sunny present , to spend the days in wandering incredulously through vernal [Paris]35-paris , over whose bursting freshness and brilliancy the white clouds seemed to be driven , with the same joy of life . [The city]4963-the city was crammed ; [the inhabitants]916-the inhabitants poured forth in swarms to enjoy , in true French fashion , the genial warmth and the universal awakening after the long capricious winter . It was actually hot in the sun , and fresh light clothing became a luxury , like a bath after a journey . The year had raised its siege , and there was sudden amity between [man]332-man and [Nature]120-nature . [Shrivelled man]6021-shrivelled man could relax the tension of resistance to cold and damp and change , and go forth into the sun with cordial insouciance . In many of the faces might be read this kindly amnesty , although there were some so set and fixed with past cares that not even the soft hand of a Parisian spring could smooth away the lines , or even touch the spirit . [These Hadria]211-hadria passed with an aching pity . [Circumstance]106-circumstance had been to [them]6017-a few figures [a relentless taskmaster]6022-a relentless taskmaster . Perhaps [they]6017-a few figures had not rubbed the magic ring of will , and summoned [the obedient genius]6023-the obedient genius . Perhaps circumstance had forbidden [them]6017-a few figures even the rag wherewith to rub ‚Äî or the impulse . Sallying forth from the pension , [Hadria]211-hadria would sometimes pause , for a moment , at the corner of [the street]5996-the street , where [it]5996-the street opened into [the Place de la Concorde]6005-the place de la concorde , irresolute , because of the endless variety of possible ways to turn , and [places to visit]6026-places to visit . [She]211-hadria seldom made definite plans the day before , unless it were for the pleasure of changing them . The letter of introduction to [Madame Vauchelet]232-madame vauchelet had remained unpresented . The sense of solitude , combined for the first time with that of freedom , was too delightful to forego . [One]329-one must have time to realize and appreciate the sudden calm and serenity ; the sudden absence of claims and obstructions and harassing criticisms . Heavens , what a price [people]3687-people consented to pay for the privilege of human ties ! what hard bargains were driven in the kingdom of the affections ! [Society]367-society bristled with insults , conscious and unconscious . Nor had [one]329-one lived the brightest , sweetest years of [one]329-one 's life tethered and impounded , without feeling the consequences when the tether was cut . There were dreads , shrinkings , bewilderments , confusions to encounter ; the difficulties of pilotage in [unknown seas]6037-unknown seas , of self - knowledge , and guidance suddenly needed in new ranges of the soul ; fresh temptations , fresh possibilities to deal with ; everything untested , the alphabet of worldly experience yet to learn . But all this was felt with infinitely greater force a little later , when the period of solitude was over , and [Hadria]211-hadria found [herself]211-hadria in the midst of [a little society whose real codes and ideas [she]211-hadria had gropingly to learn]6038-a little society whose real codes and ideas she had gropingly to learn . [Her]211-hadria sentiment had never been narrowly British , but now [she]211-hadria realized [her]211-hadria nationality over - keenly ; [she]211-hadria felt [herself]211-hadria almost grotesquely English , and had a sense of insular clumsiness amidst [a uprightly , dexterous people]6041-a uprightly , dexterous people . [She]211-hadria began to be painfully conscious of the effects of the narrow life that [she]211-hadria had led , and of the limitations that had crippled [her]211-hadria in a thousand ways hitherto scarcely realized . ‚Äú[329-one] [One]329-one begins to learn everything too late , ‚Äù [she]211-hadria wrote to [Algitha]81-algitha . ‚Äú[329-one] This ought all to have been familiar long ago . Why should [a woman]3753-a woman treat [herself]3753-a woman as if [she]3753-a woman were [Dresden china]243-dresden china ? [She]3753-a woman is more or less insulted and degraded whatever happens , especially if [she]3753-a woman obeys what [[our]2614-our generation]2615-our generation is pleased to call the moral law . It is an added mockery , a gratuitous piece of insolence . ‚Äù Having been , from childhood , more or less at issue with [her]3753-a woman surroundings , [Hadria]211-hadria had never fully realized [their]6043-their power upon [her]3753-a woman personality . But now daily a fresh recognition of [her]3753-a woman continued imprisonment , baffled [her]3753-a woman attempt to look at things with clear eyes . [She]3753-a woman struggled to get round and beyond that past - fashioned self , not merely in order to see truly , but in order to see at all . And in doing so , [she]3753-a woman ran the risk of letting go what [she]3753-a woman might have done better to hold . [She]3753-a woman felt painfully different from [these people among whom [she]3753-a woman found [herself]3753-a woman]6044-these people among whom she found herself . [Her]3753-a woman very trick of pondering over things sent [her]3753-a woman spinning to hopeless distances . [They]6043-their seemed to ponder so wholesomely little . [Their]6043-their intelligence was devoted to matters of the moment ; [they]6043-their were keen and well - finished and accomplished . [Hadria]211-hadria used to look at [them]6043-their in astonishment . How did [these quick - witted people]6045-these quick - witted people manage to escape the importunate inquisitive demon , the familiar spirit , who pursued [her]3753-a woman incessantly with [his]3753-a woman queries and suggestions ? [He]3753-a woman would stare up from [river]6046-river and [street]6047-street and [merry gardens]6048-merry gardens ; [his]3753-a woman haunting eyes looked mockingly out of green realms of stirring foliage , and [his]3753-a woman voice was like a sardonic echo to the happy voices of [the children]667-the children , laughing at [their]667-the children play under the flickering shadows , of [mothers]865-mothers discussing [their]865-mothers cares and interests , of [men in blouses]6051-men in blouses , at work by [the water - side]6052-the water - side , or solemn , in frock - coats , with pre - occupations of business and bread - winning . [The demon]6053-the demon had [his]6053-the demon own reflections on all these seemingly ordinary matters , and so bizarre were they at times , so startling and often so terrible , that [one]329-one found [oneself]329-one shivering in full noontide , or smiling , or thrilled with passionate pity at ‚Äú[3698-men] the sad , strange ways of [men]3698-men . ‚Äù It was sweet to stretch one 's cramped wings to the sun , to ruffle and spread them , as a released bird will , but it was startling to find already little stiff habits arisen , little creaks and hindrances never suspected , that made flight in the high air not quite effortless and serene . The Past is never past ; immortal as [the Gods]812-the gods , it lives enthroned in [the Present]59-the present , and sets its limits and lays its commands . Cases have been known of [a man blind from birth]6056-a man blind from birth being restored to sight , at mature age . For a time , the appearance of objects was strange and incomprehensible . [Their]6057-their full meaning was not conveyed to [him]3753-a woman ; they remained riddles . [He]3753-a woman could not judge the difference between near and far , between solid and liquid ; [he]3753-a woman had no experience , dating from childhood , of the apparent smallness of distant things , of the connexion between the impression given to the touch by solids and their effect on the eye . [He]3753-a woman had all these things to learn . A thousand trifling associations , of which [those with normal senses are scarcely conscious]6058-those with normal senses are scarcely conscious , had to be stumblingly acquired , as [a child]754-a child learns to connect sound and sight , in learning to read . Such were the changes of consciousness that [Hadria]211-hadria found [herself]211-hadria going through ; only realising each phase of the process after it was over , and the previous confusion of vision had been itself revealed , by the newly and often painfully acquired coordinating skill . But , as generally happens , in the course of passing from ignorance to knowledge , the intermediate stage was chaotic . Objects loomed up large and indistinct , as through a mist ; vague forms drifted by , half revealed , to melt away again ; here and there were clear outlines and solid impressions , to be deemed trustworthy and given a place of honour ; thence a disproportion in the general conception ; it being almost beyond human power to allow sufficiently for that which is unknown . For some time , however , the dominant impression on [Hadria]211-hadria 's mind was of [her]211-hadria own gigantic ignorance . This ignorance was far more confusing and even misleading than it had been when its proportions were less defined . The faint twinkle of light revealed the dusky outline , bewildering and discouraging the imagination . Intuitive knowledge was disturbed by the incursion of scraps of disconnected experience . This condition of mind made [her]211-hadria an almost insoluble pyschological problem . Since [she]211-hadria was evidently [a woman of pronounced character]6060-a woman of pronounced character , [her]211-hadria bewilderment and tentitive attitude were not allowed for . [Her]211-hadria actions were regarded as deliberate and cool - headed , when often they would be the outcome of sheer confusion , or chance , or perhaps of a groping experimental effort . The first three weeks in [Paris]35-paris had been given up to enjoying the new conditions of existence . But now practical matters claimed consideration . The pension in [the Rue Boissy d'Anglas]5987-the rue boissy d'anglas was not suitable as [a permanent abode]6062-a permanent abode . [Rooms]6063-rooms must be looked for , combining cheapness with a good situation , within easy distance of the scene of [Hadria]211-hadria 's future musical studies , and also within reach of [some park]6064-some park or [gardens]2029-gardens for [Martha]129-martha 's benefit . [This ideal place of abode]6066-this ideal place of abode was at last found . [Two great thoroughfares]6071-two great thoroughfares ran , at a respectful distance , on either side , with [omnibuses]6072-omnibuses always passing . Even [Hannah]212-hannah thought the situation might do . [Hadria]211-hadria had begun [her]211-hadria studies at [the School of Music]6073-the school of music , and found the steady work not only a profound , though somewhat stern enjoyment , but a solid backbone to [her]211-hadria new existence , giving it cohesion and form . [Recreation]244-recreation deserved its name , after work of this kind . Any lurking danger of too great speculative restlessness disappeared . There had been a moment when the luxurious joy of mere wandering observation and absorption , threatened to become overwhelming , and to loosen some of the rivets of the character . But work was to the sum - total of impulse what the central weight was to one of [Martha]129-martha 's toys : a leaden ballast that always brought the balance right again , however wildly [the little tyrant]6080-the little tyrant might swing the creature off the perpendicular . When [Hadria]211-hadria used to come in , pleasantly tired with [her]211-hadria morning 's occupation , and the wholesome heat of the sun , to take [her]211-hadria simple d√©jeuner in [the little apartment]6081-the little apartment with [Martha]129-martha , a frivolous five minutes would often be spent by [the two]4880-the two in endeavouring to overcome the rigid principles of that well - balanced plaything . About three weeks passed in almost pure enjoyment and peace ; and then it was discovered that the cost of living , in spite of an extremely simple diet , was such as might have provided epicurean luxuries for [a family of ten]6084-a family of ten . [Hadria]211-hadria was brimming over with pleasure in [[her]211-hadria new home]6110-her new home , which breathed [Paris]35-paris from every pore . [She]211-hadria had already surrounded [herself]211-hadria with odds and ends of [her]211-hadria own , with books and a few flowers . If only this venture turned out well , how delightful would be the next few months . [Hadria]211-hadria did not clearly look beyond that time . To [her]211-hadria , it seemed like a century . [Her]211-hadria only idea as to the farther future was an abstract resolve to let nothing short of absolute compulsion persuade [her]211-hadria to renounce [her]211-hadria freedom , or subject [herself]211-hadria to conditions that made the pursuit of [her]211-hadria art impossible . How to carry out the resolve , in fact and detail , was a matter to consider when the time came . If one were to consider future difficulties as well as deal with immediate ones , into what crannies and interstices were the affairs of the moment to be crammed ? There has probably never been a human experience of even a few months of perfect happiness , of perfect satisfaction with conditions , even among [the few men and women who know how to appreciate the bounty of Fate]6111-the few men and women who know how to appreciate the bounty of fate , when [she]211-hadria is generous , and to take the sting out of minor annoyances by treating [them]6111-the few men and women who know how to appreciate the bounty of fate lightly . [Henriette]142-henriette wrote that [she]142-henriette was really annoyed at the way in which [everybody]3781-everybody was talking about [Hadria]211-hadria 's conduct . It was most uncomfortable . [She]176-lady engleton hated to make [herself]176-lady engleton conspicuous ; the very ideal of [a true lady]6123-a true lady , if one might use the much - abused word . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue was reported to be still far from well . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had not taken [the Priory]31-the priory after all . [It]31-the priory was too large . It looked so deserted and melancholy now . [Henriette]142-henriette always finished [her]142-henriette letters with an entreaty to [Hadria]211-hadria to return . [People]3687-people were talking so . [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux , who had just returned from [England]14-england to [[her]195-madame bertaux beloved [Paris]35-paris]6126-her beloved paris , reported to [Hadria]211-hadria , when [she]195-madame bertaux called on [the latter]590-the latter in [[her]195-madame bertaux new abode]6128-her new abode , that [everyone]3726-everyone was talking about the affair with as much eagerness as if the fate of [the empire]6130-the empire had depended on it . THE new m√©nage went well . [Ther√®se]246-ther√®se was a treasure , and [[Martha]129-martha 's willing slave]6136-martha 's willing slave . Expenses were kept fairly reasonable by [her]211-hadria care and knowledge . Still it must not be forgotten that the little income needed supplementing . [Hadria]211-hadria had been aware of this risk from the first , but had faced it , regarding it as the less perilous of the alternatives that [she]211-hadria had to choose between . The income was small , but it was [her]211-hadria own absolutely , and [she]211-hadria must live on that , with such auxiliary sums as [she]211-hadria could earn . [She]211-hadria hoped to be able to make a little money by [her]211-hadria compositions . The future was all vague and unknown , but one thing was at least certain : it cost money to live , and in some way or other it had to be made . The character of the music , always individual , had grown more marked , and at this point an effect was produced which appeared to startle [the musician]6156-the musician . [Nature]120-nature scattered [her]120-nature gifts wildly and cruelly : cruelly , because [she]120-nature cared not into what cramped nooks and crannies [she]120-nature poured [her]120-nature maddening explosive : cruelly , because [she]120-nature hurled this fire from [heaven]4276-heaven with indiscriminate hand , to set alight one dared not guess how many chained martyrs at [their]6161-their stakes . Nature did not pick and choose the subjects of [her]120-nature wilful ministrations . [She]120-nature seemed to scatter at random , out of sheer gaiet√© de coeur , as [Jouffroy]248-jouffroy had said , and if some golden grain chanced to be gleaming in this soul or that , what cause for astonishment ? The rest might be the worst of dross . As well might the chance occur to [one of [Nature]120-nature 's children]6162-one of nature 's children as to another . [She]120-nature did not bestow even one golden grain for nothing , bien s√ªr ; [she]120-nature meant to be paid back with interest . Just one bright bead of the whole vast circlet of the truth : perhaps it was [hers]120-nature , but more likely that [these kind friends]6163-these kind friends had been misled by [their]6163-these kind friends sympathy . [M. Jouffroy]248-jouffroy came next day to have a long talk with [Hadria]211-hadria about [her]120-nature work and [her]120-nature methods . [He]248-jouffroy was absolutely confident of what [he]248-jouffroy had said , but [he]248-jouffroy was emphatic regarding the necessity for work ; steady , uninterrupted work . Everything must be subservient to the one aim . If [she]120-nature contemplated anything short of complete dedication to [her]120-nature art ‚Äî well ( [he]248-jouffroy shrugged [his]248-jouffroy shoulders ) , it would be better to amuse [herself]120-nature . There could be no half - measures with art . True , there were thousands of [people who practised a little of this and a little of that]6164-people who practised a little of this and a little of that , but [Art]253-art would endure no such disrespect . It was the affair of a lifetime . [He]248-jouffroy had known [many women with great talent]6165-many women with great talent , but , alas ! H√©las ! how many brilliant careers had [he]248-jouffroy not seen ruined by this fatal instinct !
