[Marion]273-marion fenwick had lost [her]273-marion fenwick freshness and [her]273-marion fenwick exquisite √¶therial quality ; otherwise there was little change in [her]273-marion fenwick appearance . [Hadria]211-hadria was struck by the way in which [she]211-hadria had looked at [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux , and it occurred to [her]211-hadria that [Marion Fenwick]273-marion fenwick was probably not quite so acquiescent and satisfied as [[her]211-hadria friends]4444-her friends supposed . But [she]211-hadria would not speak out . Early training had been too strong for [her]211-hadria . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald was unusually serious to - night . [He]181-professor theobald did not respond to [Hadria]211-hadria 's flippancy . [He]181-professor theobald looked at [her]211-hadria with grave , sympathetic eyes . [He]181-professor theobald seemed to intimate that [he]181-professor theobald understood all that was passing in [her]211-hadria mind , and was not balked by sprightly appearances . There was no sign of cynicism now , no bandying of compliments . [His]181-professor theobald voice had a new ring of sincerity . It was a mood that [Hadria]211-hadria had noticed in [him]181-professor theobald once or twice before , and when it occurred , [her]211-hadria sympathy was aroused ; [she]211-hadria felt that [she]211-hadria had done [him]181-professor theobald injustice . This was evidently [the real man]6703-the real man ; [his]181-professor theobald ordinary manner must be merely the cloak that [the civilized being]6704-the civilized being acquires the habit of wrapping round [him]181-professor theobald , as a protection against the curiosity of [[his]181-professor theobald fellows]951-his fellows . [The Professor]4071-the professor [himself]4071-the professor expressed it almost in those words : ‚Äú[2952-my dear madam] It is because of the infinite variety of type and the complexity of modern life which [the individual]4889-the individual is called upon to encounter , that a sort of fancy dress has to be worn by all of [us]2959-we , as a necessary shield to [our]2959-we individuality and [our]2959-we privacy . [We]2959-we can not go through the complex process of adjustment to each new type that [we]2959-we come across , so by common consent , [we]2959-we wear [our]2959-we domino , and respect the unwritten laws of the great bal masqu√© that [we]2959-we call [society]367-society . ‚Äù The conversation took more and more intimate and serious turns . [Mrs. Jordan]179-mrs. jordan was the only check upon it . [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux followed up [her]195-madame bertaux first heresy by [others]432-others even more bold . ‚Äú[329-one] Whenever one wants very particularly to have [one]329-one 's way about a matter , ‚Äù [she]195-madame bertaux said , ‚Äú[329-one] [one]329-one sneaks off and gets [somebody else]6262-somebody else persuaded that it is [his]6262-somebody else duty to sacrifice [himself]6262-somebody else for [us]2959-we ‚Äî c'est tout simple ‚Äî and the chances are that [he]6262-somebody else meekly does it . [The Professor]4071-the professor was to [Hadria]211-hadria by far [the most entertaining person of the party]6717-the most entertaining person of the party . [He]4071-the professor had always amused [her]211-hadria , and even the first time [she]211-hadria saw [him]4071-the professor , [he]4071-the professor had exercised a strange , unpleasant fascination over [her]211-hadria , which had put [her]211-hadria on the defensive , for [she]211-hadria had disliked and distrusted [him]4071-the professor . The meetings in [the Priory gardens]5796-the priory gardens had softened [her]211-hadria hostility , and now [she]211-hadria began to feel more and more that [she]211-hadria had judged [him]4071-the professor unfairly . In those days [she]211-hadria had a strong pre - occupying interest . [He]4071-the professor had arrived on the scene at an exciting moment , just when [she]211-hadria was planning out [her]211-hadria flight to [Paris]35-paris . [She]211-hadria had not considered [the Professor]4071-the professor 's character very deeply . There were far too many other things to think of . It was simpler to avoid [him]4071-the professor . But now everything had changed . The present moment was not exciting ; [she]211-hadria had no plans and projects in [her]211-hadria head ; [she]211-hadria was not about to court the fate of [Icarus]274-icarus . That fate had already overtaken [her]211-hadria . The waves were closing over - head ; [her]211-hadria wings were wet and crippled , in the blue depths . Why not take what [the gods]812-the gods had sent and make the most of it ? [The Professor]4071-the professor had all sorts of strange lore , which [he]4071-the professor used , in [his]4071-the professor conversations with [Hadria]211-hadria , almost as [a fisherman]6722-a fisherman uses [his]6722-a fisherman bait . If [she]211-hadria shewed an inclination to re - join the rest of [the party]428-the party , [he]4071-the professor always brought out some fresh titbit of curious learning , and [Hadria]211-hadria was seldom able to resist the lure . [They]6724-they met often , almost of necessity . It was impossible to feel a stranger to [the Professor]4071-the professor , in these circumstances of frequent and informal meeting . Often when [Hadria]211-hadria happened to be alone with [him]4071-the professor , [she]211-hadria would become suddenly silent , as if [she]211-hadria no longer felt the necessity to talk or to conceal [her]211-hadria weariness . [The Professor]4071-the professor knew it too well ; [he]4071-the professor saw how heavily the burden of life weighed upon [her]211-hadria , and how it was often almost more than [she]211-hadria could do , to drag through the day . [She]211-hadria craved for excitement , no matter of what kind , in order to help [her]211-hadria to forget [her]211-hadria weariness . [Her]211-hadria anxiety about [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue preyed upon [her]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria was restless , overwrought , with every nerve on edge , unable now for consecutive work , even had events permitted it . [She]211-hadria was sitting on a little knoll , [her]211-hadria arm resting on [her]211-hadria knee , and [her]211-hadria cheek in [her]211-hadria hand . It seemed as if [she]211-hadria had grown tired of guiding and directing [herself]211-hadria , and were now commending [herself]211-hadria to fate or fortune , to do with [her]211-hadria as [they]6745-they would , or must . [Marion]273-marion fenwick struck a quiet chord . [Her]273-marion fenwick voice was sweet and tender and full , admirably suited to the song . [They]428-the party were to amuse [themselves]428-the party as [they]428-the party pleased during the afternoon , and to meet on the same spot for five o'clock tea . ‚Äú[275-mrs. fenwick] [I]0-i wish [Hadria]211-hadria would not be so reckless ! ‚Äù cried [Algitha]81-algitha anxiously . ‚Äú[211-hadria] Have [you]0-i seen [her]211-hadria lately ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] When last [I]0-i saw [her]211-hadria , ‚Äù said [Valeria]109-valeria , ‚Äú[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria had strolled off with [the Professor]4071-the professor and [Mr. Moreton]276-mr. moreton . In [my]0-i opinion , [she]211-hadria is acting very wrongly . ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] ‚Äò [He]3022-he that has eaten [his]3022-he fill does not pity the hungry , ‚Äô as the Eastern proverb puts it . Do n't [you]81-algitha think [you]81-algitha too might be tempted to try experiments with a power whose strength [you]81-algitha had found to be almost irresistible ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[81-algitha] Perhaps [I]0-i should , ‚Äù [Algitha]81-algitha admitted . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i do n't say [she]211-hadria is doing right , but [you]81-algitha must remember that [you]81-algitha have not the temperament that prompts to these outbursts . [I]0-i suppose that is only to say that [you]81-algitha are better than [Hadria]211-hadria , by nature . [I]0-i think perhaps [you]81-algitha are , but remember [you]81-algitha have had the life and the work that [you]81-algitha chose above all others ‚Äî [she]211-hadria has not . ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] Heaven knows [I]0-i do n't set [myself]0-i above [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äù cried [Algitha]81-algitha . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i have always looked up to [her]211-hadria . Do n't [you]81-algitha know how painful it is when [people]3687-people [you]81-algitha respect do things beneath [them]3687-people ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[81-algitha] [Hadria]211-hadria will disappoint [us]3024-us all in some particular , ‚Äù said [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [She]211-hadria will not correspond exactly to [anybody]3977-anybody 's theory or standard , not even [her]211-hadria own . It is a defect which gives [her]211-hadria character a quality of the unexpected , that has for [me]0-i , infinite attraction . ‚Äù [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria had never shewn so much disposition to support [Hadria]211-hadria 's conduct as now , when disapproval was general . [She]109-valeria had a strong fellow - feeling for [a woman who desired to use [her]6748-a woman who desired to use her power power]6748-a woman who desired to use her power , and [she]109-valeria was half disposed to regard [her]6748-a woman who desired to use her power conduct as legitimate . At any rate , it was a temptation almost beyond one 's powers of resistance . If [a woman]3753-a woman might not do this , what , in heaven 's name , might [she]3753-a woman do ? Was [she]3753-a woman not eternally referred to [[her]3753-a woman woman]3014-her woman 's influence , [[her]3753-a woman woman]3014-her woman 's kingdom ? Surely a day 's somewhat murderous sport was allowable in [that realm]6752-that realm ! After all , energy , ambition , nervous force , must have an outlet somewhere . [Men]3698-men could look after [themselves]3698-men . [They]3698-men had no mercy on [women]606-women when [they]3698-men lay in [their]3698-men power . Why should [a woman]3753-a woman be so punctilious ? ‚Äú[3754-the man] Only [the man]3754-the man is sure to get the best of it , ‚Äù [she]3753-a woman added , bitterly . ‚Äú[3754-the man] [He]3754-the man loses so little . It is a game where the odds are all on one side , and the conclusion foregone . ‚Äù Unexpectedly , the underwood behind the speakers was brushed aside and [Hadria]211-hadria appeared before [them]3028-we . [She]211-hadria looked perturbed . ‚Äú[3754-the man] What is it ? [You]211-hadria have tested [your]211-hadria power sufficiently . What more do [you]211-hadria want ? [Claude Moreton]178-claude moreton is too nice and too good [a man]3704-a man to trifle with . As [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria says , ‚Äò It is always [the good men whom [one wounds]3044-one wounds]3043-the good men whom one wounds ; the others wound [us]3045-us . ‚Äô ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria was silent . ‚Äú[109-valeria] And [Claude Moreton]178-claude moreton , ‚Äù continued [Algitha]81-algitha presently . ‚Äú[178-claude moreton] [He]178-claude moreton is far too deeply interested in [you]211-hadria , far too absorbed in what [you]211-hadria say and do . [I]0-i have watched [him]178-claude moreton . It is cruel . ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria grew fierce . ‚Äú[178-claude moreton] Has [he]178-claude moreton never cruelly injured [a woman]3753-a woman ? Has [he]178-claude moreton not at least given moral support to the hideous indignities that [all womanhood]3047-all womanhood has to endure at [men]3698-men 's hands ? At best one can make [a man]3704-a man suffer . But [men]3698-men also humiliate [us]3045-us , degrade [us]3045-us , jeer at , ridicule the miseries that [they]3698-men and [their]3698-men society entail upon [us]3045-us . Yet for sooth , [they]3698-men must be spared the discomfort of becoming a little infatuated with [a woman]3753-a woman for a time ‚Äî a short time , at worst ! [Their]3698-men feelings must be considered so tenderly ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[3698-men] But what good do [you]211-hadria do by [your]211-hadria present conduct ? ‚Äù asked [Algitha]81-algitha , sticking persistently to the practical side of the matter . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i am not trying to do good . [I]0-i am merely refusing to obey these rules for [our]3045-us guidance , which are obviously drawn up to safeguard [man]332-man 's property and privilege . Whenever [I]0-i can find [a man - made precept]3053-a man - made precept , that will [I]0-i carefully disobey ; whenever [the ruling powers]3054-the ruling powers seek to guide [me]0-i through [my]0-i conscience , there shall [they]3054-the ruling powers fail ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria forget that in playing with the feelings of [others]432-others [you]211-hadria are placing [yourself]211-hadria in danger , [Hadria]211-hadria . How can [you]211-hadria be sure that [you]211-hadria wo n't [yourself]211-hadria fall desperately in love with [one of [[your]211-hadria intended victims]3057-your intended victims]3056-one of your intended victims ? ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria 's eyes sparkled . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i wish to heaven [I]0-i only could ! ‚Äù [she]211-hadria exclaimed . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i would give [my]0-i right hand to be in the sway of a complete undoubting , unquestioning passion that would make all suffering and all life seem worth while ; some emotion to take the place of [my]0-i lost art , some full and satisfying sense of union with [a human soul]2092-a human soul to rescue [one]329-one from the ghastly solitude of life . But [I]0-i am raving like [a girl]3734-a girl . [I]0-i am crying for the moon . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] Ah , take care , take care , [Hadria]211-hadria ; that is a mood in which one may mistake [any twopenny - halfpenny little luminary]3061-any twopenny - halfpenny little luminary for the impossible moon . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i should be almost ready to bless the beautiful illusion , ‚Äù cried [Hadria]211-hadria passionately . IN the conversation with [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister , the name which [Hadria]211-hadria had dreaded to hear had not been mentioned . [She]211-hadria felt as if [she]211-hadria could not have met [[her]211-hadria sister]313-her sister 's eyes , at that moment , had [she]211-hadria alluded to [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald ; for only five minutes before , in the wood , [he]181-professor theobald had spoken to [her]211-hadria in a way that was scarcely possible to misunderstand , though [his]181-professor theobald wording was so cautious that [she]211-hadria could not have taken offence , had [she]211-hadria been so minded , without drawing upon [herself]211-hadria the possible retort . ‚Äú[0-i] [[My]0-i dear lady]3062-my dear lady , [you]3062-my dear lady have completely misunderstood [me]0-i . ‚Äù The thought made [her]211-hadria flush painfully . But suppose [he]181-professor theobald really had meant what [his]181-professor theobald words seemed to imply ? [He]181-professor theobald could intend no insult , because [he]181-professor theobald despised , and knew that [she]211-hadria despised , popular social creeds . Into what new realms was [she]211-hadria drifting ? There was something attractive to [Hadria]211-hadria , in the idea of defying [the world]334-the world 's laws . It was not as the dutiful property of another , but as [herself]211-hadria , [a separate and responsible individual]6761-a separate and responsible individual , that [she]211-hadria would act and feel , rightly or wrongly , as the case might be . That was a matter between [herself]211-hadria and [her]211-hadria conscience , not between [herself]211-hadria and [the world]334-the world or [[her]211-hadria legal owner]6677-her legal owner . [The Professor]4071-the professor 's ambiguous and yet startling speech had forced [her]211-hadria to consider [her]211-hadria position . [She]211-hadria remembered how [her]211-hadria instinct had always been to hold [him]181-professor theobald aloof from [her]211-hadria life , just because , as [she]211-hadria now began to believe , there was something in [him]181-professor theobald that powerfully attracted [her]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria had feared an attraction that appeared unjustified by [the man]3754-the man 's character . But now the fascination had begun to take a stronger grip , as the pre - occupying ideas of [her]211-hadria life had been chased from their places . It had insensibly crept in to fill the empty throne . So long as [she]211-hadria had cherished hope , so long as [she]211-hadria was still struggling , this insidious half - magnetic influence had been easily resisted . Now , [she]211-hadria was set adrift ; [her]211-hadria anchor was raised ; [she]211-hadria lay at the wind 's mercy , half - conscious of the peril and not caring . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had an acute perception of the strange and confused struggle that was going on in [her]211-hadria mind . But [he]181-professor theobald had no notion of the peculiar reasons , in [her]211-hadria case , for an effect that [he]181-professor theobald knew to be far from rare among [women]606-women ; [he]181-professor theobald did not understand the angry , corroding action of a strong artistic impulse that was incessantly baulked in full tide . The sinister , menacing voices of that tide had no meaning for [him]181-professor theobald , except as expressing a malaise which [he]181-professor theobald had met with a hundred times before . [He]181-professor theobald put it down to an excess of emotional or nervous energy , in a nature whose opportunities did not offer full scope to its powers . [He]181-professor theobald had grasped the general conditions , but [he]181-professor theobald had not perceived the particular fact that added tenfold to the evil which exists in the more usual , and less complicated case . [He]181-professor theobald thought but little of a musical gift , having no sympathy with music ; and since [he]181-professor theobald had never known what it was to receive anything but help and encouragement in the exercise of [his]181-professor theobald own talents , the effect upon the mind and character of such an experience as [Hadria]211-hadria 's , was beyond the range of [his]181-professor theobald conceptions . [He]181-professor theobald understood subtly , and misunderstood completely , at one and the same time . But to [Hadria]211-hadria , every syllable which revealed how much [he]181-professor theobald did understand , seemed to prove , by implication , that [he]181-professor theobald understood the whole . It never occurred to [her]211-hadria that [he]181-professor theobald was blinder than [Henriette]142-henriette [herself]142-henriette , to the real centre and heart of the difficulty . It has been said that what [the human being]5264-the human being longs for above all things , is to be understood : that [he]181-professor theobald prefers it infinitely to being over - rated . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald gave [Hadria]211-hadria this desired sensation . [His]181-professor theobald attraction for [her]211-hadria was composed of many elements , and it was enhanced by the fact that [she]211-hadria had now grown so used to [his]181-professor theobald presence , as to cease to notice many little traits that had repelled [her]211-hadria , at the beginning . [Her]211-hadria critical instincts were lulled . Thus had come to pass that which is by no means an uncommon incident in human history : a toleration for and finally a strong attraction towards [a nature that began by creating distrust , and even dislike]6768-a nature that began by creating distrust , and even dislike . [Hadria]211-hadria 's instinct now was to hunt up reasons for desiring the society of [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , for the gladness that [she]211-hadria felt at the prospect of seeing [him]181-professor theobald . [She]211-hadria wished to explain to [herself]211-hadria how it was that [he]181-professor theobald had become so prominent a figure in [her]211-hadria life . It was surprising how rapidly and how completely [he]181-professor theobald had taken a central position . [Her]211-hadria feeling towards [him]181-professor theobald , and [her]211-hadria admiring affection for [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue , were as different as night from day . [She]211-hadria shrank from comparing the two emotions , because at the bottom of [her]211-hadria heart , [she]211-hadria felt how infinitely less fine and sound was this latter attachment , how infinitely less to be welcomed . If [any one]2075-any one spoke disparagingly of [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald , [Hadria]211-hadria 's instinct was to stand up for [him]181-professor theobald , to find ingenious reasons for [his]181-professor theobald words or [his]181-professor theobald conduct that threw upon [him]181-professor theobald the most favourable light , and [her]211-hadria object was as much to persuade [herself]211-hadria as to convince [[her]211-hadria interlocutor]6770-her interlocutor . What [the Professor]4071-the professor had said this afternoon , had brought [her]211-hadria to a point whence [she]211-hadria had to review all these changes and developments of [her]211-hadria feeling . [She]211-hadria puzzled [herself]211-hadria profoundly . In remembering those few words , [she]211-hadria was conscious of a little thrill of ‚Äî not joy ( the word was too strong ) , but of something akin to it . [She]211-hadria thought ‚Äî and then laughed at [herself]211-hadria ‚Äî that it had a resemblance to the sensation that is caused to the mind by the suggestion of some new and entrancingly interesting idea ‚Äî say about astronomy ! And if [she]211-hadria consulted [her]211-hadria mere wishes in the matter , apart from all other considerations , [she]211-hadria would explore farther in this direction . Whether curiosity or sentiment actuated [her]211-hadria , [she]211-hadria could not detect . It would certainly be deeply exciting to find out what [her]211-hadria own nature really was , and still more so to gain greater insight into [his]181-professor theobald . Was this heartless , cold - blooded ? Or was it that [she]211-hadria felt a lurking capacity for a feeling stronger than ‚Äî or at any rate different from ‚Äî any that [she]211-hadria had hitherto felt ? This was a secret that [she]211-hadria could not discover . [Hadria]211-hadria gave a frightened start . Was [she]211-hadria finding [herself]211-hadria to be bad in a way that [she]211-hadria had never suspected ? If [she]211-hadria could but fully and completely escape from tradition , so that [her]211-hadria judgment might be quite unhampered . Tradition seemed either to make [human beings]4313-human beings blindly submissive , or to tempt [them]4313-human beings to act out of an equally blind opposition to its canons . [One]329-one could never be entirely independent . In [her]211-hadria confusion , [she]211-hadria longed to turn to some clear mind and sound conscience , not so much for advice , as in order to test the effect upon such a mind and conscience of the whole situation . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue was [the only person upon whose judgment and feeling]6774-the only person upon whose judgment and feeling [she]211-hadria could absolutely rely . What would [he]116-professor fortescue think of [her]211-hadria ? [His]116-professor fortescue impression would be the best possible guide , for [no one]383-no one opposed more strongly than [he]116-professor fortescue did the vulgar notion of proprietary rights between [husband]1286-husband and [wife]1287-wife , [no one]383-no one asserted more absolutely the independence of [the individual]4889-the individual . Yet [Hadria]211-hadria could not imagine that [he]116-professor fortescue would be anything but profoundly sorry , if [he]116-professor fortescue knew the recklessness of [her]211-hadria feeling , and the nature of [her]211-hadria sentiment for [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . But then [he]116-professor fortescue did not know how [she]211-hadria stood ; [he]116-professor fortescue did not know that the blue hopeful distance of life had disappeared ; that even the middle - distance had been cut off , and that the sticks and stones and details of a very speckly foreground now confronted [her]211-hadria immovably . [She]211-hadria would like to learn how [many women of [her]211-hadria temperament]6780-many women of her temperament , placed in [her]211-hadria position , would stop to enquire very closely into the right and wrong of the matter , when for a moment , a little avenue seemed on the point of opening , misty and blue , leading the eye to hidden perilous distances . And then [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had , after all , many fine qualities . [He]181-professor theobald was complex , and [he]181-professor theobald had faults like the rest of [us]6781-us ; but the more one knew [him]181-professor theobald , the more [one]329-one felt [his]181-professor theobald kindness of heart ( how good [he]181-professor theobald was to [little Martha]129-martha ) , [his]181-professor theobald readiness to help [others]432-others , [his]181-professor theobald breadth of view and [his]181-professor theobald sympathy . These were not common qualities . [He]181-professor theobald was [a mall whom one]6784-a mall whom one could admire , despite certain traits that made [one]329-one shrink a little , at times . These moreover had disappeared of late . They were accidental rather than intrinsic . It was a matter of daily observation that [people]3687-people catch superficial modes of thought and speech , just as [they]3687-people catch accent , or as [women who have given no thought to the art of dress]6787-women who have given no thought to the art of dress , sometimes misrepresent [themselves]6787-women who have given no thought to the art of dress , by adopting , unmodified , whatever happens to be in the fashion . [Hadria]211-hadria had a wistful desire to be able to respect [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald without reserve , to believe in [him]181-professor theobald thoroughly , to think [him]181-professor theobald noble in calibre and fine in fibre . [She]211-hadria had a vague idea that emphatic statement could conduce to making all this true . [She]211-hadria had never met [him]181-professor theobald alone since that day of the picnic , except for a few chance minutes , when [he]181-professor theobald had expressed over again , rather in tone than in words , the sentiment before implied . [Algitha]81-algitha and [Miss Du Prel]109-valeria were relieved to see that [Hadria]211-hadria had , after all , taken [their]6787-women who have given no thought to the art of dress advice . Without making any violent or obvious change in [her]211-hadria conduct , [she]211-hadria had ceased to cause [[her]211-hadria friends]4444-her friends anxiety . Something in [her]211-hadria manner had changed . [Claude Moreton]178-claude moreton felt it instantly . [He]178-claude moreton spoke of leaving [Craddock Place]29-craddock place , but [he]178-claude moreton lingered on . [The house]296-the house had begun to empty . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton wished to have some time to [herself]176-lady engleton . [She]176-lady engleton was painting a new picture . But [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald remained . [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming went away to stay with [[his]159-joseph fleming married sister]6790-his married sister . About this time [Hubert]118-hubert had to go abroad to attend to some business matters of a serious and tedious character , connected with a law - suit in which [he]118-hubert was professionally interested . From some instinct which [Hadria]211-hadria found difficult to account for , [she]211-hadria avoided meeting [the Professor]4071-the professor alone . Yet the whole interest of the day centred in the prospect of seeing [him]4071-the professor . If by chance , [she]211-hadria missed [him]4071-the professor , [she]211-hadria felt flat and dull , and found [herself]211-hadria going over in [her]211-hadria mind every detail of [their]3064-their last meeting . [He]4071-the professor had the art of making [his]4071-the professor most trifling remark interesting . Even [his]4071-the professor comments on the weather had a colour and quality of [their]3064-their own . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton admired [his]4071-the professor lightness of touch . ‚Äú[3062-my dear lady] Did [you]3063-you know that [[our]3064-their amiable [Professor]181-professor theobald]3065-our amiable professor shews [his]181-professor theobald devotion to [you]3063-you , by devotion to [[your]3063-you prot√©g√©e]3066-your prot√©g√©e ? ‚Äù [she]176-lady engleton asked one day , when [she]176-lady engleton met [Hadria]211-hadria returning from [the Priory]1664-the priory with [the two boys , whose holidays were not yet over]6793-the two boys , whose holidays were not yet over . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] [I]0-i saw [him]181-professor theobald coming out of [[the child]4983-the child 's cottage]3068-the child 's cottage this morning , and [she]0-i shewed [me]0-i the toy [he]181-professor theobald had given [her]0-i . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [He]181-professor theobald is very fond of [her]0-i , [I]0-i know , ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] [He]181-professor theobald gives [her]0-i lots of things ! ‚Äù cried [Jack]277-jack , opening round and envious eyes . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] How do [you]181-professor theobald know , [sir]5634-sir ? ‚Äù enquired [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] Because [Mary]128-mary says so , ‚Äù [Jack]277-jack returned . [Hadria]211-hadria was pleased at the kindness which the act seemed to indicate . [The doctor]1471-the doctor had ordered [her]211-hadria to be in the open air as much as possible , and to take a walk every day . Sometimes [she]211-hadria would walk with [the boys]3870-the boys , sometimes alone . In either case , the thought of [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald pursued [her]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria often grew wearied with it , but it could not be banished . If [she]211-hadria saw [a distant figure on the road , a little sick , excited stir of the heart]6796-a distant figure on the road , a little sick , excited stir of the heart , betrayed [her]211-hadria suspicion that it might be [he]181-professor theobald . [She]211-hadria could not sincerely wish [herself]211-hadria free from the strange infatuation , for the thought of life without it , troublesome and fatiguing though it was , seemed inexpressibly dull . It had taken the colour out of everything . It had altered the very face of nature , in [her]211-hadria eyes . [Her]211-hadria hope had been to escape loneliness , but with this preposterous secret , [she]211-hadria was lonelier than [she]211-hadria had ever been before . [She]211-hadria could no longer make [a confidante of [herself]211-hadria]6797-a confidante of herself . [She]211-hadria was afraid of [her]211-hadria own ridicule , [her]211-hadria own blame , above all of finding [herself]211-hadria confronted with some accusation against [the Professor]4071-the professor , some overpowering reason for thinking poorly of [him]4071-the professor . Whenever [they]6799-they met , [she]211-hadria was in terror lest [he]4071-the professor should leave [her]211-hadria no alternative . [She]211-hadria often opened conversational channels by which [he]4071-the professor could escape [his]4071-the professor unknown peril , and [she]211-hadria would hold [her]211-hadria breath till it was over . [She]211-hadria dreaded [the cool - headed , ruthless critic]6800-the cool - headed , ruthless critic , lurking within [her]211-hadria own consciousness , who would hear of no ingenious explanations of words or conduct . But [she]211-hadria would not admit to this dread ‚Äî that would have been to admit everything . [She]211-hadria had not the satisfaction of openly thinking the matter out , for the suspicion that so profoundly saddened [her]211-hadria , must be kept scrupulously hidden . [Hadria]211-hadria was filled with dismay when [she]211-hadria dared to glance at the future . No wonder [Valeria]109-valeria had warned [her]211-hadria against playing with fire ! Was it always like this when [people]3687-people fell in love ? What a ridiculous , uncomfortable , outrageous thing it was ! How destructive to common sense and sanity and everything that kept life running on reasonable lines . A poor joke at best , and oh , how stale ! ‚Äú[128-mary] Shall [I]0-i tell [you]3070-you [your]3070-you ruling passion , [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] If [you]3070-you can , [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . ‚Äù Before [them]6802-them stretched [a woodland glade]6803-a woodland glade . The broad fronds of the bracken made bright patches of light where the sun caught them , and tall plants , such as hemlock and wild parsley , stood out , almost white against the shade ; the flies and midges moving round [them]6802-them in the warmth . At some distance behind , the sound of voices could be heard through the windings of the wood . There were snatches of song and laughter . ‚Äú[181-professor theobald] [Your]3070-you ruling passion is power over [others]432-others . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3070-you] It has been sadly thwarted then , ‚Äù [she]154-mrs. temperley answered , with a nervous laugh . ‚Äú[3070-you] Thwarted ? [She]154-mrs. temperley could do nothing but walk on in silence . ‚Äú[3074-even an actor] [Even an actor]3074-even an actor does not impress [himself]3074-even an actor so directly upon [[his]3074-even an actor fellows]951-his fellows as [a woman]3753-a woman of ‚Äî well , [a woman like [yourself]3070-you]3077-a woman like yourself . [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley ‚Äî [Hadria]211-hadria ‚Äî ‚Äù [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had stopped short in the path , and then [Hadria]211-hadria made some drowning effort to resist the force that [she]211-hadria still feared . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald advanced a step . [Hadria]211-hadria drew back . The sweet cadence died away . A bird 's note took up the dropped thread of music . Again came the voice of [the singer]6810-the singer , nearer this time . The song was hummed softly . THE need for vigilance over that hidden distrust was more peremptory now than ever . The confession once made , the die once cast , anything but complete faith and respect became intolerable . Outwardly , affairs seemed to run on very much as before . But [Hadria]211-hadria could scarcely believe that [she]211-hadria was living in [the same world]6811-the same world . The new fact walked before [her]211-hadria , everywhere . [She]211-hadria did not dare to examine it closely . [She]211-hadria told [herself]211-hadria that a great joy had come to [her]211-hadria , or rather that [she]211-hadria had taken the joy in spite of everything and [everybody]3781-everybody . [She]211-hadria would order [her]211-hadria affections exactly as [she]211-hadria chose . If only [she]211-hadria could leave [Craddock Dene]22-craddock dene ! [Hubert]118-hubert and [[her]211-hadria parents]3931-her parents considered the opinion of [the public]4347-the public as of more importance than anything else in life ; for [[her]211-hadria mother]520-her mother 's sake [she]211-hadria was forced to acquiesce ; otherwise there was absolutely no reason why [she]211-hadria and [Hubert]118-hubert should live under the same roof . It was a mere ceremony kept up on account of [others]432-others . That had been acknowledged by [him]118-hubert in so many words . And a wretched , ridiculous , irksome ceremony it was for [them]6817-them both . [Hadria]211-hadria refused now to meet [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald at [the Cottage]1763-the cottage . [His]181-professor theobald visits [there]571-there , which had been timed to meet [her]211-hadria , must be paid at a different hour . [He]181-professor theobald remonstrated in vain . [She]211-hadria shewed various other inconsistencies , as [he]181-professor theobald called them . [He]181-professor theobald used to laugh affectionately at [her]211-hadria ‚Äú[3089-she] glimpses of conscience , ‚Äù but said [he]181-professor theobald cared nothing for these trifles , since [he]181-professor theobald had [her]211-hadria assurance that [she]211-hadria loved [him]181-professor theobald . How [he]181-professor theobald had waited and longed for that ! How hopeless , how impossible it had seemed . [He]181-professor theobald professed to have fallen in love at first sight . [He]181-professor theobald even declared that [Hadria]211-hadria had done the same , though in a different way , without knowing it . [Her]211-hadria mind had resisted and , for the time , kept [her]211-hadria feelings in abeyance . [He]181-professor theobald had watched the struggle . [Her]211-hadria heart , [he]181-professor theobald rejoiced to believe , had responded to [him]181-professor theobald from the beginning . By dint of repeating this very often , [he]181-professor theobald had half convinced [Hadria]211-hadria that it was so . [She]211-hadria preferred to think that [her]211-hadria feeling was of the long - standing and resistless kind . Sometimes [she]211-hadria had intervals of reckless happiness , when all doubts were kept at bay , and the condition of belief that [she]211-hadria assiduously cultivated , remained with [her]211-hadria freely . [She]211-hadria felt no secret tug at the tether . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald would then be at [his]181-professor theobald best ; grave , thoughtful , gentle , considerate , responsive to every mood . When [they]6820-they met at [Craddock Place]29-craddock place and elsewhere , [Hadria]211-hadria suffered miseries of anxiety . [She]211-hadria was terrified lest [he]181-professor theobald should do or say something in bad taste , and that [she]211-hadria would see [her]211-hadria own impression confirmed on the faces of [others]432-others . [She]211-hadria put it to [herself]211-hadria that [she]211-hadria was afraid [people]3687-people would not understand [him]181-professor theobald as [she]211-hadria did . The history of [his]181-professor theobald past life , as [he]181-professor theobald had related it to [her]211-hadria , appealed overpoweringly to all that was womanly and protective in [her]211-hadria nature . [He]181-professor theobald was emotional by temperament , but circumstance had doomed [him]181-professor theobald to repression and solitude . This call on [her]211-hadria sympathy did more than anything to set [Hadria]211-hadria 's mind at rest . [She]211-hadria gave a vast sigh when that feeling of confidence became confirmed . Life , then , need no longer be ridiculous ! Hard and cruel it might be , full of lost dreams , but at least there would be something in it that was perfect . [This new emotional centre]6823-this new emotional centre offered the human summun bonum : release from [oneself]6824-oneself . [I]0-i should like to speak out and be honest about it . ‚Äù ‚Äú[832-your mother] And [[your]0-i mother]832-your mother ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[832-your mother] Oh , [I]0-i know of course ‚Äî ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria set [her]211-hadria teeth . ‚Äú[832-your mother] It drives [me]0-i mad , all this ! ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] Oh , [Hadria]211-hadria ! The question that turned up , in the course of discussion , was this : If [a man]3704-a man stands in a position which is itself the result of an aggression upon [his]3704-a man liberty and [his]3704-a man human rights , is [he]3704-a man in honour bound to abide by the laws which are laid down to coerce [him]3704-a man ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[3704-a man] Obviously not , ‚Äù replied [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue . ‚Äú[3704-a man] Is [he]3704-a man morally justified in using every means [he]3704-a man can lay hold of to overcome the peculiar difficulties under which [he]3704-a man has been tyrannously placed ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[3704-a man] Not merely justified , but [I]0-i should say [he]3704-a man was [a poor fool]3153-a poor fool if [he]3704-a man refrained from doing so . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3153-a poor fool] That is exactly what [I]0-i say . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] Surely [Mrs. Temperley]154-mrs. temperley does not demur ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[154-mrs. temperley] No ; [I]0-i quite agree as to the right . [Hadria]211-hadria had been growing more and more restless since the arrival of [the new - comer]1028-the new - comer . [She]211-hadria took no further part in the conversation . Some domestic catastrophe had happened at [the Red House]4718-the red house . [The cook]1504-the cook had called [Mary]128-mary ‚Äú[3821-my dear fellow] names , ‚Äù and [Mary]128-mary declared [she]128-mary must leave . [Hadria]211-hadria shrugged [her]211-hadria shoulders . ‚Äú[3821-my dear fellow] Oh , well then , [I]0-i suppose [you]3189-you must , ‚Äù [she]211-hadria said wearily , and retired to [[her]211-hadria room]4419-her room , in a mood to be cynically amused at the tragedies that [the human being]5264-the human being manufactures for [himself]5264-the human being , lest [he]5264-the human being should not find the tragedies of birth and death and parting , and the solitude of the spirit , sufficient to occupy [him]5264-the human being during [his]5264-the human being little pilgrimage . [She]211-hadria sat by the open window that looked out over [the familiar fields]6888-the familiar fields , and [the garden that was gay with summer flowers]6889-the garden that was gay with summer flowers . The red roof of [the Priory]1664-the priory could just be caught through the trees of [the park]2144-the park . [She]211-hadria wished the little pilgrimage were over . A common enough wish , [she]211-hadria commented , but surely not unreasonable . The picture of [those two men]6892-those two men came back to [her]211-hadria , in spite of every effort to banish it . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue had affected [her]211-hadria as if [he]116-professor fortescue had brought with [him]116-professor fortescue a new atmosphere , and disastrous was the result . It seemed as if [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had suddenly become a stranger to [her]211-hadria , whom [she]211-hadria criticised , whose commonness of fibre , ah [me]3189-you ! whose coarseness , [she]211-hadria saw as [she]211-hadria might have seen it in some casual acquaintance . And yet [she]211-hadria had loved [this man]4247-this man , [she]211-hadria had allowed [him]4247-this man to passionately profess love for [her]211-hadria . [His]4247-this man companionship , in the deepest sense , had been chosen by [her]211-hadria for life . To sit by and listen to that conversation , feeling every moment how utterly [he]4247-this man and [she]211-hadria were , after all , [strangers to one another]6894-strangers to one another , how completely unbroken was the solitude that [she]211-hadria had craved to dispel ‚Äî that had been horrible . What had lain at the root of [her]211-hadria conduct ? How had [she]211-hadria deceived [herself]211-hadria ? Was it not for the sake of mere excitement , distraction ? Was it not the sensuous side of [her]211-hadria nature that had been touched , while the rest had been posing in the foreground ? But no , that was only partly true . There had been more in it than that ; very much more , or [she]211-hadria could not have deceived [herself]211-hadria so completely . It was this craving to fill the place of [her]211-hadria lost art,‚Äîbut oh , what morbid nonsense it had all been ! Why , for the first time in [her]211-hadria life , did [she]211-hadria feel ashamed to meet [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue ? Obviously , it was not because [she]211-hadria thought [he]4247-this man would disapprove of [her]211-hadria breaking the social law . It was because [she]211-hadria had fallen below [her]211-hadria own standard , because [she]211-hadria had been hypocritical with [herself]211-hadria , played [herself]211-hadria false , and acted contemptibly , hatefully ! [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's mere presence had hunted out the truth from its hiding - place . [He]116-professor fortescue had made further self - sophistication impossible . [She]211-hadria buried [her]211-hadria face in [her]211-hadria hands , in an agony of shame . [She]211-hadria had known all along , that this had not been a profound and whole - hearted sentiment . [She]211-hadria had known all along , of what a poor feverish nature it was ; yet [she]211-hadria had chosen to persuade [herself]211-hadria that it was all , or nearly all , that [she]211-hadria had dreamed of a perfect human relationship . [She]211-hadria had tried to arrange facts in such a light as to simulate that idea . It was so paltry , so contemptible . Why could [she]211-hadria not at least have been honest with [herself]211-hadria , and owned to the nature of the infatuation ? That , at any rate , would have been straightforward . [Her]211-hadria self - scorn made the colour surge into [her]211-hadria cheeks and burn painfully over neck and brow . ‚Äú[3189-you] How [little one]2165-little one knows [oneself]3191-oneself . Here am [I]0-i , who rebel against the beliefs of [others]432-others , sinning against [my]0-i own . Here am [I]0-i , who turn up [my]0-i nose at the popular gods , deriding [my]0-i own private and particular gods in [[their]3193-their very temples]3194-their very temples ! That [I]0-i have done , and heaven alone knows where [I]0-i should have stopped in the wild work , if this had not happened . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue has no need to speak . [His]116-professor fortescue gentleness , [his]116-professor fortescue charity , are as rods to scourge [one]329-one ! ‚Äù WHEN [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue called at [the Red House]4718-the red house , [he]116-professor fortescue found that the blinds , in [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room , were all half down . [Hadria]211-hadria held the conversation to the subject of [his]116-professor fortescue plans . [He]116-professor fortescue knew [her]211-hadria well enough to read the meaning of that quiet tone , with a subtle cadence in it , just at the end of a phrase , that went to [his]116-professor fortescue heart . To [him]116-professor fortescue it testified to an unspeakable regret . It was difficult to define the change in [her]211-hadria manner , but it conveyed to [the visitor]4013-the visitor the impression that [she]211-hadria had lost belief in [herself]211-hadria , or in some one ; that [she]211-hadria had received a severe shock , and knew no longer what to trust or how to steer . [She]211-hadria seemed to speak across some vast spiritual distance , an effect not produced by reserve or coldness , but by a wistful , acquiescent , subdued quality , expressive of uncertainty , of disorder in [her]211-hadria conceptions of things . ‚Äú[116-professor fortescue] How tempting those two easy - chairs look , under the old tree on [[your]3196-you lawn]3197-your lawn , ‚Äù said [the Professor]4071-the professor . ‚Äú[116-professor fortescue] Would n't it be pleasant to go out ? ‚Äù [Hadria]211-hadria hesitated for a second , and then rose . ‚Äú[116-professor fortescue] Certainly ; [we]3198-their will have tea [there]571-there . ‚Äù When [they]3198-their were seated under the shade taking [their]3198-their tea , with the canopy of walnut leaves above [their]3198-their heads , [the Professor]4071-the professor saw that [Hadria]211-hadria shewed signs of serious trouble . The haggard lines , the marks of suffering , were not to be hidden in the clear light of the summer afternoon . [He]4071-the professor insensibly shifted [his]4071-the professor chair so as not to have to gaze at [her]211-hadria when [he]4071-the professor spoke . That seemed to be a relief to [her]211-hadria . ‚Äú[116-professor fortescue] [Valeria]109-valeria is here till the day after to - morrow , ‚Äù [she]211-hadria said . ‚Äú[109-valeria] [She]109-valeria has gone for a walk , and has probably forgotten the tea - hour ; but [I]0-i hope [you]3196-you will see [her]109-valeria . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i want to find out what [her]109-valeria plans are . It corresponds to the raised arm when a blow threatens . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3196-you] One has the choice between egoism and extinction . ‚Äù ‚Äú[3196-you] It almost amounts to that . [Most people]4077-most people become extinct , and then congratulate [themselves]4077-most people on self - conquest . ‚Äù ‚Äú[4077-most people] Yes , [I]0-i suppose so , ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria musingly . ‚Äú[4077-most people] How dangerous it is to congratulate [oneself]3203-oneself on anything ! [One]329-one never is so near to folly as then . ‚Äù [The Professor]4071-the professor threw some crumbs to a chaffinch , which had flown down within a few yards of the tea - table . ‚Äú[329-one] [I]0-i think [you]3196-you are disposed , at present , to criticise [yourself]3196-you too mercilessly , ‚Äù [he]4071-the professor said in a tone that had drawn forth many a confidence . [Beginners]3207-beginners must make wrong moves now and then . ‚Äù There was a long pause . ‚Äú[0-i] It sounds so mild when [you]0-i put it like that . But [I]0-i am not [a beginner]3208-a beginner . [I]0-i am quite [a veteran]3209-a veteran , yet [I]0-i am not seasoned . [My]0-i impulses are more imperious , more blinding than [I]0-i had the least idea of . ‚Äù ( The words hastened on . ) ‚Äú[0-i] Life comes and pulls [one]329-one by the sleeve ; stirs , prompts , bewilders , tempts in a thousand ways ; emotion rises in whirlwinds ‚Äî and [one]329-one is confused , and reels and gropes and stumbles , and then some cruel , clear day one awakes to find the print of intoxicated footsteps in [the precincts of [the sanctuary]3213-the sanctuary]3212-the precincts of the sanctuary , and recognises [oneself]329-one as [desecrator]3214-desecrator . ‚Äù [The Professor]4071-the professor leant forward in [his]4071-the professor low chair . There was a step on the lawn behind [them]3217-they . [The Professor]4071-the professor sprang up . [He]4071-the professor went to meet [Valeria]109-valeria and [they]3217-they came to the table together , talking . [Valeria]109-valeria 's eyes were bright and [her]109-valeria manner animated . Yes , [she]109-valeria was going abroad . It would be delightful to meet somewhere , if chance favoured [them]3217-they . [She]109-valeria thought of [Italy]11-italy . And at that magic name , [they]3217-they fell into reminiscences of former journeyings ; [they]3217-they talked of [towns]6905-towns and [temples]6906-temples and [palaces]6907-palaces , of art , of sunshine ; and [Hadria]211-hadria listened silently . Once , in [her]109-valeria girlhood , when [she]109-valeria was scarcely sixteen [she]109-valeria had gone with [[her]109-valeria parents]3931-her parents and [Algitha]81-algitha for a tour in [Italy]11-italy . It was a short but vivid experience which had tinged [her]109-valeria life , leaving a memory and a longing that never died . The movement of travel , the sense of change and richness offered to eye and mind , remained with [her]109-valeria always ; the vision of a strange , tumultuous , beautiful world ; of [exquisite Italian cities , of [forests and seas]6910-forests and seas]6909-exquisite italian cities , of forests and seas ; of [classic plains]6911-classic plains and [snow - capped mountains]6912-snow - capped mountains ; of treasures of art ‚Äî the eternal evidence of [man]332-man 's aloofness , on one side of [him]332-man , from the savage element in nature ‚Äî and glimpses of cathedral domes and [palace walls]6914-palace walls ; and [villages]5951-villages clinging like living things to [the hill - sides]6916-the hill - sides , or dreaming away [their]5951-villages drowsy days in [some sunny valley]6917-some sunny valley . And then the mystery that every work of [man]332-man enshrines ; the life , the thought , the need that it embodies , and the passionate histories that it hides ! It was as if the sum and circumstance of life had mirrored itself in the memory , once and for all . [The South]10-the south lured [her]0-i with its languor , its colour , its hot sun , and its splendid memories . It was exquisite pleasure and exquisite pain to listen to the anticipations of [these two , who were able to wander]6919-these two , who were able to wander as [they]6919-these two , who were able to wander would . ‚Äú[281-siena] [Siena]281-siena ? ‚Äù said [Valeria]109-valeria with a sigh , ‚Äú[281-siena] [I]0-i used to know [Siena]281-siena when [I]0-i was young and happy . [I]0-i might have married [a good and brilliantly intellectual man]3218-a good and brilliantly intellectual man , whom [I]0-i could respect and warmly admire ; for whom [I]0-i had every feeling but the one that [we]3219-we romantic women think so essential , and that [people]3687-people assure [us]3219-we is the first to depart . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] [You]0-i regret that [you]0-i held fast to [your]0-i own standard ? ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i regret that [I]0-i could not see the wisdom of taking the good that was offered to [me]0-i , since [I]0-i could not have that which [I]0-i wished . [Valeria]109-valeria shook [her]109-valeria head , and remained silent . But [her]0-i face expressed the sad thoughts left unsaid . In youth , it was all very well . One had [the whole world]6921-the whole world before one , life to explore , [one]329-one 's powers to test . But later on , when all that seemed to promise fades away , when the dreams drift out of sight , and strenuous efforts repeated and repeated , are beaten down by the eternal obstacles ; when the heart is wearied by delay , disappointment , infruition , vain toil , then [this once intoxicating world]6923-this once intoxicating world becomes a place of desolation to [the woman who has rebelled against the common lot]6924-the woman who has rebelled against the common lot . And all the old instincts awake , to haunt and torment ; to demand that which reason has learnt to deny or to scorn ; to burden [[their]3221-civilized women victims]6925-their victims with the cruel heritage of the past ; to whisper regrets and longings , and sometimes to stir to a conflict and desperation that end in madness . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i believe [I]0-i should have been happier , if [I]0-i had married [some commonplace worthy in early life]3222-some commonplace worthy in early life , and been [the mother of ten children]3223-the mother of ten children , ‚Äù [Valeria]109-valeria observed , aloud . But since the embroidery is insisted on , [I]0-i ca n't see that it is of any moral consequence on which side of the canvas one happens to be . ‚Äù ‚Äú[0-i] It is chiefly a matter of luck , ‚Äù said [the Professor]4071-the professor . A long shadow fell across [Hadria]211-hadria as [she]0-i spoke , blotting out the little flicker of the sunlight that shone through the stirring leaves . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald had crept up softly across [the lawn]1843-the lawn , and as the chairs were turned towards the flower - borders , [he]181-professor theobald had approached unobserved . [Hadria]211-hadria gave so violent a start when [she]211-hadria heard [his]181-professor theobald voice , that [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue looked at [her]211-hadria anxiously . [He]116-professor fortescue thought [her]211-hadria nerves must be seriously out of order . The feverish manner of [her]211-hadria greeting to [the new - comer]1028-the new - comer , confirmed [his]181-professor theobald fear . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald apologized for intruding . [He]181-professor theobald had given up [his]181-professor theobald intention of going up to [town]4255-town to - day . [He]181-professor theobald meant to put it off till next week . [He]181-professor theobald could not miss [Fortescue]116-professor fortescue 's visit . [One]329-one could not tell when [one]329-one might see [him]181-professor theobald again . And [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald led the conversation airily on ; talking fluently , and at times brilliantly , but always with that indefinable touch of something ignoble , something coarse , that now filled [Hadria]211-hadria with unspeakable dismay . [She]211-hadria was terrified lest [the other two]6938-the other two should go , and [he]181-professor theobald should remain . And yet [she]211-hadria ought to speak frankly to [him]181-professor theobald . [His]181-professor theobald conversation was full of little under - meanings , intended for [her]211-hadria only to understand ; [his]181-professor theobald look , [his]181-professor theobald manner to [her]211-hadria made [her]211-hadria actually hate [him]181-professor theobald . Yet [she]211-hadria felt the utter inconsequence and injustice of [her]211-hadria attitude . [He]181-professor theobald had not changed . There was nothing new in [him]181-professor theobald . The change was in [herself]211-hadria . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue had awakened [her]211-hadria . But , of course , [he]181-professor theobald was [one in ten thousand]6939-one in ten thousand . It was not fair to make the comparison by which [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald suffered so pitiably . At that moment , as if [Fate]102-fate had intended to prove to [her]211-hadria how badly [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald really stood comparison with [any thoroughly well - bred man]6940-any thoroughly well - bred man , even if infinitely beneath [him]181-professor theobald intellectually , [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming happened to call . [He]181-professor theobald was [his]181-professor theobald old self again , simple , friendly , contented . [Theobald]181-professor theobald was in one of [his]181-professor theobald self - satisfied moods . Perhaps [he]181-professor theobald enjoyed the triumph of [his]181-professor theobald position in regard to [Hadria]211-hadria . [Joseph]159-joseph fleming had no talent to oppose to it , but [he]159-joseph fleming had a simple dignity , the offspring of a kind and generous nature , which made [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald 's conduct towards [him]159-joseph fleming appear contemptible . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue shifted uncomfortably in [his]116-professor fortescue chair . [Hadria]211-hadria tried to change the topic ; the flush deepening in [her]211-hadria cheeks . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue attempted to come to [her]211-hadria aid . [Joseph Fleming]159-joseph fleming laughed good - naturedly . [They]6942-they sat late into the evening . [Hadria]211-hadria went into [the house]296-the house by the open window of [the drawing - room]737-the drawing - room . [She]211-hadria sank back on the sofa ; a blackness came before [her]211-hadria eyes . ‚Äú[0-i] No , no , [I]0-i wo n't , [I]0-i wo n't . [Valeria]109-valeria rushed forward . ‚Äú[0-i] Good heavens , [Hadria]211-hadria ! are [you]211-hadria going to faint ? ‚Äù ‚Äú[211-hadria] No , ‚Äù said [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äú[211-hadria] [I]0-i am not going to faint , if there is such a thing as human will . ‚Äù THE morning had passed as usual , but household arrangements at [the Cottage]1763-the cottage had required much adjustment , [one of [the maids]6950-the maids]6949-one of the maids being ill . [She]6949-one of the maids had been sent away for a rest , and the difficulty was to find another . [Mary]128-mary went from [the Red House]4718-the red house as substitute , in the mean time , and [the Red House]4718-the red house became disorganised . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria look distracted with these little worries , [Hadria]211-hadria . [She]211-hadria stopped at [[Martha]129-martha 's cottage]6954-martha 's cottage for [the child]4983-the child . Ah ! What would become of [her]211-hadria if it were not for [Martha]129-martha ? [The two]4880-the two sauntered together along [the Craddock road]6957-the craddock road . All night long , [Hadria]211-hadria had been trying to decide when and how to speak to [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald . Should [she]211-hadria send for [him]181-professor theobald ? Should [she]211-hadria write to [him]181-professor theobald ? Should [she]211-hadria trust to chance for an opportunity of speaking ? But , no , [she]211-hadria could not endure to see [him]181-professor theobald again in the presence of [others]432-others , before [she]211-hadria had spoken ! [Yesterday]282-yesterday 's experience had been too terrible . [She]211-hadria had brought pencil and paper with [her]211-hadria , in order to be able to write to [him]181-professor theobald , if [she]211-hadria decided on that course . There were plenty of retired nooks under the shade of the yew - trees in [the churchyard]1413-the churchyard , where [one]329-one could write . The thick hedges made [it]1413-the churchyard perfectly secluded , and at this hour , it was always solitary . [Little Martha]129-martha was gathering wild - flowers in the hedges . [She]211-hadria used to pluck them to lay on [[[her]129-martha mother]520-her mother 's grave]6962-her mother 's grave . [The grave]4790-the grave looked fresh and sweet in the summer sunshine , with the ivy creeping up the tomb - stone and half obliterating the name . A rose - tree that [Hadria]211-hadria and [Martha]129-martha had planted together , was laden with rich red blooms . [The two figures]450-the two figures stood , hand in hand , by [the grave]4790-the grave . [The child]4983-the child stooped to place [her]4983-the child little tribute of flowers at the head of the green mound . [Neither of [them]450-the two figures]6546-neither of them noticed [a tall figure at the wicket gate]6973-a tall figure at the wicket gate . [He]6973-a tall figure at the wicket gate stood outside , looking up [the path]3883-the path , absolutely motionless . [Martha]129-martha let go [Hadria]211-hadria 's hand , and ran off after a gorgeous butterfly that had fluttered over the headstone : a symbol of the soul ; fragile , beautiful , helpless thing that any rough hand may crush and ruin . [Hadria]211-hadria turned to watch the graceful , joyous movement of [the child]4983-the child , and [her]211-hadria delight in the beauty of the rich brown wings , with their enamelled spots of sapphire . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria ! ‚Äù [She]4983-the child gave a little gasping cry , and turned sharply . [Professor Theobald]181-professor theobald looked at [her]4983-the child with an intent , triumphant expression . [She]4983-the child stood before [him]181-professor theobald , for the moment , as if paralysed . It was by no means the first time that this look had crossed [his]181-professor theobald face , but [she]4983-the child had been blind , and had not fully understood it . [He]181-professor theobald interpreted [her]4983-the child cry and [her]4983-the child paleness , as signs of the fullness of [his]181-professor theobald power over [her]4983-the child . This pleased [him]181-professor theobald immeasurably . [His]181-professor theobald self - love basked and purred . [He]181-professor theobald felt that [his]181-professor theobald moment of triumph had come . Contrasting this meeting with the last occasion when [they]6976-they had stood together beside [this grave]5597-this grave , had [he]181-professor theobald not ground for self - applause ? [He]181-professor theobald remembered so well that unpleasant episode . It was [Hadria]211-hadria who stood then in the more powerful position . [He]181-professor theobald had actually feared to meet [her]211-hadria eye . [He]181-professor theobald remembered how bitterly [she]4983-the child had spoken , of [her]4983-the child passion for revenge , of the relentless feud between [man]332-man and [woman]3844-woman . [They]6976-they had discussed the question of vengeance ; [he]181-professor theobald had pointed out its futility , and [Hadria]211-hadria had set [her]211-hadria teeth and desired it none the less . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton had reminded [her]4983-the child of [a woman]3753-a woman 's helplessness if [she]4983-the child places [herself]4983-the child in opposition to [a man]3704-a man , for whom all things are ordered in the society that [he]181-professor theobald governs ; [her]4983-the child only chance of striking a telling blow being through [his]181-professor theobald passions . If [he]181-professor theobald were in love with [her]4983-the child , then there might be some hope of making [him]181-professor theobald wince . And [Hadria]211-hadria , with a fierce swiftness had accepted the condition , with a mixture of confidence in [her]211-hadria own power of rousing emotion , if [she]211-hadria willed , and of scorn for the creature who could be appealed to through [his]181-professor theobald passions , but not through [his]181-professor theobald sense of justice . That [she]211-hadria might [herself]211-hadria be in that vulnerable condition , had not appeared to strike [her]211-hadria as possible . It was a challenge that [he]181-professor theobald could not but accept . [She]211-hadria attracted [him]181-professor theobald irresistibly . From the first moment of meeting , [he]181-professor theobald had felt [her]211-hadria power , and recognized , at the same time , the strange spirit of enmity that [she]211-hadria seemed to feel towards [him]181-professor theobald , and to arouse in [him]181-professor theobald against [her]211-hadria . [He]181-professor theobald felt the savage in [him]181-professor theobald awake , the desire of mere conquest . Yes ; and [she]211-hadria should understand the position of affairs to the full , and consent nevertheless ! [Her]211-hadria adoption of [the child]4983-the child had added to [his]181-professor theobald triumph . [He]181-professor theobald could not think of it without a sense of something humourous in the relation of events . If ever Fate was ironical , this was the occasion ! [He]181-professor theobald felt so sure of [Hadria]211-hadria to - day , that [he]181-professor theobald was swayed by an overpowering temptation to reveal to [her]211-hadria the almost comic situation . It appealed to [his]181-professor theobald sense of the absurd , and to the savagery that lurked , like a beast of prey , at the foundation of [his]181-professor theobald nature . [Her]211-hadria evident emotion when [he]181-professor theobald arrived yesterday afternoon and all through [his]181-professor theobald visit , [her]211-hadria agitation to - day , at the mere sound of [his]181-professor theobald voice , assured [him]181-professor theobald that [his]181-professor theobald hold over [her]211-hadria was secure . [He]181-professor theobald must be [a fool]1606-a fool indeed if [he]181-professor theobald could not keep it , in spite of revelations . There was something of [their]6985-their old antagonism , in the attitude in which [they]6985-their stood facing [one another]3945-one another by the side of [the grave]4790-the grave , looking straight into [one another]3945-one another 's eyes . Whether [Theobald]181-professor theobald 's intense consciousness of the situation had , in some way , affected [Hadria]211-hadria , or whether [his]181-professor theobald expression had given a clue , it would be difficult to say , but suddenly , as a whiff of scent invades the senses , [she]211-hadria became aware of a new and horrible fact which had wandered into [her]211-hadria mind , [she]211-hadria knew not how ; and [she]211-hadria took a step backwards , as if stunned , breathing shortly and quickly . Again [he]181-professor theobald interpreted this as a sign of intense feeling . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äù [he]181-professor theobald said bending towards [her]211-hadria , ‚Äú[211-hadria] [you]211-hadria do love [me]0-i ? ‚Äù [He]181-professor theobald did not wait for [her]211-hadria answer , so confident did [he]181-professor theobald feel . ‚Äú[211-hadria] [You]211-hadria love [me]0-i for [myself]0-i , not for [my]0-i virtues or qualities , for [I]0-i have but few of those , alas ! ‚Äù [She]211-hadria tried to speak , but [he]181-professor theobald interrupted [her]211-hadria . ‚Äú[0-i] [I]0-i want to make a confession to [you]211-hadria . There was not a sound , far or near , to break the sense of seclusion . ‚Äú And [you]3291-he mean to tell [me]129-martha [we]7002-we are to part ? With a sudden strong movement , [he]3291-he flung [his]3291-he arms round [her]129-martha and clasped [her]129-martha in an embrace , as fierce and revengeful as the sweep of the wind which sends great trees crashing to the ground , and ships to [the bottom of [the sea]1589-the sea]3296-the bottom of the sea . ‚Äú [You]3291-he do n't love [me]3291-he ? ‚Äù[3291-he] [he]3291-he enquired . ‚Äú Let [me]3291-he go , let [me]3291-he go ‚Äî [coward ‚Äî madman]7003-coward ‚Äî madman ! ‚Äù[3291-he] ‚Äú [You]3291-he do n't love [me]3291-he ? ‚Äù[3291-he] [he]3291-he repeated . ‚Äú [I]3291-he hate [you]3291-he ‚Äî let [me]3291-he go ! ‚Äù[3291-he] ‚Äú If this is the last time ‚Äî ‚Äù[3291-he] ‚Äú [I]3291-he wish [I]3291-he could kill [you]3291-he ! ‚Äù[3291-he] ‚Äú Ah , that is the sort of woman [I]3291-he like ! ‚Äù[3291-he] ‚Äú [You]3291-he make [me]3291-he know what it is to feel like [a murderess]7004-a murderess ! ‚Äù[3291-he] ‚Äú And to look like one , by heaven ! ‚Äù[3291-he] [She]3291-he wrenched [herself]3291-he away , with a furious effort . ‚Äú [Coward]7005-coward ! ‚Äù[3291-he] [she]3291-he cried . ‚Äú [I]3291-he did right to mistrust [you]3298-you ! ‚Äù[3291-he] [Little Martha]129-martha ran up and offered [her]129-martha a wild heartsease which [she]129-martha had found on one of the graves . [Hadria]211-hadria , trembling and white , stooped instinctively to take the flower , and as [she]211-hadria did so , the whole significance of the afternoon 's revelation broke over [her]211-hadria , with fresh intensity . [[His]3298-you child]3299-his child ! After all , [a woman]3753-a woman has probably to be [a wife]1373-a wife and [mother]3851-mother , on the good old terms that have served [the world]334-the world for a fair number of centuries , when one comes to consider it : it is a pity to allow [her]3753-a woman to grow up without those dogmas and sentiments that may help to make the position tolerable , if not always satisfactory , to [her]3753-a woman . Though , as [a philosopher]7026-a philosopher , [one]7027-one may see the absurdity of popular prejudices , yet as [a practical man]7028-a practical man , one feels the inexpediency of disturbing the ideas upon which the system depends , and thus adding to the number of malcontents . [You]211-hadria will not believe [me]4071-the professor , [I]4071-the professor know , so [I]4071-the professor think it better , for this as well as for other reasons , to take [[my]4071-the professor daughter]7031-my daughter under [my]4071-the professor own care . [Hannah]212-hannah will be [there]571-there ‚Äî [she]212-hannah knows everything about [her]212-hannah charge ; and if [she]212-hannah is only allowed to stay ‚Äî ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú [He]4983-the child told [me]211-hadria [he]4983-the child meant to keep [her]129-martha . ‚Äù[211-hadria] ‚Äú [I]211-hadria am thankful for that ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] By this time , the story had flown through [the village]1124-the village ; nothing else was talked of . The excitement was intense . Gossip ran high in [hall]3324-hall and [cottage]3325-cottage . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue alone could not be drawn into the discussion . [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton took [him]116-professor fortescue aside and asked what [he]116-professor fortescue really thought about it . All [he]116-professor fortescue would say was that the whole affair was deeply tragic . [He]116-professor fortescue had no knowledge of the circumstances and feelings involved , and [his]116-professor fortescue judgment must therefore be useless . It seemed more practical to try to help [[one]329-one 's fellows]2089-one 's fellows to resist sin , than to shriek at [convicted sinners]3328-convicted sinners . [His]116-professor fortescue departure had been fixed for the following morning . ‚Äú So [you]211-hadria and [poor little [Martha]129-martha]7066-poor little martha will go up together by [the afternoon train]7067-the afternoon train , [I]176-lady engleton suppose , ‚Äù[176-lady engleton] said [Lady Engleton]176-lady engleton . [Hadria]211-hadria spent the rest of the day at [[Martha]129-martha 's cottage]6954-martha 's cottage . There were many preparations to make . [Hannah]212-hannah was bustling about , [her]212-hannah eyes red with weeping . [She]212-hannah was heart - broken . [She]212-hannah declared that [she]212-hannah could never live with ‚Äú [that bad man]7068-that bad man . ‚Äù[212-hannah] But [Hadria]211-hadria persuaded [her]212-hannah , for [Martha]129-martha 's sake , to remain . And [Hannah]212-hannah , with another burst of tears , gave an assurance which amounted to a pledge , that [she]212-hannah would take a situation with [the Father of [Evil]3330-evil [himself]134-father]134-father , rather than desert [the blessed child]3331-the blessed child . ‚Äú [I]211-hadria wonder if [Martha]129-martha realizes at all what is going to happen , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria sadly , as [she]211-hadria stood watching [the little girl]5857-the little girl playing with [her]5857-the little girl toys . [Martha]129-martha was talking volubly to [the blue man]3333-the blue man . [He]3333-the blue man still clung to a precarious existence ( though [he]3333-the blue man was seriously chipped and faded since the Paris days ) , and had as determined a centre of gravity as ever . ‚Äú [I]212-hannah do n't think [she]211-hadria understands , [ma'am]1503-ma'am , ‚Äù[212-hannah] said [Hannah]212-hannah . ‚Äú [I]212-hannah kep ' on tellin ' [her]211-hadria , and once [she]211-hadria cried and said [she]211-hadria did not want to go , but [she]211-hadria soon forgot it . ‚Äù[212-hannah] [Hadria]211-hadria remained till it was time to dress for dinner . [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue had promised to dine with [her]211-hadria and [Valeria]109-valeria on this last evening . [Little Martha]129-martha had been put early to bed , in order that [she]129-martha might have a long rest before the morrow 's journey . The golden curls lay like strands of silk on the pillow , the bright eyes were closed in healthful slumber . [The child]4983-the child lay , the very image of fresh and pure and sweet human life , with no thought and no dread of the uncertain future that loomed before [her]4983-the child . [Hannah]212-hannah had gone [upstairs]4836-upstairs to pack [her]212-hannah own belongings . The little window was open , as usual , letting the caressing air wander in , as sweet and fresh as the little body and soul to which it had ministered from the beginning . The busy , loud - ticking clock was working on with cheerful unconcern , as if this were just like every other day whose passing moments it had registered . The hands were pointing towards seven , and the dinner hour was half - past seven . [Hadria]211-hadria stood looking down at [the sleeping child]3336-the sleeping child , [her]211-hadria hands resting on the low rail of the cot . There was a desolate look in [her]211-hadria eyes , and something more terrible still , almost beyond definition . It was like the last white glow of some vast fire that has been extinguished . Suddenly ‚Äî as something that gives way by the run , after a long resistance ‚Äî [she]211-hadria dropped upon [her]211-hadria knees beside the cot with a slight cry , and broke into a silent storm of sobs , deep and suppressed . The stillness of [the room]379-the room was unbroken , and [one]329-one could hear the loud tick - tack of the little clock telling off the seconds with business - like exactness . THE evening was sultry . Although the windows of [the dining - room]1265-the dining - room were wide open , not a breath of air came in from [the garden]3867-the garden . A dull , muggy atmosphere brooded sullenly among the masses of the evergreens , and in the thick summer foliage of the old walnut tree on [the lawn]1843-the lawn . ‚Äú How oppressive it is ! ‚Äù[109-valeria] [Valeria]109-valeria exclaimed . [She]109-valeria had been asked to allow [a niece of [Madame Bertaux]195-madame bertaux , who was to join [some friends in [Italy]11-italy]3343-some friends in italy , to make the journey under [[her]109-valeria escort]3344-her escort]3342-a niece of madame bertaux , who was to join some friends in italy , to make the journey under her escort , and the date of [her]109-valeria departure was therefore fixed . [She]109-valeria had decided to return to [town]4255-town on the morrow , to make [her]109-valeria preparations . [Valeria]109-valeria declared impulsively that [she]109-valeria would stay at [home]3770-home , after all . [She]109-valeria could not bear to leave [Hadria]211-hadria for so many lonely months . ‚Äú Oh , no , no , ‚Äù[211-hadria] cried [Hadria]211-hadria in dismay , ‚Äú do n't let [me]211-hadria begin already to impoverish other lives ! ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Valeria]109-valeria remonstrated but [Hadria]211-hadria persisted . ‚Äú At least [I]211-hadria have learnt that lesson , ‚Äù[211-hadria] [she]211-hadria said . ‚Äú [I]211-hadria should have been [a fool]1606-a fool if [I]211-hadria had n't , for [my]211-hadria life has been a sermon on the text . ‚Äù[211-hadria] [Professor Fortescue]116-professor fortescue gave a little frown , as [he]116-professor fortescue often did when some painful idea passed through [his]116-professor fortescue mind . ‚Äú It is happening everywhere , ‚Äù[211-hadria] said [Hadria]211-hadria , ‚Äú the poor , sterile lives exhaust [the strong and full ones]7071-the strong and full ones . [I]211-hadria will not be one of [those vampire souls]7072-those vampire souls , at least not while [I]211-hadria have [my]211-hadria senses about [me]211-hadria . ‚Äù[211-hadria] Again , the little frown of pain contracted [the Professor]4071-the professor 's brow . The dusk had invaded the dinner table , but [they]3348-they had not thought of candles . [They]3348-they went straight out to [the still garden]3349-the still garden . [Valeria]109-valeria had a fan , with which [she]109-valeria vainly tried to overcome the expression of the atmosphere . [She]109-valeria was very low - spirited . [Hadria]211-hadria looked ill and exhausted . [Little Martha]129-martha 's name was not mentioned . It was too sore a subject . ‚Äú [I]109-valeria ca n't bear the idea of leaving [you]211-hadria , [Hadria]211-hadria , especially when [you]211-hadria talk like that . Is all [our]3348-they force to be killed and overwhelmed in this absurd way ? ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú Ah , no , not all , in heaven 's name ! ‚Äù[109-valeria] ‚Äú But if [women]606-women wo n't repudiate , in practice , the claims that [they]606-women hold to be unjust , in theory , how can [they]606-women hope to escape ? [She]109-valeria made some vague statement about strength of character , and holding on through storm and stress to [one]329-one 's purpose ; had not this been the history of all lives worth living ? [Hadria]211-hadria agreed , but pressed the practical question . And that [Valeria]109-valeria could not answer . [She]109-valeria could not bring [herself]109-valeria to say that [the doctor]1471-the doctor 's warnings ought to be disregarded by [Hadria]211-hadria , at the risk of [[her]109-valeria mother]520-her mother 's life .
